"https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/fbi-chief-to-face-questions-over-trump-assassination-attempt-as-he-returns-to-capitol-hill/article_e0e35d63-646c-5cc1-b14f-8e1aa9938845.html", "title": "FBI chief to face questions over Trump assassination attempt as he returns to Capitol Hill", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray is set to testify about the bureau's investigation into the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, with lawmakers at a congressional hearing likely to press him for fresh details about the gunman's motive and background\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- FBI Director Christopher Wray is set to testify Wednesday about the bureau's investigation into the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, with lawmakers at a congressional hearing likely to press him for fresh details about the gunman's motive and background.\n\nThe hearing before the House Judiciary Committee will represent Wray's most detailed comments to date about a shooting that has again thrust the FBI into the political maelstrom as agents continue to investigate the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, and the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the June 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign. Though the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said that it is investigating the Butler, Pennsylvania, shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and President Joe Biden and other officials, and had also looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances. Though the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said that it is investigating the Butler, Pennsylvania, shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and President Joe Biden and other officials, and had also looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances. A law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drove above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nMore from this section\n\nFederal funds fuel quarterly growth in U.S. down payment assistance programs, which now number 2,415\n\nMost airlines except one are recovering from the CrowdStrike tech outage. Though the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said that it is investigating the Butler, Pennsylvania, shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and President Joe Biden and other officials, and had also looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances. A law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drove above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-07-432377728", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:59:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:59:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:19:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_e0e35d63-646c-5cc1-b14f-8e1aa9938845.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers on Wednesday that a laptop tied to the Trump rally gunman included a Google search of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nThat is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nWray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of FBI Director Christopher Wray at https://apnews.com/hub/christopher-wray.", "source": {"uri": "register-herald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Beckley Register-Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@register-herald.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "eric_tucker@register-herald.com", "name": "Eric Tucker", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\nElections\n\nGOP threatened to sue over November ballot if Biden dropped out. Experts call that 'ridiculous'\n\nROBERT YOON Associated Press\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pa.\n\nWray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nJust hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards (180 metres) from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the U.S. House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pa., which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since then-U.S. president Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the U.S. Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the U.S. Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic U.S. President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.", "source": {"uri": "ctvnews.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CTV News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "2024-07-432362898", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:42:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:42:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:19:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9215686321258545, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_cd5aaddf-cf20-539d-8c8b-49007456bd46.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray has told lawmakers that a laptop tied to the Trump rally gunman included a Google search of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers on Wednesday that a laptop tied to the Trump rally gunman included a Google search of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nThat is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nWray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of FBI Director Christopher Wray at https://apnews.com/hub/christopher-wray.\n\nCOPYRIGHT 2024 BY CHANNEL 3000. {"uri": "2024-07-432354659", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:33:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:33:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:19:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9137254953384399, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_de116508-c053-5464-a265-72fbda9eecb4.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray has told lawmakers that a laptop tied to the Trump rally gunman included a Google search of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers on Wednesday that a laptop tied to the Trump rally gunman included a Google search of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nThat is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nWray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of FBI Director Christopher Wray at https://apnews.com/hub/christopher-wray.\n\nMore from this section\n\nOptimal Blue Launches New Generative AI Assistant Capabilities\n\nFederal funds fuel quarterly growth in U.S. down payment assistance programs, which now number 2,415\n\nMMI Taps Dan Jones as Chief Data Officer as It Expands Data Initiatives and Features", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "eric_tucker@kulr8.com", "name": "Eric Tucker", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "2024-07-432345542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:23:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:23:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:55:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://www.bradfordera.com/news/nation/trump-rally-gunman-flew-a-drone-200-yards-from-the-stage-hours-before-the-event/article_c494f479-2cb7-5a67-a8da-17a0e8d9af83.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman flew a drone 200 yards from the stage hours before the event, FBI chief testifies", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray says the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone 200 yards from the rally stage where the Republican ex-president would stand hours later and viewed and livestreamed the footage\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of FBI Director Christopher Wray at https://apnews.com/hub/christopher-wray.", "source": {"uri": "bradfordera.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8241622081", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:32:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:32:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:31:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2024/07/24/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says - Medicine Hat News", "body": "FILE - FBI Director Christopher Wray speaks during a hearing of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Capitol Hill, March 11, 2024, in Washington. Wray is set to testify about the bureau\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s investigation into the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, with lawmakers at a congressional hearing likely to press him for fresh details about the gunman\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s motive and background.(AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein, File)WASHINGTON (AP) - FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers on Wednesday that a laptop tied to the Trump rally gunman included a Google search of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\u009d That is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963. The Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania Wray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee. THIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below. WASHINGTON (AP) - Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday. The FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive. Wray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981. The details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event. Wray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\"\u009d in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific. \"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I've been talking about,\"\u009d Wray said. The hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session. Despite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign. That sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\u009d Though the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions. The FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\"\u009d after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear. Wray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances. A law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance. ___ Follow the AP's coverage of FBI Director Christopher Wray at", "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Medicine Hat News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "canadian_press@medicinehatnews.com", "name": "Canadian Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241638035", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:44:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:44:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:43:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9058823585510254, "url": "https://gvwire.com/2024/07/24/trump-rally-gunman-searched-online-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/", "title": "Trump Rally Gunman Searched Online About Kennedy Assassination, FBI Director Says", "body": "WASHINGTON -- FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers on Wednesday that a laptop tied to the Trump rally gunman included a Google search of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nThat is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nWray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nRelated Story: Secret Service Director Steps Down After Assassination Attempt Against ...\n\nWASHINGTON -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nRelated Story: Trump Credits Chart for Saving His Life, His Former White House Doctor Says\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nRelated Story: Trump Announces He Will Meet with Netanyahu on Friday at Mar-a-Lago\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nWray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nElections Secret Service director steps down after assassination attempt against Trump By COLLEEN LONG The Associated Press\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\nElections GOP threatened to sue over November ballot if Biden dropped out. Experts call that 'ridiculous' ROBERT YOON Associated Press\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "dothaneagle.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Dothan Eagle"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@dothaneagle.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}, {"uri": "manuel_balce_ceneta@dothaneagle.com", "name": "Manuel Balce Ceneta", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "2024-07-432416858", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:41:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:41:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:49:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8980392217636108, "url": "https://www.bradfordera.com/news/nation/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_c494f479-2cb7-5a67-a8da-17a0e8d9af83.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said that Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. The use of the drone so close the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, when Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle,\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of FBI Director Christopher Wray at https://apnews.com/hub/christopher-wray.", "source": {"uri": "bradfordera.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Bradford Era"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@bradfordera.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "eric_tucker@bradfordera.com", "name": "Eric Tucker", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. Wray is set to testify about the bureau's investigation into the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, with lawmakers at a congressional hearing likely to press him for fresh details about the gunman's motive and background.(AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein, File)\n\nThe FBI will \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, the bureau's director told Congress on Wednesday.\n\nChristopher Wray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee was reflecting his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Pennsylvania that once more has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom. Agents are investigating the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, and what was the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's regular oversight of the FBI and Justice Department.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting. Though the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said that it is investigating the Butler, Pennsylvania, shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9758656", "eventUri": "eng-9758656", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-13", "textStart": 878, "textEnd": 885, {"uri": "8241658657", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:00:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:00:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:59:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_5f331edc-3526-5a4c-a5c3-ab5b6cf5510e.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray testifies before a House committee about the July 13 shooting at a campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, Wednesday, July 24, 2024, on Capitol Hill. Wray said that the FBI will \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said that Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. The use of the drone so close the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, when Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle,\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. {"uri": "2024-07-432400056", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:23:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:23:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:08:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://www.rep-am.com/news/2024/07/24/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "WASHINGTON - The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive - or why Trump was singled out - remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials - besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures - and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said that Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. The use of the drone so close the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, when Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle,\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. {"uri": "2024-07-432435750", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:05:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:05:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:05:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://gulftoday.ae/news/2024/07/24/trump-attacker-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says", "title": "Trump's attacker looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, says FBI director", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray testifies before the House Judiciary Committee in the Rayburn House Office Building in Washington on Wednesday. AFP\n\nThe gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said on Wednesday,\n\nRevealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe July 6 online search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov.22, 1963.\n\n\"That is a search that is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears he registered\" for the Trump rally scheduled for July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting, which killed one rally-goer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism.\n\nCrooks was killed by a Secret Service countersniper.\n\nThe investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe agency has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive - or why Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, was singled out - remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI's assessment is that Crooks acted alone.\n\nWray noted that Crooks had grown interested in public officials - besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures - and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump.\n\nCrooks is believed to have visited the rally site a week before the event, staying for about 20 minutes, and then returned on the morning of July 13.\n\nAbout two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally for about 11 minutes, using the device to livestream and watch footage and obtain what Wray said would have been a \"rear view mirror\" of the scene behind him.\n\nThe use of the drone, which along with a controller were recovered from Crooks' car, so close to the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage add to the questions about the security lapses.\n\nOn the afternoon of the rally, Crooks attracted law enforcement scrutiny because of odd behavior around the edges of the event, including shouldering a backpack and peering into the lens of a range finder toward the rooftops behind the stage where Trump would stand within the hour.\n\nUsing what Wray said was mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping, Crooks was able to hoist himself up onto the roof of a squat manufacturing building that was within 135 meters of the stage. Crooks fired eight shots from an AR-style rifle before being he was killed.\n\nThe FBI thinks Crooks may have managed to avoid detection despite being armed because his weapon had a collapsible folding stock, Wray said.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting - as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle.\n\nEven so, Wray was not able to entirely avoid the antagonistic questions he typically receives from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of the lingering perception that the FBI and Justice Department have become politicized against Trump - something Wray has consistently denied.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Though the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said that it is investigating the Butler, Pennsylvania, shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which he said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances. A law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nThis story has been corrected to show the Trump assassination attempt was July 13, not June 13.\n\nCopyright \u00a9 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-07-432173442", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "13:45:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T13:45:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T13:41:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8941176533699036, "url": "https://myfox8.com/news/national/watch-live-fbi-chief-faces-questions-over-the-trump-assassination-attempt/", "title": "WATCH LIVE: FBI chief faces questions over the Trump assassination attempt", "body": "The hearing is expected to begin at 10 a.m. ET and will be livestreamed in the video player above.\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- FBI Director Christopher Wray is set to testify Wednesday about the bureau's investigation into the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, with lawmakers at a congressional hearing likely to press him for fresh details about the gunman's motive and background.\n\nThe hearing before the House Judiciary Committee will represent Wray's most detailed comments to date about a shooting that has again thrust the FBI into the political maelstrom as agents continue to investigate the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, and the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign. Though the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said that it is investigating the Butler, Pennsylvania, shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which he said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.
