{"uri": "8241788018", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:38:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:38:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:38:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://floridapolitics.com/archives/686005-donald-trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-jfk-assassination/", "title": "Donald Trump rally gunman looked online for information about JFK assassination", "body": "'That is a search that is significant in terms of his state of mind,' FBI Director Christopher Wray said.\n\nThe gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe July 6 online search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\n\"That is a search that is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears he registered\" for the Trump rally scheduled for July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism. Crooks was killed by a Secret Service countersniper. The investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a President or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe agency has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI's assessment is that Crooks acted alone.\n\nWray noted that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump.\n\nCrooks is believed to have visited the rally site a week before the event, staying for about 20 minutes, and then returned on the morning of July 13. About two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally for about 11 minutes, using the device to livestream and watch footage and obtain what Wray said would have been a \"rear view mirror\" of the scene behind him.\n\nThe use of the drone, which along with a controller were recovered from Crooks' car, so close to the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage add to the questions about the security lapses.\n\nOn the afternoon of the rally, Crooks attracted law enforcement scrutiny because of odd behavior around the edges of the event, including shouldering a backpack and peering into the lens of a range finder toward the rooftops behind the stage where Trump would stand within the hour.\n\nUsing what Wray said was mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping, Crooks was able to hoist himself up onto the roof of a squat manufacturing building that was within 135 meters (157 yards) of the stage. Crooks fired eight shots from an AR-style rifle before being he was killed.\n\nThe FBI thinks Crooks may have managed to avoid detection despite being armed because his weapon had a collapsible folding stock, Wray said.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting -- as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle.\n\nEven so, Wray was not able to entirely avoid the antagonistic questions he typically receives from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of the lingering perception that the FBI and Justice Department have become politicized against Trump -- something Wray has consistently denied.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee Chair, Republican Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\n___\n\nRepublished with permission of The Associated Press.", "source": {"uri": "floridapolitics.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Florida Politics - Campaigns & Elections. {"uri": "8241346691", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "13:34:05", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T13:34:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T13:33:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://whdh.com/news/fbi-chief-to-face-questions-over-trump-assassination-attempt-as-he-returns-to-capitol-hill/", "title": "FBI chief to face questions over Trump assassination attempt as he returns to Capitol Hill - Boston News, Weather, Sports | WHDH 7News", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- FBI Director Christopher Wray is set to testify Wednesday about the bureau's investigation into the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, with lawmakers at a congressional hearing likely to press him for fresh details about the gunman's motive and background.\n\nThe hearing before the House Judiciary Committee will represent Wray's most detailed comments to date about a shooting that has again thrust the FBI into the political maelstrom as agents continue to investigate the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, and the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign. Though the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said that it is investigating the Butler, Pennsylvania, shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which he said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances. A law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "8241692280", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:24:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:24:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:23:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said that Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. The use of the drone so close the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, when Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle,\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of FBI Director Christopher Wray at https://apnews.com/hub/christopher-wray.\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox28spokane.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 28 Spokane"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241591032", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:11:16", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:11:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:10:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.denver7.com/news/national/trump-rally-gunman-flew-a-drone-200-yards-from-the-stage-hours-before-the-event-fbi-chief-testifies", "title": "Trump rally gunman flew a drone 200 yards from the stage hours before the event, FBI chief testifies", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nMore National Politics videos Can Vice President Harris beat Trump? The drone viewed and livestreamed the footage, Wray said.\n\nThe gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nFBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe July 6 online search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\n\"That is a search that is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears he registered\" for the Trump rally scheduled for July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism.\n\nCrooks was killed by a Secret Service countersniper.\n\nThe investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe agency has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI's assessment is that Crooks acted alone.\n\nWray noted that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump.\n\nCrooks is believed to have visited the rally site a week before the event, staying for about 20 minutes, and then returned on the morning of July 13.\n\nAbout two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally for about 11 minutes, using the device to livestream and watch footage and obtain what Wray said would have been a \"rear view mirror\" of the scene behind him.\n\nThe use of the drone, which along with a controller were recovered from Crooks' car, so close to the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage add to the questions about the security lapses.\n\nOn the afternoon of the rally, Crooks attracted law enforcement scrutiny because of odd behavior around the edges of the event, including shouldering a backpack and peering into the lens of a range finder toward the rooftops behind the stage where Trump would stand within the hour.\n\nUsing what Wray said was mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping, Crooks was able to hoist himself up onto the roof of a squat manufacturing building that was within 135 meters (157 yards) of the stage. Crooks fired eight shots from an AR-style rifle before being he was killed.\n\nThe FBI thinks Crooks may have managed to avoid detection despite being armed because his weapon had a collapsible folding stock, Wray said.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting -- as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle.\n\nEven so, Wray was not able to entirely avoid the antagonistic questions he typically receives from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of the lingering perception that the FBI and Justice Department have become politicized against Trump -- something Wray has consistently denied.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"", "source": {"uri": "nbcchicago.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NBC Chicago"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Matt Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241717037", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:43:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:43:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:42:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.886274516582489, "url": "https://www.news18.com/world/fbi-director-says-gunman-who-shot-trump-researched-kennedy-assassination-on-the-internet-8977465.html", "title": "FBI Director Says Gunman Who Shot Trump Researched Kennedy Assassination On The Internet - News18", "body": "Thomas Matthew Crooks' Google search showed a search being run for the query \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nThe gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said that Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. The use of the drone so close the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, when Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle,\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. {"uri": "8241566627", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:53:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:53:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:53:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.twincities.com/2024/07/23/trump-rally-gunman-flew-a-drone-200-yards-from-the-stage-hours-before-the-event-fbi-chief-testifies/", "title": "Trump rally gunman flew a drone 200 yards from the stage hours before the event, FBI chief testifies", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of FBI Director Christopher Wray at https://apnews.com/hub/christopher-wray.", "source": {"uri": "twincities.com", Agents are investigating the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, and what was the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's regular oversight of the FBI and Justice Department.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting. On Tuesday, Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned.\n\nWray was expected to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the FBI's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nThis story has been corrected to show the assassination attempt on Trump was July 13, not June 13.", "source": {"uri": "bradfordera.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Bradford Era"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@bradfordera.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "eric_tucker@bradfordera.com", "name": "Eric Tucker", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241890486", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:11:30", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:11:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:10:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.kurv.com/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/", "title": "Trump Rally Gunman Looked Online For Information About Kennedy Assassination, FBI Director Says", "body": "(AP) -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe July 6 online search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\n\"That's a search obviously that is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears that he registered\" for the Trump rally scheduled for July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism. Crooks was killed by a Secret Service countersniper. The investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe agency has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"In terms of what we've been able to find so far, a lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI's assessment continues to be that Crooks acted alone, though agents are still investigating.\n\nWray noted that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump and the Butler rally.\n\nCrooks is believed to have visited the rally site a week before the event, staying for about 20 minutes, and then returned on the morning of July 13. More than two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally stage for about 11 minutes, using the device to livestream and watch footage and obtain what Wray said would have been a \"rearview mirror\" of the scene behind him.\n\nThe use of the drone, which along with a controller were recovered from Crooks' car, so close to the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage add to the questions about the security lapses that preceded the shooting.\n\nOn the afternoon of the rally, Crooks attracted law enforcement scrutiny because of odd behavior around the edges of the event, including shouldering a backpack and peering into the lens of a range finder toward the rooftops behind the stage where Trump would stand within the hour.\n\nUsing what Wray said was mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping, Crooks was able to hoist himself up onto the roof of a squat manufacturing building that was within 135 meters (157 yards) of the stage. Crooks fired eight shots from an AR-style rifle before he was killed. (The Warren Commission report that analyzed the Kennedy assassination assessed that Kennedy had been shot through the neck at a range of 174.9 feet to 190.8 feet, or about 53.3 meters to 58.1 meters.)\n\nThe FBI thinks Crooks may have managed to avoid detection in the crowd despite being armed because his weapon had a collapsible folding stock, Wray said.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and very public one -- of what I have been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been schedule well before the shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session, but other topics included the FBI's diversity efforts, election interference and the Jan 6, 2021 riot at the U.S. Capitol.\n\nThough the FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Kimberly Cheatle as the agency's director, Wray was not able to entirely avoid the antagonistic questions he typically receives from the Republican-led committee.\n\nThat's a reflection of the lingering perception among some GOP lawmakers that the FBI and Justice Department in the Biden administration have become politicized against Trump -- something Wray has consistently denied.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"", "source": {"uri": "kurv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "710 KURV - The Valley's News/Talk Station"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Matt Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8242031736", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:32:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:32:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:30:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://www.kob.com/politics-news/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe July 6 online search, recovered from a laptop the FBI says is tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\n\"That's a search obviously that is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears that he registered\" for the Trump rally scheduled for July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism. The investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe agency has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said. The FBI's assessment continues to be that Crooks, who was killed by a Secret Service counter sniper, acted alone.\n\n\"We do not know the motive. That is obviously one of the central questions in our investigation, and it's been very frustrating to us that a lot of the usual kind of low-hanging-fruit places that we would find that have not yielded significant clues about his motive,\" Wray said.\n\nBut, he added, the bureau has seen indications that he was interested in public figures -- officials said at a private briefing last week that besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent people -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump and the Butler rally\n\nCrooks is believed to have visited the rally site a week before the event, staying for about 20 minutes, and then returned on the morning of July 13. More than two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally stage for about 11 minutes, using the device to livestream and watch footage.\n\nThe use of the drone, which along with a controller were recovered from Crooks' car, so close to the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage add to the questions about the security lapses that preceded the shooting.\n\nOn the afternoon of the rally, Crooks attracted law enforcement scrutiny because of odd behavior around the edges of the event, including shouldering a backpack and peering into the lens of a range finder toward the rooftops behind the stage where Trump would stand within the hour.\n\nUsing what Wray said was mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping, Crooks was able to hoist himself up onto the roof of a squat manufacturing building that was within 135 meters (157 yards) of the stage. Crooks fired eight shots from an AR-style rifle before he was killed. (The Warren Commission report that analyzed the Kennedy assassination assessed that Kennedy had been shot through the neck at a range of 174.9 feet to 190.8 feet, or about 53.3 meters to 58.1 meters.)\n\nTrump's campaign said the GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear. Wray said his understanding was that either a bullet or some shrapnel \"is what grazed his ear.\"\n\nHe pledged that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and very public one -- of what I have been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nHe later added, \"I think this is a moment where, in the most stark way possible, all of us as Americans can see how out of control political violence is in this country, and it's an opportunity for everyone to come together and to try to show that this is not the kind of thing we're going to tolerate in this country.\"\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session, but other topics included the FBI's diversity efforts, election interference, the Jan 6, 2021 riot at the U.S. Capitol and whether Wray had personally observed any cognitive decline in meetings with Biden that preceded the president's announcement Sunday that he would not seek reelection.\n\nAfter Wray testified that his interactions had been \"completely professional,\" Trump posted on his Truth Social platform that the FBI director he appointed in 2017 \"has to resign, and NOW, for LYING TO CONGRESS!\"\n\nThe FBI was not involved in ensuring security for the rally and has therefore avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over the lapses that preceded the event. On Tuesday, Kimberly Cheatle resigned as the agency's director.\n\nEven so, Wray was not entirely spared the politically charged and occasionally combative questions he typically receives from the Republican-led committee.\n\nThat's a reflection of the lingering perception among some GOP lawmakers that the FBI and Justice Department in the Biden administration have become politicized against Trump -- something Wray has consistently denied.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray, \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nAt the conclusion of the daylong hearing, he praised Wray for having \"told us some things that weren't even prompted by questions.\"\n\n___\n\nFollow the AP's coverage of FBI Director Christopher Wray at https://apnews.com/hub/christopher-wray.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"uri": "8241594565", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:12:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:12:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:12:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8784313797950745, "url": "https://time.com/7002706/trump-rally-shooter-drone-fbi/", "title": "Trump Gunman Flew Drone 200 Yards from Stage Before Rally, FBI Chief Testifies", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nRead More: Eyewitness Accounts From the Trump Rally Shooting\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nRead More: What We Know -- and Don't Know -- So Far About the Trump Rally Gunman\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent AFP\n\nThe gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said on Wednesday,\n\nRevealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe July 6 online search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov.22, 1963.\n\n\"That is a search that is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears he registered\" for the Trump rally scheduled for July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting, which killed one rally-goer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism.\n\nCrooks was killed by a Secret Service countersniper.\n\nThe investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe agency has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive - or why Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, was singled out - remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI's assessment is that Crooks acted alone.\n\nWray noted that Crooks had grown interested in public officials - besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures - and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump.\n\nCrooks is believed to have visited the rally site a week before the event, staying for about 20 minutes, and then returned on the morning of July 13.\n\nAbout two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally for about 11 minutes, using the device to livestream and watch footage and obtain what Wray said would have been a \"rear view mirror\" of the scene behind him.\n\nThe use of the drone, which along with a controller were recovered from Crooks' car, so close to the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage add to the questions about the security lapses.\n\nOn the afternoon of the rally, Crooks attracted law enforcement scrutiny because of odd behavior around the edges of the event, including shouldering a backpack and peering into the lens of a range finder toward the rooftops behind the stage where Trump would stand within the hour.\n\nUsing what Wray said was mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping, Crooks was able to hoist himself up onto the roof of a squat manufacturing building that was within 135 meters of the stage. Crooks fired eight shots from an AR-style rifle before being he was killed.\n\nThe FBI thinks Crooks may have managed to avoid detection despite being armed because his weapon had a collapsible folding stock, Wray said.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting - as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle.\n\nEven so, Wray was not able to entirely avoid the antagonistic questions he typically receives from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of the lingering perception that the FBI and Justice Department have become politicized against Trump - something Wray has consistently denied.", "source": {"uri": "gulftoday.ae", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Gulf Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241736089", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:58:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:58:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:57:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/us-news/trump-shooter-googled-jfk-assassination-same-day-he-registered-for-rally-fbi-101721842959908.html", "title": "Trump shooter googled JFK assassination same day he registered for rally: FBI", "body": "The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe July 6 online search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\n\"That is a search that is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears he registered\" for the Trump rally scheduled for July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism. Crooks was killed by a Secret Service countersniper. The investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe agency has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI's assessment is that Crooks acted alone.\n\nWray noted that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump.\n\nCrooks is believed to have visited the rally site a week before the event, staying for about 20 minutes, and then returned on the morning of July 13. About two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally for about 11 minutes, using the device to livestream and watch footage and obtain what Wray said would have been a \"rear view mirror\" of the scene behind him.\n\nThe use of the drone, which along with a controller were recovered from Crooks' car, so close to the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage add to the questions about the security lapses.\n\nOn the afternoon of the rally, Crooks attracted law enforcement scrutiny because of odd behavior around the edges of the event, including shouldering a backpack and peering into the lens of a range finder toward the rooftops behind the stage where Trump would stand within the hour.\n\nUsing what Wray said was mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping, Crooks was able to hoist himself up onto the roof of a squat manufacturing building that was within 135 meters (157 yards) of the stage. Crooks fired eight shots from an AR-style rifle before being he was killed.\n\nThe FBI thinks Crooks may have managed to avoid detection despite being armed because his weapon had a collapsible folding stock, Wray said.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting -- as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle.\n\nEven so, Wray was not able to entirely avoid the antagonistic questions he typically receives from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of the lingering perception that the FBI and Justice Department have become politicized against Trump -- something Wray has consistently denied.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. {"uri": "2024-07-432338262", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:16:55", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:16:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:08:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8745098114013672, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/us/fbi-chief-grilled-about-trump-assassination-attempt-reveals-shooter-used-drone-near-the-scene-before-attack/", "title": "FBI chief grilled about Trump assassination attempt; reveals shooter used drone near the scene before attack - Internewscast Journal", "body": "WASHINGTON -- FBI Director Christopher Wray is giving his testimony Wednesday about the bureau's investigation into the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, with lawmakers at a congressional hearing likely to press him for fresh details about the gunman's motive and background.\n\nThe hearing before the House Judiciary Committee will represent Wray's most detailed comments to date about a shooting that has again thrust the FBI into the political maelstrom as agents continue to investigate the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, and the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign. Though the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said that it is investigating the Butler, Pennsylvania, shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which he said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances. A law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nShooter flew drone 200 yards from site hours before shooting\n\nThe shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally venue, and had it up in the air for about 11 minutes, just hours before the shooting, Wray told the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday.\n\nThe drone -- which was recovered in the shooter's car -- was flown at about 3:50 p.m., he said.\n\n\"Let me be clear about the area -- not over the stage, and that part of the area itself, but, I would say, about 200 yards, give or take, away,\" he said. \"And that we think, but we do not know. So again, this is one of these things that's qualified because of our ongoing review.\"\n\nWray confirmed two explosive devices were recovered in Crooks' car and one was recovered in his home.\n\nALSO SEE: New details reveal officers left post to look for Crooks before Trump shooting\n\nWray called them \"relatively crude devices,\" but he added, \"they did have the ability to be detonated remotely.\"\n\nCrooks had a transmitter with him when he was killed by law enforcement.\n\nWray said that based on the positioning of the on and off switch on the devices, \"if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked.\"\n\n\"But that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous,\" he added.", "source": {"uri": "internewscast.com", "dataType": "news", "https://internewscast.com/wp-content/uploads/2024/07/rewrite-this-title-FBI-director-faces-questions-over-Trump-assassination.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9758656", "eventUri": {"uri": "8242029229", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:28:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:28:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:27:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.vaildaily.com/news/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination/", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe July 6 online search, recovered from a laptop the FBI says is tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\n\"That's a search obviously that is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears that he registered\" for the Trump rally scheduled for July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism. The investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe agency has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said. The FBI's assessment continues to be that Crooks, who was killed by a Secret Service counter sniper, acted alone.\n\n\"We do not know the motive. That is obviously one of the central questions in our investigation, and it's been very frustrating to us that a lot of the usual kind of low-hanging-fruit places that we would find that have not yielded significant clues about his motive,\" Wray said.\n\nBut, he added, the bureau has seen indications that he was interested in public figures -- officials said at a private briefing last week that besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent people -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump and the Butler rally\n\nCrooks is believed to have visited the rally site a week before the event, staying for about 20 minutes, and then returned on the morning of July 13. More than two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally stage for about 11 minutes, using the device to livestream and watch footage.\n\nThe use of the drone, which along with a controller were recovered from Crooks' car, so close to the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage add to the questions about the security lapses that preceded the shooting.\n\nOn the afternoon of the rally, Crooks attracted law enforcement scrutiny because of odd behavior around the edges of the event, including shouldering a backpack and peering into the lens of a range finder toward the rooftops behind the stage where Trump would stand within the hour.\n\nUsing what Wray said was mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping, Crooks was able to hoist himself up onto the roof of a squat manufacturing building that was within 135 meters (157 yards) of the stage. Crooks fired eight shots from an AR-style rifle before he was killed. (The Warren Commission report that analyzed the Kennedy assassination assessed that Kennedy had been shot through the neck at a range of 174.9 feet to 190.8 feet, or about 53.3 meters to 58.1 meters.)\n\nTrump's campaign said the GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear. Wray said his understanding was that either a bullet or some shrapnel \"is what grazed his ear.\"\n\nHe pledged that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and very public one -- of what I have been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nHe later added, \"I think this is a moment where, in the most stark way possible, all of us as Americans can see how out of control political violence is in this country, and it's an opportunity for everyone to come together and to try to show that this is not the kind of thing we're going to tolerate in this country.\"\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session, but other topics included the FBI's diversity efforts, election interference, the Jan 6, 2021 riot at the U.S. Capitol and whether Wray had personally observed any cognitive decline in meetings with Biden that preceded the president's announcement Sunday that he would not seek reelection.\n\nAfter Wray testified that his interactions had been \"completely professional,\" Trump posted on his Truth Social platform that the FBI director he appointed in 2017 \"has to resign, and NOW, for LYING TO CONGRESS!\"\n\nThe FBI was not involved in ensuring security for the rally and has therefore avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over the lapses that preceded the event. On Tuesday, Kimberly Cheatle resigned as the agency's director.\n\nEven so, Wray was not entirely spared the politically charged and occasionally combative questions he typically receives from the Republican-led committee.\n\nThat's a reflection of the lingering perception among some GOP lawmakers that the FBI and Justice Department in the Biden administration have become politicized against Trump -- something Wray has consistently denied.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray, \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nAt the conclusion of the daylong hearing, he praised Wray for having \"told us some things that weren't even prompted by questions.\"", "source": {"uri": "vaildaily.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Vail Daily"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241671426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:09:25", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:09:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:08:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://wsvn.com/news/politics/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says - WSVN 7News | Miami News, Weather, Sports | Fort Lauderdale", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said that Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. The use of the drone so close the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, when Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle,\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press.
