{"uri": "8241653870", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:56:53", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:56:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:56:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8705882430076599, "url": "https://www.pressherald.com/2024/07/24/trump-gunman-searched-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/", "title": "Trump gunman searched for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray speaks during a hearing of the Senate Intelligence Committee on Capitol Hill, March 11, 2024, in Washington. AP Photo/Mark Schiefelbein, File\n\nWASHINGTON -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said that Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. The use of the drone so close the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, when Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle,\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nCopy the Story Link Related Headlines Three days after attempted assassination, Trump shooter remains an enigma Secret Service director steps down after Trump assassination attempt\n\nComments are not available on this story.\n\nSend questions/comments to the editors.\n\nfiled under: Donald Trump, FBI Related Stories Latest Articles", "source": {"uri": "pressherald.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Portland Press Herald"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "2024-07-432475438", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:56:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:56:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:41:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8666666746139526, "url": "https://www.fox13memphis.com/news/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_5285a060-49ec-11ef-a744-8bb8c0a2f7f2.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe July 6 online search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\n\"That is a search that is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears he registered\" for the Trump rally scheduled for July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism. Crooks was killed by a Secret Service countersniper. The investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe agency has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI's assessment is that Crooks acted alone.\n\nWray noted that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump.\n\nCrooks is believed to have visited the rally site a week before the event, staying for about 20 minutes, and then returned on the morning of July 13. About two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally for about 11 minutes, using the device to livestream and watch footage and obtain what Wray said would have been a \"rear view mirror\" of the scene behind him.\n\nThe use of the drone, which along with a controller were recovered from Crooks' car, so close to the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage add to the questions about the security lapses.\n\nOn the afternoon of the rally, Crooks attracted law enforcement scrutiny because of odd behavior around the edges of the event, including shouldering a backpack and peering into the lens of a range finder toward the rooftops behind the stage where Trump would stand within the hour.\n\nUsing what Wray said was mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping, Crooks was able to hoist himself up onto the roof of a squat manufacturing building that was within 135 meters (157 yards) of the stage. Crooks fired eight shots from an AR-style rifle before being he was killed.\n\nThe FBI thinks Crooks may have managed to avoid detection despite being armed because his weapon had a collapsible folding stock, Wray said.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting -- as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle.\n\nEven so, Wray was not able to entirely avoid the antagonistic questions he typically receives from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of the lingering perception that the FBI and Justice Department have become politicized against Trump -- something Wray has consistently denied.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nDownload the FOX13 Memphis app to receive alerts from breaking news in your neighborhood.\n\nCLICK HERE TO DOWNLOAD\n\nTrending stories:\n\n'I had to do it': Affidavit sheds light on Main Event murder Inmate dies while in custody at 201 Poplar, sheriff's office says Memphis man sentenced to over 8 years for SNAP fraud, identity theft Mid-South Most Wanted Fugitives", "source": {"uri": "fox13memphis.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Fox13"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Matt Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241801033", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:50:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:50:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:50:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.fox5atlanta.com/news/fbi-director-wray-testifies-trump-rally-shooting-vows-thorough-investigation", "title": "FBI Director Wray testifies on Trump rally shooting, vows thorough investigation", "body": "WASHINGTON - Testimony continued today at the U.S. Capitol over the Secret Service's handling of security at former president Donald Trump's rally where a shooter attempted to assassinate him.\n\nFBI Director Christopher Wray testified before congressional lawmakers, saying the gunman, Thomas Matthew Crook, flew a drone roughly 200 yards from the rally stage where Trump would later stand.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray also said he had uncovered that Crook searched about the JFK assassination on the day he registered to attend Trump's July 13 campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"One of the things that I can share here today that has not been shared yet is that we've just in the last couple of days, found that from our... analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter, reveals that on July 6th, he did a Google search for, quote, 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy? And so that's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray said. \"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally.\"\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nRELATED: Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigns after Trump assassination attempt\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nRELATED: Bodycam captures Thomas Crooks' death following Trump shooting\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. {"uri": "8241780989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:33:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:33:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:32:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/world/united-states-canada/article/3271769/gunman-who-shot-trump-googled-jfk-assassination-rally-attack-fbi-director-says", "title": "Trump gunman googled JFK assassination before shooting, FBI director says", "body": "Suspect Thomas Matthew Crooks also flew a drone near the rally to live-stream and watch footage of the scene\n\nThe gunman in the attempted assassination of former US president Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \u201cHow far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\u201d FBI Director Christopher Wray said on Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe July 6 online search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed US President John F. Kennedy from a sniper\u2019s perch in Dallas on November 22, 1963.\n\n\u201cThat is a search that is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears he registered\u201d for the Trump rally scheduled for July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting, which killed one rally-goer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism. Crooks was killed by a Secret Service countersniper.\n\nThe investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a US president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe agency has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks\u2019 movements and online activity, but the precise motive \u2013 or why Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, was singled out \u2013 remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\u201cA lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\u201d Wray said.\n\nThe FBI\u2019s assessment is that Crooks acted alone.\n\nWray noted that Crooks had grown interested in public officials \u2013 besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic US President Joe Biden and other prominent figures \u2013 and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump.\n\nCrooks is believed to have visited the rally site a week before the event, staying for about 20 minutes, and then returned on the morning of July 13.\n\nAbout two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone about 180 metres (200 yards) from the rally for about 11 minutes, using the device to live-stream and watch footage and obtain what Wray said would have been a \u201crear view mirror\u201d of the scene behind him.\n\nThe use of the drone, which along with a controller were recovered from Crooks\u2019 car, so close to the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage add to the questions about the security lapses.\n\nOn the afternoon of the rally, Crooks attracted law enforcement scrutiny because of odd behaviour around the edges of the event, including shouldering a backpack and peering into the lens of a rangefinder toward the rooftops behind the stage where Trump would stand within the hour.\n\nUsing what Wray said was mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping, Crooks was able to hoist himself up onto the roof of a squat manufacturing building that was within 135 metres (157 yards) of the stage. Crooks fired eight shots from an AR-style rifle before being he was killed.\n\nThe FBI thinks Crooks may have managed to avoid detection despite being armed because his weapon had a collapsible folding stock, Wray said.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \u201cleave no stone unturned\u201d in its investigation.\n\n\u201cI have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example \u2013 a particularly heinous and public one \u2013 of what I\u2019ve been talking about,\u201d Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting \u2013 as part of the committee\u2019s routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle.\n\nEven so, Wray was not able to entirely avoid the antagonistic questions he typically receives from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of the lingering perception that the FBI and Justice Department have become politicised against Trump \u2013 something Wray has consistently denied.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Republican congressman Jim Jordan, told Wray: \u201cI\u2019m sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy scepticism regarding the FBI\u2019s ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\u201d", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "South China Morning Post"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Matt Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241781044", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:33:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:33:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:32:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.newsweek.com/gunman-researched-kennedy-assassination-before-trump-shooting-fbi-director-1929787", "title": "Gunman Researched Kennedy Assassination Before Trump Shooting: FBI Director", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray said during a Wednesday hearing before the House Judiciary Committee that before the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, the gunman researched the shooting of President John F. Kennedy.\n\nTrump, the Republican presidential nominee, was speaking at a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, on July 13 when he was shot on stage, with a bullet hitting the upper part of his right ear. The suspected gunman, identified by the FBI as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks of Bethel Park, Pennsylvania, was shot and killed by the Secret Service.\n\nAccording to the Associated Press (AP), Wray said during his Wednesday testimony that a laptop tied to Crooks included a Google search of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" The FBI director said the search was conducted on July 6.\n\nNewsweek reached out to the FBI on Wednesday via email for further comment.\n\nWray also revealed that hours before the rally, Crooks flew a drone roughly 200 yards from the stage where the former president spoke.\n\nAccording to the AP, the FBI has since recovered the drone and a controller from Crooks' car.\n\nThe details shared by Wray of Crooks' actions represents the most detailed comments the FBI director has about the July 13 shooting.\n\n\"We will leave no stone unturned in our investigation of this despicable and horrific act,\" Wray said. \"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically, the Butler County assassination attempt is a particularly heinous and public example of this.\"\n\nWray's testimony comes as House Oversight and Accountability Committee Chair James Comer, Republican Representative of Kentucky, has continued to lead efforts into investigating the shooting while also expressing concerns regarding the Secret Service's protection of Trump.\n\nThe AP noted that while the FBI has not faced the same level of scrutiny over the shooting as the Secret Service, which resulted in the resignation of Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle on Tuesday, Wray is expected to face questions about the bureau's assessment that Crooks had no clear ideological motive for his actions.\n\nIn addition, despite being appointed by Trump, Wray is expected to face skepticism from the Republican-led panel due to ongoing discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 Trump campaign, the AP reported.\n\nWednesday's hearken comes after Wray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, during which time they revealed Crooks had photos of Trump, Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials on his phone, the AP reported. He had also researched the dates for the Democratic National Convention and Trump's schedule.\n\nThe FBI is continuing to take the lead in investigating the shooting, which resulted in the death of one rallygoer and serious injuries to two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and attempted assassination.", "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Newsweek"}, "authors": [{"uri": "natalie_venegas@newsweek.com", "name": "Natalie Venegas", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241714959", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:41:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:41:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:41:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8509804010391235, "url": "https://www.dallasnews.com/news/politics/2024/07/24/trump-rally-gunman-researched-kennedy-assassination-online-fbi-director-says/", "title": "Trump rally gunman researched Kennedy assassination online, FBI director says", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\nPolitical Points\n\nGet the latest politics news from North Texas and beyond.\n\nSIGN UP\n\nOr with:\n\nGoogleFacebook\n\nBy signing up you agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. The use of the drone so close the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally added to the questions about security lapses preceding the event.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, when Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle,\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBy ERIC TUCKER, The Associated Press", "source": {"uri": "dallasnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Dallas Morning News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said that Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. {"uri": "2024-07-432569574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:10:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:10:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8470588326454163, "url": "https://gephardtdaily.com/top-stories/no-clear-picture-of-motive-for-would-be-trump-assassin-fbi-director-says-at-congressional-hearing/", "title": "No 'clear picture' of motive for would-be Trump assassin, FBI director says at congressional hearing", "body": "July 24 (UPI) -- The 20-year-old would-be assassin of Donald Trump had conducted Internet research into Lee Harvey Oswald's 1963 killing of President John F. Kennedy, the FBI director told U.S. lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nFBI Director Christopher Wray appeared on Capitol Hill to provide lawmakers testimony and reveal new details at a congressional hearing on the recent assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump in western Pennsylvania.\n\n\"The attempted assassination of the former president was an attack on our democracy and our democratic process and we will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind, especially a despicable account of this magnitude,\" Wray said in his opening remarks.\n\nTrump was shot at by Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, at least eight times with an AR15-style semi-automatic rifle, Wray confirmed at Wednesday's House Judiciary Committee hearing. He also told the panel it was a weapon with a collapsible stock, which he added \"could explain why it might've been less easy for people to observe.\"\n\nWray's comments come the day after Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned from her post amid bipartisan calls to do so after a Monday congressional hearing left many lawmakers unsatisfied with her answers about the security failure.\n\nOn Tuesday, Cheatle stepped down the same day a bipartisan House Task Force was announced to seek answers regarding the attempted assassination of the now-Republican presidential nominee. Several investigations are underway by Congress, law enforcement and federal agencies into Trump's attempted July 13 assassination at a campaign event in Butler, Penn., by 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks.\n\nCrooks was identified as \"suspicious\" earlier the day of the shooting when he was on the property and although he never attempted to get into the secured perimeter of the rally. Eventually, he was spotted with a rangefinder, according to a state police official in Pennsylvania.\n\nOn Tuesday, Pennsylvania State Police Col. Christopher Paris told the House Homeland Security Committee that Butler County Emergency Services Unit officers had spotted Crooks from a second-story window, leaving their post to search for the shooter.\n\nMeanwhile, the FBI director said Wednesday that Crooks became \"very focused\" on Trump and the Butler rally sometime around July 6.\n\nIt was revealed by Wray the would-be presidential assassin on July 6 conducted a Google search for \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" alluding to the 1963 assassination of former President John F. Kennedy in Dallas by Lee Harvey Oswald, the same day Crooks registered for Trump's Butler rally.\n\n\"That's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray remarked.\n\nHowever, the FBI is still in the \"legal process\" of getting access to Crooks' other digital accounts but so far why he shot at Trump is still not clear. The shooter, Wray says, appeared to have performed Internet searches of public figures \"in general.\"\n\n\"We do not yet have a clear picture of his motive,\" Wray told lawmakers, adding that Crooks has so far left no trace of a \"manifesto\" or other documents outlining his reasoning like multiple shooters typically have.\n\nAnd the bureau has not found any accomplices \"at this time,\" he said, noting the investigation is ongoing.\n\n\"We're going to leave no stone unturned,\" said Wray. \"The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing.\"\n\nWray says the description of Crooks as a loner \"fit[s] with what we're seeing\" on his devices. He lived with his parents in Bethel Park, Penn., and the family has cooperated with the investigation.\n\n\"There doesn't appear to be a whole lot of interactions between him, face-to-face or digital, with a lot of people,\" the director said, adding that \"that doesn't mean there's not any.\"\n\nAccording to Wary, the FBI recovered 8 cartridges from roof where a Secret Service sniper killed Crooks. He said 14 guns were found in the Crooks home, which Wray stated had been bought legally through the father.\n\nWray told Rep. Matt Gaetz, R-Fla., that the FBI \"did not have any information about the shooter\" and that Crooks \"was not in our holdings before the shooting.\"\n\nA drone and remote controller were found in his car, along with explosives also being discovered at the family home. One of the three explosives was found at his home; the other two in the car.\n\nCrooks had a transmitter on him, according to Wray, adding it appears the remote detonation \"would not have worked.\" He was flying the drone in the area roughy 200 yards from the stage where Trump was standing at about 4 p.m. EDT the day of the July 13 shooting.\n\nThe FBI is in the middle of analyzing the drone. Wray said \"we think\" the drone was producing a live-stream footage for a total of 11 minutes.\n\n\"At a moment, it looks like because of the on/off position on the receivers, that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked, but that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous,\" Wray said.", "source": {"uri": "gephardtdaily.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Gephardt Daily"}, "authors": [{"uri": "united_press_international@gephardtdaily.com", "name": "United Press International", "type": "author", "isAgency": true}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_congressional_hearing", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "United States congressional hearing"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Assassination"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. "FBI chief to face questions over Trump assassination attempt as he returns to Capitol Hill", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- FBI Director Christopher Wray is set to testify Wednesday about the bureau's investigation into the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, with lawmakers at a congressional hearing likely to press him for fresh details about the gunman's motive and background.\n\nThe hearing before the House Judiciary Committee will represent Wray's most detailed comments to date about a shooting that has again thrust the FBI into the political maelstrom as agents continue to investigate the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, and the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.", {"uri": "2024-07-432618856", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:36:57", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:36:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:33:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/4791433-fbi-director-briefs-congress-on-trump-shooter-five-takeaways/", "title": "FBI director briefs Congress on Trump shooter: Five takeaways", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray on Wednesday confirmed or revealed a host of information on former President Trump's would-be assassin, including new details on what the shooter had searched for online and his movements in the days, hours and minutes before he took aim at the Republican presidential nominee on July 13.\n\nSpeaking before the Republican-led House Judiciary Committee, Wray called the assassination attempt \"an attack on our democracy and our democratic process,\" asserting that \"we will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind, especially a despicable account of this magnitude.\"\n\nThe FBI is leading the criminal investigation into the events surrounding the incident, which occurred during a Trump rally in Butler, Pa.\n\nWray said that his agents are working \"tirelessly to get to the bottom of what happened,\" adding that his agency is \"bringing all the resources of the FBI to bear, both criminal and national security.\"\n\n\"We're going to leave no stone unturned,\" he said in his opening remarks. \"The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing.\"\n\nWray also promised transparency, telling lawmakers that he hoped to provide them \"with all the information I can, given where we are at this point.\"\n\nWray's candidness was a far cry from the disastrous testimony from former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle before the House Oversight and Accountability Committee on Monday, when she refused to answer questions or confirm information that was already public knowledge. The display frustrated lawmakers and forced her to resign on Tuesday.\n\nHere are five takeaways from Wray's testimony:\n\nShooter's laptop revealed searches on JFK assassination\n\nAmong the most startling new facts, an analysis of the shooter's laptop found that a week before the rally he had conducted a Google search for \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, who shot and killed former President Kennedy in 1963, according to Wray.\n\nThat same day, July 6, Crooks registered for Trump's speaking event.\n\n\"We've, just in the last couple days, found that ... [the] laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6 he did a Google search 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy?'\" Wray said.\n\nHe said the search is \"significant\" in terms of the shooter's state of mind.\n\nWray also revealed that the FBI was able to get into Crooks' phone, which he called a \"significant technical challenge.\" Once cracked, they found Crooks had been using encrypted messaging applications.\n\nWray also said Crooks had one phone but the FBI has identified others he may have used, including his father's, though not necessarily related to the attack.\n\nIn addition, he noted Crooks was a \"gamer\" with accounts on different gaming platforms, but no information has yet been found on those.\n\n\"We're trying to make sure we process and exploit every device he could have used,\" Wray said, earlier indicating that the bureau is involved in a \"legal process\" to gain access to Crooks' other accounts.\n\n\"We keep identifying new pieces of equipment, new accounts, what have you.\"\n\nBased on what the FBI has observed on his laptop and phone, the bureau has found no evidence that Crooks had accomplices or co-conspirators, foreign or domestic, with those interviewed describing the shooter as a \"loner,\" according to Wray.\n\n\"There doesn't appear to be a whole lot of interactions between him, face-to-face or digital, with a lot of people,\" Wray said before adding, \"that doesn't mean there's not any.\"\n\nThe FBI still does \"not yet have a clear picture of his motive.\"\n\nShooter had 'collapsible stock' on gun purchased from his father\n\nWray told lawmakers that Crooks' AR-style rifle had a collapsible stock, which \"could explain why it might've been less easy for people to observe.\"\n\nThe FBI has yet to find any witnesses who saw or video that displays Crooks walking around the fairground area with a gun, with observers only spotting him with a firearm when he was already on the roof he shot from, according to Wray.\n\nThe collapsible stock is \"potentially a very significant feature that might be relevant to that,\" he said.\n\nAnd earlier in the day on July 13, Crooks purchased 50 rounds of ammunition for his firearm which had been legally bought by his father in 2013. Using \"documentation,\" investigators confirmed Crooks later legally purchased the rifle from his father in October 2023.\n\nWray confirmed previous knowledge that Crooks fired approximately eight times at Trump before being killed by a Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nWray also confirmed that Crooks bought a roughly 5-foot ladder before the shooting but it was not found at the scene.\n\nAgents instead believe Crooks got on the roof from the back of the building \"using some mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping on the side\" of the building, Wray said. \"In other words, we do not believe he used a ladder to get up there.\"\n\nShooter flew drone over area two hours ahead of rally\n\nWray offered new information that the shooter flew a drone over the Butler fairgrounds about two hours before Trump spoke at the rally location.\n\nThe FBI director said Crooks flew the drone around the area, roughly 200 yards away from the stage, around 3:50 p.m. to 4 p.m. Trump took the stage around two hours later at 6 p.m.\n\n\"We think -- but we do not know, so again, this is one of these things that is qualified because of our ongoing review -- that he was live-streaming, viewing the footage [for] about 11 minutes,\" Wray said.\n\nThe drone was in Crooks' vehicle at the time of the shooting. The device is now \"being exploited and analyzed by the FBI lab,\" which has reverse-engineered its flight path on the day of the rally.\n\n\"It would have shown the shooter, we think - again, we're still doing more work on this . . . we think it would have shown him, kind of, what would have been behind him when he was shooting,\" giving Crooks a \"rearview mirror of the scene,\" Wray explained.\n\nThree 'crude' explosive devices found\n\nThe FBI also recovered three \"relatively crude\" explosive devices, two in Crooks' car and one other at his home.\n\nCrooks was found with a transmitter that would have allowed him to detonate the bombs in his car remotely, but initial findings suggest if he had tried to he would not have been successful.\n\n\"At a moment, it looks like because of the on-off position on the receivers, that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" Wray said before adding, \"that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous.\"\n\nWray later said the discovered explosives were compelling as it's unclear if Crooks had been planning further mayhem during or after the rally.\n\n\"What else he may have had in mind is something that I think is very much of an open question,\" he said.\n\nIn addition, investigators \"located a number of firearms associated with the shooter and his family,\" a total of 14 in the house, Wray said.\n\nOfficers first spotted gunman with rifle 'only seconds' before shooting\n\nWray attempted to clarify the timeline as to what took place from the time Crooks was identified on the roof and when he shot at Trump.\n\nA member of the public first spotted Crooks on the roof a \"handful of minutes\" before he opened fire at 6:11 p.m. Though it's unclear whether this individual saw Crooks had a gun, they \"saw him in a way that was concerning,\" Wray said.\n\nHe added that local law enforcement first viewed Crooks with the rifle \"literally just seconds\" before the shooting.\n\nThe local police officer, after being hoisted up by another, was able to view the roof, where he saw Crooks in a \"prone shooting position.\" The gunman then turned and pointed his gun at the officer, Wray confirmed.\n\n\"This is all seconds before the shooter took his shots,\" he said.\n\nWray also said local police observed the shooter with a rangefinder \"in a way that was odd and suspicious\" about an hour before the shooting.", "source": {"uri": "thehill.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Hill"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ellen_mitchell@thehill.com", "name": "Ellen Mitchell", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Matt Crooks"}}, {"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-432301859", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:41:49", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:41:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:56:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/the-fbi-will-leave-no-stone-unturned-investigating-the-trump-rally-shooting-wray-tells-congress/article_de116508-c053-5464-a265-72fbda9eecb4.html", "title": "The FBI will 'leave no stone unturned' investigating the Trump rally shooting, Wray tells Congress", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray says the FBI will \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump\n\nWASHINGTON (AP) -- The FBI will \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, the bureau's director told Congress on Wednesday.\n\nChristopher Wray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee was reflecting his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Pennsylvania that once more has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom. Agents are investigating the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, and what was the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's regular oversight of the FBI and Justice Department.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting. On Tuesday, Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned.\n\nWray was expected to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the FBI's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nThis story has been corrected to show the assassination attempt on Trump was July 13, not June 13.\n\nMore from this section\n\nExodus United Global Signs Multi-Year Agreement to Bring Indian Films and TV shows to the U.S.\n\n2024 Election Latest: Biden ends reelection bid, endorses VP Harris for Democratic nomination\n\nFederal funds fuel quarterly growth in U.S. down payment assistance programs, which now number 2,415", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@kulr8.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "eric_tucker@kulr8.com", "name": "Eric Tucker", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.itv.com/news/2024-07-24/trump-gunman-researched-kennedy-assassination-days-before-shooting", "title": "Trump gunman 'researched Kennedy assassination days before shooting'", "body": "The gunman who tried to assassinate Donald Trump googled \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" in the days before the shooting, the head of the FBI has revealed.\n\nAnswering questions in front of the House Judiciary Committee, FBI Director Christopher Wray revealed that a laptop connected to Thomas Matthew Crooks made the search on July 6, a week before the attack.\n\nThe search is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the gunman who killed President John F Kennedy in Dallas on November 22, 1963.\n\nIn a wide-ranging question session focused mostly on the assassination attempt Wray also revealed Crooks flew a drone roughly 180 metres from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage.\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of the 20-year-old shooter and is analysing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony comes on the heels of the resignation of the head of the Secret Service Kimberly Cheatle after questions were raised over how the shooting was able to take place.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example, a particularly heinous and public one, of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray has faced a lot of discontent from the Republican Party following complaints that the FBI has become political and favours the Democrats.\n\nSubscribe free to our weekly newsletter for exclusive and original coverage from ITV Agents are investigating the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, and what was the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's regular oversight of the FBI and Justice Department.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting. On Tuesday, Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned.\n\nWray was expected to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the FBI's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\n(Copyright (c) 2024 The Associated Press. {"uri": "2024-07-432488262", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:15:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:15:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:06:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8392156958580017, "url": "https://www.myrtlebeachonline.com/news/nation-world/national/article290389269.html", "title": "No 'clear picture' of motive for would-be Trump assassin, FBI director says at congressional hearing", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray appeared on Capitol Hill to provide lawmakers testimony and reveal new details at a congressional hearing on the recent assassination attempt of former President Donald Trump in western Pennsylvania.\n\n\"The attempted assassination of the former president was an attack on our democracy and our democratic process and we will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind, especially a despicable account of this magnitude,\" Wray said in his opening remarks.\n\nTrump was shot at by Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, at least eight times with an AR15-style semi-automatic rifle, Wray confirmed at Wednesday's House Judiciary Committee hearing. He also told the panel it was a weapon with a collapsible stock, which he added \"could explain why it might've been less easy for people to observe.\"\n\nWray's comments come the day after Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned from her post amid bipartisan calls to do so after a Monday congressional hearing left many lawmakers unsatisfied with her answers about the security failure.\n\nOn Tuesday, Cheatle stepped down the same day a bipartisan House Task Force was announced to seek answers regarding the attempted assassination of the now-Republican presidential nominee. Several investigations are underway by Congress, law enforcement and federal agencies into Trump's attempted July 13 assassination at a campaign event in Butler, Penn., by 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks.\n\nCrooks was identified as \"suspicious\" earlier the day of the shooting when he was on the property and although he never attempted to get into the secured perimeter of the rally. Eventually, he was spotted with a rangefinder, according to a state police official in Pennsylvania.\n\nOn Tuesday, Pennsylvania State Police Col. Christopher Paris told the House Homeland Security Committee that Butler County Emergency Services Unit officers had spotted Crooks from a second-story window, leaving their post to search for the shooter.\n\nMeanwhile, the FBI director said Wednesday that Crooks became \"very focused\" on Trump and the Butler rally sometime around July 6.\n\nIt was revealed by Wray the would-be presidential assassin on July 6 conducted a Google search for \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" alluding to the 1963 assassination of former President John F. Kennedy in Dallas by Lee Harvey Oswald, the same day Crooks registered for Trump's Butler rally.\n\n\"That's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray remarked.\n\nHowever, the FBI is still in the \"legal process\" of getting access to Crooks' other digital accounts but so far why he shot at Trump is still not clear. The shooter, Wray says, appeared to have performed Internet searches of public figures \"in general.\"\n\n\"We do not yet have a clear picture of his motive,\" Wray told lawmakers, adding that Crooks has so far left no trace of a \"manifesto\" or other documents outlining his reasoning like multiple shooters typically have.\n\nAnd the bureau has not found any accomplices \"at this time,\" he said, noting the investigation is ongoing.\n\n\"We're going to leave no stone unturned,\" said Wray. \"The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing.\"\n\nWray says the description of Crooks as a loner \"fit[s] with what we're seeing\" on his devices. He lived with his parents in Bethel Park, Penn., and the family has cooperated with the investigation.\n\n\"There doesn't appear to be a whole lot of interactions between him, face-to-face or digital, with a lot of people,\" the director said, adding that \"that doesn't mean there's not any.\"\n\nAccording to Wary, the FBI recovered 8 cartridges from roof where a Secret Service sniper killed Crooks. He said 14 guns were found in the Crooks home, which Wray stated had been bought legally through the father.\n\nWray told Rep. Matt Gaetz, R-Fla., that the FBI \"did not have any information about the shooter\" and that Crooks \"was not in our holdings before the shooting.\"\n\nA drone and remote controller were found in his car, along with explosives also being discovered at the family home. One of the three explosives was found at his home; the other two in the car.\n\nCrooks had a transmitter on him, according to Wray, adding it appears the remote detonation \"would not have worked.\" He was flying the drone in the area roughy 200 yards from the stage where Trump was standing at about 4 p.m. EDT the day of the July 13 shooting.\n\nThe FBI is in the middle of analyzing the drone. Wray said \"we think\" the drone was producing a live-stream footage for a total of 11 minutes.\n\n\"At a moment, it looks like because of the on/off position on the receivers, that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked, but that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous,\" Wray said.", "source": {"uri": "myrtlebeachonline.com", "dataType": "news", Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nWray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nElections Secret Service director steps down after assassination attempt against Trump By COLLEEN LONG The Associated Press\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nPeople are also reading... Ben Sasse to resign as University of Florida president North Platte man sentenced to 10 to 15 years for domestic assault Letter from the Editor: Megan Kelley has moved from newsroom to classroom and back again For $20,000, and a bit of 'vision,' this rural Nebraska church could be yours 'Ready to learn from this': John Cook updates Harper Murray's status for 2024 season North Platte man sentenced to prison term for possession of firearm Tornados, damaged buildings from sever storms reported Tuesday night\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\nElections GOP threatened to sue over November ballot if Biden dropped out. Experts call that 'ridiculous' ROBERT YOON Associated Press\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "nptelegraph.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "North Platte Nebraska's Newspaper"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@nptelegraph.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "manuel_balce_ceneta@nptelegraph.com", "name": "Manuel Balce Ceneta", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8242069296", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:17:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:17:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T23:16:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://www.news-gazette.com/trump-rally-gunman-looked-online-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_20aabd1f-1fcb-5587-bdec-c7a03d206a56.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe July 6 online search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\n\"That's a search obviously that is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears that he registered\" for the Trump rally scheduled for July 13 in Butler, Pa., Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism. Crooks was killed by a Secret Service countersniper. The investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe agency has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump, the Republican presidential nominee, was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"In terms of what we've been able to find so far, a lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI's assessment continues to be that Crooks acted alone, though agents are still investigating.\n\nWray noted that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump and the Butler rally.\n\nCrooks is believed to have visited the rally site a week before the event, staying for about 20 minutes, and then returned on the morning of July 13. More than two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally stage for about 11 minutes, using the device to livestream and watch footage and obtain what Wray said would have been a \"rearview mirror\" of the scene behind him.\n\nThe use of the drone, which along with a controller were recovered from Crooks' car, so close to the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage add to the questions about the security lapses that preceded the shooting.\n\nOn the afternoon of the rally, Crooks attracted law enforcement scrutiny because of odd behavior around the edges of the event, including shouldering a backpack and peering into the lens of a range finder toward the rooftops behind the stage where Trump would stand within the hour.\n\nUsing what Wray said was mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping, Crooks was able to hoist himself up onto the roof of a squat manufacturing building that was within 157 yards of the stage. Crooks fired eight shots from an AR-style rifle before he was killed. (The Warren Commission report that analyzed the Kennedy assassination assessed that Kennedy had been shot through the neck at a range of 174.9 feet to 190.8 feet.\n\nThe FBI thinks Crooks may have managed to avoid detection in the crowd despite being armed because his weapon had a collapsible folding stock, Wray said.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.", "source": {"uri": "news-gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The News-Gazette"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Matt Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. Kennedy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nWray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nElections Secret Service director steps down after assassination attempt against Trump By COLLEEN LONG The Associated Press\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nPeople are also reading... represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | Experts call that 'ridiculous' ROBERT YOON Associated Press\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally", "source": {"uri": "richmond.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Richmond Times-Dispatch"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A.
