{"uri": "8242111686", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:08:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:08:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:07:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.skynews.com.au/world-news/united-states/how-far-away-was-oswald-from-kennedy-trump-gunman-googled-jfk-assassination-before-butler-rally-attempt-fbi-director-reveals-during-committee-hearing/news-story/324f54c40027b355a39b63b114bba8e2", "title": "Would-be Trump assassin googled JFK shooting, committee hears", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray has revealed fresh details concerning the investigation into the attempted assassination of former president Donald Trump in his testimony before the House Judiciary Committee in Washington DC on Wednesday.\n\nMr Wray said the 20-year-old would-be assassin Thomas Matthew Crooks had made a Google search one week before the shooting in which he researched the assassination of president John F. Kennedy.\n\n\"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" Crooks searched, referencing Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed JFK with a sniper rifle in Dallas on November 22, 1963.\n\nThe FBI director said it was a \"significant\" online search in terms of Crooks' \"state of mind\".\n\nMr Wray said the JFK Google search was made \"about July 6\" - the same day Crooks registered to attend the Trump rally scheduled for July 13.\n\nAfter Mr Wray swore in, the FBI director began his introductory statement by offering his condolences to the victims of the \"horrific\" assassination attempt, and honored Corey Comperatore, 50, who died while protecting his family from danger.\n\n\"And of course, of course, to former president Trump, and his family. As I've said from the beginning, the attempted assassination of the former president was an attack on our democracy and our democratic process, and we will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind, especially a despicable account of this magnitude,\" Mr Wray said.\n\n\"I want to assure you, and the American people, that the men and women of the FBI will continue to work tirelessly to get to the bottom of what happened. We are bringing all the resources of the FBI to bear, both criminal and national security.\n\n\"We're going to leave no stone unturned. The shooter may be deceased, but the FBI's investigation is still ongoing.\"\n\nThe FBI director discussed the shooter's preparation for the event, revealing during the hearing that Crooks travelled to the grounds of the rally the day before the shooting \"for the first time\" which was \"consistent with some kind of planning or reconnaissance\".\n\nMr Wray added Crooks had made a \"certain amount of (Google) searches\" relating to Mr Trump during the days leading up to the attempted assassination.\n\nDespite this, Mr Wray said the shooter's motive was still unknown and it had been \"very frustrating\" that some of the usual kind of \"low hanging-fruit places\" had not yielded any significant clues.\n\nThe FBI director said the images the investigators had recovered from the shooter's device appeared to be \"cached images from searches\" of high-profile individuals.\n\n\"There doesn't seem to be a whole lot of rhyme or reason to it, so far, other than these are all prominent public people, but they cover both parties, they cover both US people and even some foreign public officials,\" Mr Wray said.\n\nRep. Thomas Massie then asked Mr Wray if Crooks had any help to plan the shooting at the Butler rally, with the FBI boss insisting it was a line of inquiry being \"intensely focussed on\".\n\n\"So far we have not found any evidence of any accomplices or co-conspirators, foreign or domestic,\" Mr Wray said.\n\n\"From everything we've seen ... a lot of people describe him (Crooks) as a loner, that does kinda fit with what we're seeing in his devices.\n\n\"His list of contacts, for example, is very short compared to what you would normally see from most people, so it doesn't appear to be much interaction between him, face-to-face or digital, with people.\"\n\nThe \"AR-15 style\" gun was sold to Crooks by his father, Mr Wray revealed, after it was purchased legally, however he did not know for how much or how close to the day of the shooting it was obtained, with the FBI director speculating \"it may have been a year before, give or take\".\n\n\"I do know that on the day of the shooting, at about 1.30pm, he (Crooks) bought about 50 rounds of ammunition,\" Mr Wray said.\n\nMr Wray was also questioned on whether Crooks used a ladder to gain access to the roof where he was ultimately shot dead, with the FBI director confirming investigators know he purchased a 5-foot ladder, but they did not find the ladder at the scene.\n\nRep. Andy Biggs questioned the FBI director on the shooter's use of a drone and heard the bureau had been able to reverse engineer the flight path of the drone in the hours leading up to the shooting.\n\nMr Wray told the committee Crooks used the drone to determine a vantage point, as well as using it as a \"rear view mirror\", however the FBI director could not say with certainty the imagery the would-be assassin obtained from the drone footage.", "source": {"uri": "skynews.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sky News Australia"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241851877", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:35:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:35:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:34:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.wfae.org/2024-07-24/fbi-director-says-gunman-at-trump-rally-searched-for-info-on-jfk-assassination", "title": "FBI director says gunman at Trump rally searched for info on JFK assassination", "body": "The gunman who attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump conducted an online search a week before the shooting about the killing of former President John F. Kennedy, the FBI director said Wednesday.\n\nTestifying before the House Judiciary Committee, Christopher Wray gave lawmakers an update on the investigation into the July 13 shooting targeting Trump at a rally in Butler, Pa. That includes information pulled from a computer linked to the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Crooks, that suggests he spent at least a week planning the attack.\n\n\"An analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6 he did a Google search for 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?' \" Wray said. \"That's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally.\"\n\nLee Harvey Oswald is the gunman who shot former President John F. Kennedy in Dallas, Texas, in 1963.\n\nIn his testimony, which comes 11 days after the attempt on Trump's life, Wray filled in some of the details about the gunman and the timeline ahead of the shooting.\n\nThe FBI has gained access to Crooks' digital devices, Wray said, but investigators still have not found anything that points to a motive or political ideology.\n\n\"Having said that, it does appear fairly clear that he was interested in public figures more broadly and, I think this is important, starting somewhere around July 6 or so, he became very focused on former president Trump and this rally,\" he told lawmakers.\n\nInvestigators believe Crooks visited the site of the Butler rally on three occasions, Wray said.\n\nThe first time was a week before the event, when he spent roughly 20 minutes there. The second time was the morning of the Trump rally, when he appears to have been on site for roughly 70 minutes, Wray said. The third time was later that afternoon, a few hours before the event -- and he never left.\n\nDuring that last visit, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone at the rally grounds for 11 minutes around 4 p.m., about 200 yards from the stage.\n\nInvestigators recovered the drone in the gunman's vehicle along with its controller. They have been able to reverse engineer the device's flight path, Wray said, but they don't know exactly what Crooks was able to see or why.\n\nWray also discussed the three explosive devices that investigators recovered: two from Crooks' vehicle and one at his residence. Wray described the devices as \"relatively crude,\" but said they did have the ability to be detonated remotely.\n\nA transmitter was found on Crooks' body, he said, but it appears that the receivers on the explosive devices were not turned on so he wouldn't have been able to detonate them.\n\nInvestigators now believe, Wray said, that Crooks climbed up onto the roof where he fired from by using \"some mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping\" on the side of the building. The bureau still has not determined, however, when the gunman got onto the roof.\n\nWray did say that Crooks' AR-style rifle had a collapsible stock, which Wray said \"could explain why it might have been less easy for people to observe.\"\n\nThe day before the shooting, Crooks went to a shooting range and fired an AR-style rifle, Wray said. The director described Crooks as a \"fairly avid shooting hobbyist.\"\n\nInvestigators have conducted more than 400 interviews so far of a wide range of people, he said, which has helped provide a picture of who Crooks was.\n\n\"From everything we've seen, which is consistent with what we've learned in interviews -- a lot of people describe him as a loner,\" Wray said. \"That does kind of fit with what we're seeing in his devices. His list of contacts, for example, is very short compared to what you would normally see from most people. There doesn't seem to be a whole lot of interaction between him face-to-face or digital with a lot of people.\"\n\nNPR and other media outlets have previously reported that investigators found images of President Biden, former President Trump, the attorney general and the FBI director on Crooks' phone.\n\nWray said the photos found were stored automatically from online searches and from reading news articles.\n\n\"This does not appear to be some sort of target list,\" he said.\n\n\"This is cached images from running searches, so news stories. And again, there is nothing, no pattern, from that particular piece of information that is overly remarkable so far.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 NPR", "source": {"uri": "wfae.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "WFAE 90.7 - Charlotte's NPR News Source"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Matt Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butler_University", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Butler University"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. "label": {"eng": "NPR"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Terrorism", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Warfare_and_Conflict", "label": "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9758656", "eventUri": "eng-9758656", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-13", "textStart": 334, "textEnd": 341}, {"uri": "2024-07-432431381", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:01:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:01:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.wxow.com/news/trump-shooter-searched-details-of-lee-harvey-oswald-and-jfk-assassination-flew-drone-near-rally/article_bb5df3e1-4d96-5994-97e7-b448ee54aca7.html", "title": "Trump shooter searched details of Lee Harvey Oswald and JFK assassination; flew drone near rally site, FBI director says", "body": "(CNN) -- Donald Trump's would-be assassin searched for details of the John F. Kennedy shooting from his laptop and flew a drone in the area near the rally just two hours before the former president took the stage on July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday.\n\nAccording to the FBI's analysis of Thomas Matthew Crooks' laptop, Crooks searched how far Lee Harvey Oswald was when he shot and killed President John F. Kennedy in 1963.\n\nThe search was on July 6, the same day the Trump rally was announced.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for: 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\n\"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" the FBI director added. \"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally.\"\n\nShooter flew drone just 2 hours before Trump took the stage\n\nSpeaking to the House Judiciary Committee, Wray revealed that \"around 4 p.m.,\" the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, \"was flying the drone around the area\" of the rally, approximately 200 yards from the stage.\n\nThe drone was in the air for approximately 11 minutes, and investigators believe Crooks watched a live feed from the drone on his phone. CNN previously reported that the drone was found in his car following the shooting.\n\nIn addition, Crooks had two explosives in his car at the time of the shooting and one in his home, but likely did not have the ability to detonate them from the roof where he was killed, Wray testified.\n\n\"It looks like because of the on/off position on the receivers, that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" Wray said.\n\nWray said that investigators have been able to \"reverse-engineer the flight path of the drone from the day of the rally,\" and now think that the drone footage \"would have shown [the shooter] what would have been behind him.\"\n\n\"It was almost like giving him a rear-view mirror of the scene behind him,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting as both an attempted assassination and as a potential act of domestic terrorism. FBI officials have repeatedly asserted that they believe Crooks acted alone, and Wray reiterated that there is no evidence of any co-conspirators.\n\nGun had a collapsable stock and was purchased from shooter's father\n\nInvestigators say that Crooks fired approximately eight times from an AR-style rifle at the former president before being killed by a US Secret Service counter sniper.\n\nThe rifle Crooks used was purchased from his father, Wray testified.\n\n\"The weapon that he used for the attempted assassination was an AR-style rifle that was purchased legally, that he - as my understanding - acquired, I think bought actually from his father, who was the one who originally bought it,\" Wray said.\n\nPreviously, officials said they believed the firearm belonged to Crooks' father - not the shooter - and they didn't know how Crooks accessed the weapon.\n\n\"I have been saying some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment,\" Wray said. \"The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is ongoing.\"\n\nInvestigators have gone through the shooter's phone and computer, scoured his search history and bedroom and have interviewed his family and friends, but have struggled to identify what motivated the 20-year-old would be assassin to act.\n\nCrooks also had no prior contacts with the FBI, officials say, and had not been previously on their radar or databases.\n\nShooter was searching for news stories\n\nWray pushed back against reports that Crooks searched for images of specific prominent public officials online, saying that it appears he was actually searching for news articles.\n\n\"The shooter appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures in general, but so far we are seeing kind of news articles and things like that,\" Wray said. He continued, \"so the images that have been reported about, really what we are talking about there are when you do a news search of an article the image appears in a cache as opposed to like a search for that specific individual.\"\n\nThe FBI director cautioned that the effort to uncover Crooks' motive is ongoing, but warned that \"it is, quite frankly, a dangerous time to be a prominent public official.\"\n\nWray expects more threats from Iran\n\nWray said on Wednesday that the FBI informed the US Secret Service about an Iranian plot to assassinate former President Donald Trump, saying that it's likely law enforcement agencies are going to see more such \"brazenness\" from Iran in the future.\n\nThe director declined to provide details of \"specific, classified information,\" to the committee but stressed that his agency has been calling out \"efforts by the Iranian government to attempt to retaliate for the killing of (Iranian General) Soleimani by going after current or former prominent US officials.\"\n\n\"I think we need to recognize the brazenness of the Iranian regime, including right here in the United States, and I expect that we're going to see more of it and I expect there will be more coming on that,\" Wray said.\n\nCNN has previously reported that US authorities obtained intelligence from a human source in recent weeks on a plot by Iran to try to assassinate Trump, a development that led to the Secret Service increasing security around the former president, multiple people briefed on the matter told CNN. There's no indication that Thomas Matthew Crooks, the would-be assassin who attempted to kill the former president, was connected to the plot, the sources said.\n\nSchiff, in swipe at Trump's felony conviction, praises FBI's ban on hiring felons\n\nDemocratic Rep. Adam Schiff pressed Wray on the agency's hiring standards in an effort to criticize the Republican Party's decision to make Trump, a convicted felon, its 2024 presidential nominee.\n\n\"Do candidates for the FBI have to go through background checks?\" Schiff asked, to which Wray said yes.\n\n\"Would someone with dozens of felony convictions survive a background check for the bureau?\" Schiff said.\n\n\"No,\" Wray replied.\n\n\"So they would never be hired by the bureau?\"\n\n\"No,\" Wray said again.\n\n\"Clearly, the bureau has higher standards for their hiring than one of America's great political parties,\" Schiff said.\n\nTrump was convicted earlier this year on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records as part of a hush money scheme he orchestrated ahead of the 2016 election.\n\nThe House Judiciary Committee hearing is ongoing.\n\nThis story is breaking and will be updated.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Wray has revealed that a laptop tied to the Trump rally gunman showed a Google search for, \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\".\n\nThe question is in reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the assassin who killed President John F Kennedy in Dallas on 22 November, 1963.\n\nIt is believed that the gunman, identified as Thomas Matthew Crooks, carried out the Google search on 6 July, just a week before the assassination attempt against former US president Donald Trump.\n\nMr Wray was updating the House Judiciary Committee on the bureau's investigation into the 13 July shooting at the Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nThe FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with officials and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks.\n\nThe attempt on Mr Trump's life was the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe gunman, John Hinkley Jr, who was released from prison in 2016, tweeted an appeal not to resort to violence after the shooting at the Butler rally.\n\nA detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity has been formed by the FBI, but the precise motive -- or why Mr Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Mr Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Mr Trump.\n\nAbout two hours prior to the shooting, Crooks had allegedly flown a drone about 180 meters from the rally stage where Mr Trump would later stand, Mr Wray said.\n\nHe added that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage.\n\nThe use of the {"uri": "8241810529", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:00:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:00:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:59:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.dailysignal.com/2024/07/24/fbi-director-testifies-before-congress-about-trump-assassination-attempt/", "title": "FBI Director Testifies Before Congress About Trump Assassination Attempt", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray testified before the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, offering scant new information on the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump.\n\nWray sat down before the House lawmakers and, in his opening remarks, described the \"complex threat environment\" that the FBI is facing. He also emphasized the need for the agency to understand what happened at the July 13 Trump campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, where Thomas Crooks, who was killed by authorities, shot at Trump, hitting him in the right ear.\n\nWray promised that the agency will \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\nLawmakers grilled Wray throughout Wednesday morning and into the afternoon about the incident, but a number of lawmakers also brought up related and unrelated topics, such as gun control; Jan. 6; diversity, equity, and inclusion efforts; and Vice President Kamala Harris.\n\nWray revealed that Crooks, using a laptop computer, had Googled \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" on July 6, a little more than a week before the July 13 attack on Trump's life. The FBI director said that Crooks became \"very focused\" on Trump around that date, though he stressed that the FBI has not yet uncovered Crooks' motivations for trying to kill the former president.\n\nWray also discussed how Crooks' devices showed that the gunman had looked at other political figures, but he stressed that there is no indication that Crooks had another target. He told lawmakers that federal agents found three \"relatively crude\" explosive devices in Crooks' possession -- two in his car and one in his house.\n\nThe FBI director said that Crooks had been flying a drone about 200 yards from the stage where Trump stood and was livestreaming the video about two hours before the Pennsylvania rally began.\n\nHe did not offer insight into whether Crooks was conspiring with anyone else, citing the ongoing nature of the FBI's investigation into the attempted assassination.\n\n\"We're still in early stages, but we have not seen anything so far that would suggest to us that he acted with others,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI director blamed \"an uptick in threats about judges ... including a case we helped investigate involving a threat to a sitting Supreme Court justice\" (apparently meaning Justice Brett Kavanaugh) to \"a reflection of a broader phenomenon that we're seeing in this country.\"\n\nWray expressed understanding for those who are \"again very passionate, I respect that; very angry, I respect that. But there is a right way and wrong way to express yourself when you are angry. And violence and threats of violence just can't be it.\"\n\nThe FBI chief clarified that someone at the Butler rally saw Crooks on the roof a \"handful of minutes\" before he began shooting at Trump at about 6:11 p.m. on July 13. According to Wray, it's unclear whether the person could see that Crooks had a gun.\n\nWray also described how a local police officer saw Crooks in a \"prone, shooting position\" on the roof before the gunman turned and faced the officer with his gun \"seconds before the shooter took his shots.\"\n\nThe FBI chief said that local police had also seen the shooter with a range finder \"in a way that was odd and suspicious\" about an hour before Crooks tried to kill Trump.", "source": {"uri": "dailysignal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Daily Signal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mary_margaret_olohan@dailysignal.com", "name": "Mary Margaret Olohan", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Thomas Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump_2016_presidential_campaign", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump 2016 presidential campaign"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. assassination, FBI director says", "body": "The FBI said Thomas Matthew Crooks Googled 'how far away from Oswald from Kennedy?' just a week before the attempted assassination of Donald Trump.\n\nFBI director Christopher Wray told officials on Wednesday that a laptop tied to the Trump rally gunman showed a Google search for \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\".\n\nThe question is in reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F Kennedy in Dallas on November 22, 1963.\n\nIt is believed that the gunman, identified as Thomas Matthew Crooks, carried out the Google search on July 6, just a week before the assassination attempt against former US president Donald Trump.\n\nThe House Judiciary Committee heard a collection of new details from Mr Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nThe attempt on Mr Trump's life was the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nA detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity has been formed by the FBI, but the precise motive -- or why Mr Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Mr Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Mr Wray said.\n\nHe did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Mr Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Mr Trump.\n\nAbout two hours prior to the shooting, Crooks had allegedly flown a drone about 180 meters from the rally stage where Mr Trump would later stand, Mr Wray said.\n\nHe added that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage.\n\nMr Wray pledged that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" the FBI director said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, but questions about the shooting "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/world-news/trump-gunman-researched-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/a974236567.html", "title": "Trump gunman researched Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "FBI director Christopher Wray told officials on Wednesday that a laptop tied to the Trump rally gunman showed a Google search for \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\".\n\nThe question is in reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F Kennedy in Dallas on November 22, 1963.\n\nIt is believed that the gunman, identified as Thomas Matthew Crooks, carried out the Google search on July 6, just a week before the assassination attempt against former US president Donald Trump.\n\nThe House Judiciary Committee heard a collection of new details from Mr Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nThe FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with officials and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks.\n\nThe attempt on Mr Trump's life was the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nA detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity has been formed by the FBI, but the precise motive -- or why Mr Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Mr Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Mr Wray said.\n\nHe did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Mr Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Mr Trump.\n\nAbout two hours prior to the shooting, Crooks had allegedly flown a drone about 180 meters from the rally stage where Mr Trump would later stand, Mr Wray said.\n\nHe added that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage.\n\nThe use of the drone so close to the rally site just hours before Mr Trump took the stage adds to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nMr Wray pledged that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" the FBI director said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, but questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination.\n\nMr Trump's campaign said the presumptive Republican nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which the former president said pierced the Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nWray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nElections Secret Service director steps down after assassination attempt against Trump By COLLEEN LONG The Associated Press\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nPeople are also reading... Few cash-only spots, abundant credit card fees: How Jersey Shore boardwalks have changed with consumer habits Jack Morey, the 'creative force' behind Wildwood's Morey's Piers, dies at 63 Small says preliminary agreement reached with CRDA, state on Atlantic City 'road diet' Family thanks Ocean City first responders for saving teen's life More than just fish and money make Jimmy Johnson's Atlantic City tournament popular Fish falls from sky in New Jersey, smashes windshield Hot meals return to Sister Jean's Kitchen in Atlantic City\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\nElections GOP threatened to sue over November ballot if Biden dropped out. Experts call that 'ridiculous' ROBERT YOON Associated Press\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "pressofatlanticcity.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Press of Atlantic City"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@pressofatlanticcity.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "manuel_balce_ceneta@pressofatlanticcity.com", "name": "Manuel Balce Ceneta", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241681287", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:16:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:16:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:16:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.staradvertiser.com/2024/07/24/breaking-news/fbi-director-trump-shooter-did-online-search-for-jfk-assassination/", "title": "FBI director: Trump shooter did online search for JFK assassination | Honolulu Star-Advertiser", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray testifies during a Senate Appropriations Commerce, Justice, Science, and Related Agencies Subcommittee hearing on President Biden's proposed budget request for the Federal Bureau of Investigation, on Capitol Hill in Washington, D.C., on June 4. The 20-year-old man suspected of trying to kill former President Donald Trump conducted an online search of the John F. Kennedy assassination on the day he registered for Trump's rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, FBI Director Christopher Wray said today.\n\nWASHINGTON >> The 20-year-old man suspected of trying to kill former President Donald Trump conducted an online search of the John F. Kennedy assassination on the day he registered for Trump's rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, FBI Director Christopher Wray said today.\n\n\"Analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6, he did a Google search for -quote - 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Wray said in testimony before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\n\"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally,\" he said, adding that suspect Thomas Crooks had become \"very focused on President Trump and his rally\" at the time.\n\nFormer President Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas, Texas, on Nov. 22, 1963, by Lee Harvey Oswald.\n\nWray said Crooks, a nursing home aide, fired at least eight rounds from his rooftop position near the July 13 rally, wounding the Republican presidential candidate in the ear, killing one rally attendee and wounding two others.\n\nCrooks used an AR-15 assault-style rifle with a collapsible stock, \"which could explain why it might have been less easy for people to observe,\" Wray said.\n\nThe motive for the shooting remains unclear. Wray said many people have described Crooks as a loner and the list of contacts in his phone was short.\n\nWray also told lawmakers that Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the stage where Trump spoke to the crowd and live-streamed footage for about 11 minutes, some two hours before the event.\n\nHe said the crude explosive devices recovered from Crooks' car and home were designed to be detonated remotely. Crooks had a transmitter with him at the time of the shooting, Wray added. But he said the FBI believes the suspect would not have been successful had he tried to detonate the devices.\n\nThe hearing also focused on the increasingly tense political atmosphere surrounding the presidential campaign.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated-threat environment. And tragically, the ... assassination attempt is another example, particularly heinous,\" Wray testified.\n\nKimberly Cheatle resigned as director of the U.S. Secret Service on Tuesday after bipartisan demands to quit over the failure to prevent the attempted assassination.\n\nJudiciary Committee Chairman Jim Jordan said he expected Wray to answer questions about what happened before, during and after the incident but expressed doubt about the FBI director's answers even before questioning began.\n\n\"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation,\" Jordan said.\n\nRepresentative Jerrold Nadler, the panel's top Democrat, condemned the Trump shooting \"unequivocally and unabashedly\" but pointed to years of political threats and violence, and violent rhetoric from Republicans including Trump himself.\n\n\"If you think that this one assassin's bullet was a bolt out of the blue, and not part of a wave of violence that has threatened this nation for years, then you have missed the point,\" the New York Democrat said.\n\nWray has long faced opposition from hardline Republicans, some angered over the arrest of Trump supporters who stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, as Congress certified President Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.", "source": {"uri": "staradvertiser.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Honolulu Star Advertiser"}, "authors": [{"uri": "reuters@staradvertiser.com", "name": "Reuters", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. {"uri": "8241647009", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:51:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:51:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:50:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/trump-gunman-searched-how-far-away-lee-harvey-oswald-was-from-jfk-had-access-to-14-guns-and-flew-drone-200-yards-from-stage-two-hours-before-shooting-fbi-director-reveals/", "title": "Trump gunman searched 'how far away' Lee Harvey Oswald was from JFK, had access to 14 guns and flew drone 200 yards from stage two hours before shooting, FBI director reveals", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray revealed Donald Trump's would-be assassin Thomas Crooks' concerning search history in the days leading up to the Butler rally in a congressional hearing on Wednesday.\n\nWray said Crooks had been 'interested in public figures' and 'somewhere around July 6 or so he became very focused on former President Trump and his rally.'\n\nThe director said an analysis of Crooks' laptop revealed he had searched on Google on July 6 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy.' It was the same day he registered to attend the Butler rally.\n\nLee Harvey Oswald shot and killed former President John F. Kennedy Jr. in 1963.\n\nCrooks was flying a drone above the rally site two hours before the shooting and just 200 yards away from the stage, Wray has also revealed.\n\nWray made the bombshell revelation to Congress on Wednesday during a grilling by lawmakers on the investigation into the assassination attempt on the former president and the massive security failures.\n\nCrooks shot Trump in the ear just 400 feet away from the stage in Butler, Pennsylvania, on July 13 from the roof of a nearby building just outside the security perimeter of the event.\n\nWray revealed that investigators found Crooks had a drone that he used to survey the scene hours before the event started, which was recovered from his car parked nearby.\n\nHe flew the drone around 4 p.m. over the area of the rally close to '200 yards' from the stage to survey the scene. Trump took the stage around 6:03 p.m., over two hours later.\n\nThe FBI has also recovered three 'explosive devices' in possession of Crooks.\n\nThey were 'relatively crude devices' but had the ability 'to be detonated remotely,' Wray said.\n\nThe FBI director also revealed the weapon used had a 'collapsible stock,' which he said 'could explain why it might've been less easy for people to observe.'\n\nHe said Crooks and his family owned a combined 14 guns. He used an AR-style weapon that had been purchased legally by his father.\n\nDramatic new footage shows law enforcement standing over the dead body of Donald Trump 's attempted assassin moments after he was shot dead\n\nWray also confirmed the FBI had recovered three 'explosive devices' in possession of Crooks\n\nWray said eight bullet cartridges had been recovered from the roof where Crooks fired off his shots toward the former president.\n\nAnd he wouldn't rule out that Crooks did not have any accomplices to the crime, saying it's still being looked at by law enforcement.\n\nAs Wray faced questions about why the president was allowed on stage despite the 'threat' being identified 20 minutes before the shots were fired, Wray said, 'we don't know the answer to that.'\n\nBut he insisted his investigation was not focused on the security breach and the Secret Service failures.\n\n'Our investigation is focused on the shooter and all things related to his attack.'\n\nHis hearing comes days after the former Director of Secret Service Kimberly Cheatle was forced to resign after evading answering rounds of questioning by punting to the FBI in another congressional hearing earlier this week.\n\nWray promised his agency would leave 'no stone unturned' and emphasized that he wanted to provide all the information he had at this point of the ongoing investigation.\n\n'The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing.'\n\nHe also made a reference to the warnings he has been giving Congress for years now about the threats of domestic terrorism.\n\nThe shooting is 'another example, particularly heinous and very public one of what I have been talking about.'\n\nWray again warned about 'passion and heated rhetoric turning into actual violence.'\n\n'We've seen it against public officials of all sorts, we've seen it against law enforcements the number of officers shot and killed in the line of duty is alarming.'\n\n'It's almost every five days that a law enforcement officer is killed in the line of duty, that is an example of the kinds of ways passion and heated rhetoric can bubble over into violence.'\n\nThe Judiciary Committee hearing is expected to focus on both the shooting at the Butler, Pennsylvania, rally and the 'ongoing politicization' of the FBI.\n\nQuestioning on a separate foiled Iranian plot to assassinate Donald Trump is sure to be a topic of contention.\n\nA bombshell report last week revealed the U.S. received intelligence of an Iranian assassination plot in the weeks before Trump was shot at the Pennsylvania rally.\n\nMeanwhile, House Republicans are expected to set up a bipartisan task force to investigate the shooting in a vote this week.\n\nMembers of Congress are expected to demand answers from FBI Director Chris Wray about the Trump assassination attempt on Wednesday\n\nThe FBI and Secret Service revealed to lawmakers last week they spotted shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks as a person of interest a full 62 minutes before he fired a shot.\n\nTwenty minutes passed between the time Secret Service agents spotted Crooks with a gun on the rooftop and he fired shots at the president.\n\nIn a staggering moment, Cheatle admitted on Monday her agents on the ground were warned between two and five times that there was a 'suspicious person' reported before Trump took the stage.\n\nWhile Trump walked around with little more than a bloody ear, Crooks killed former fire chief Corey Comperatore, 50, and critically injured two other rally goers sitting close to where the former president was speaking last weekend before he was neutralized.\n\nThe security chief had faced mounting questions over why an agent was not stationed on the roof from where gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks opened fire on the former president, and why Trump was allowed to take the stage even when a threat was detected.\n\nShe had also been ridiculed for suggesting her agency did not have a presence on the roof because it was 'sloped.'\n\nThe 20-year-old shooter Crooks, was able to get within 160 yards of the stage where the former president was speaking when he opened fire. The building on which he stood was outside the security perimeter, despite clearly being within rifle shooting range.\n\nAnd that was despite the FBI learning of a threat on Trump's life from Iran leading to a bump in security for the former president in the days before the July 13 rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nCheatle said she believed she was the 'best person' to lead the Secret Service at this time, but later acquiesced to the bipartisan demands for her resignation.\n\nOn the day of the rally, Trump walked out onto the stage at 6:02 p.m.\n\nThen at around 6:12 p.m. Crooks' first shots rang out.\n\nCheatle could not tell lawmakers how the shooter had gotten onto the roof.\n\nAt the time of the shooting, law enforcement agents were inside the building, 147 yards away from where Trump stood, but not on top of it.\n\nCheatle curiously claimed no officers had been placed on the roof because it was sloped.\n\n'That building in particular has a sloped roof at its highest point. And so, you know, there's a safety factor that would be considered there that we wouldn't want to put somebody up on a sloped roof,' she told ABC News in an interview Tuesday.\n\nComer said on Fox News Sunday the hearing would go on for six hours and Cheatle would face 'hundreds of questions'\n\n'And so, you know, the decision was made to secure the building, from inside.'\n\nWhat transpired instead was a security nightmare: Thomas Matthew Crooks was able to scale the building and secure his own position, while law enforcement struggled to locate him even amid pressing warnings from members of the Trump crowd. But there wasn't sufficient time to act on the tips, she explained.\n\n'The shooter was actually identified as a potential person of suspicion,' Cheatle said. 'Unfortunately, with the rapid succession of how things unfolded, by the time that individual was eventually located, they were on the rooftop and were able to fire off at the former president.'\n\nShe was referencing claims by witnesses that they alerted law enforcement about the threat, but agents weren't able to eliminate the threat in time. Officials have pointed to the initial responding officer, who lifted himself up on the roof only to lower himself back when the gunman turned his weapon at him.\n\nCheatle has take blame for the fateful security breach, but has denied calls to step down.\n\n'The buck stops with me,' she said.\n\n'It was unacceptable,' she told ABC. 'And it's something that shouldn't happen again.'\n\n'While we give overwhelming thanks to the individual Secret Service agents who did their jobs under immense pressure, this tragedy was preventable. The Secret Service has a zero fail mission, but it failed on July 13 and in the days leading up to the rally,' Comer is also expected to say, as he will again call for Cheatle's resignation.\n\nAlso coming into question on the call was the possible motive for Crooks to commit such an atrocity.\n\nOfficials did not confirm an operating motive and said that his rationale remains a mystery.\n\nAuthorities said that they have yet to find any ideological material that could shine light on why Crooks decided to shoot the former president.\n\nBut, they did reveal that Crooks operated several accounts on encrypted platforms that they are still working to gain access to.\n\nHere's a timeline of how that fateful July 11 went down:\n\n1PM\n\nThe grounds to the event at Butler Farm Show opened at 1pm.\n\nIt began an hours-long build up that saw MAGA supporters immediately pour into the area to camp out.\n\nSecurity swept the area and set up perimeters, however questions have been raised over how the gunman was able to secure a clear shot just 400ft from the stage.\n\n5PM\n\nAn hour before Trump took the stage at approximately 5pm, former GOP Senate candidate Sean Parnell warmed up the crowd, bringing cheers as he slammed President Biden and his stuttering campaign.\n\nWith the sun still high on a bright day, Trump emerged to 'God Bless the USA' playing over the loudspeakers at 6:03pm, and remained waving and shaking his fist at the crowd for several minutes.\n\n6:11PM\n\nTrump brought out a large graphic with statistics on the migrant crisis at the southern border, and told the crowd at 6:11pm: 'That chart's a couple of months old...'\n\n'If you want to really see something that's sad, take a look at what happened,' Trump continued - before he abruptly grabbed the side of his head as several 'pops' filled the event space.\n\n6:12PM\n\nThe 78-year-old dropped to the floor in an instant as five more shots rang overhead in quick succession, before four Secret Service agents raced to the stage and dove on top of the former president.\n\nStunning images showed Trump cowered on the floor as agents protected him, with blood dripping down his cheek.\n\nSeveral more Secret Service agents continued to flood the stage, while four heavily armed officers lined the perimeter ordering attendees to 'get down.'\n\nThe sniper, sat 400ft across from the rally on an exposed rooftop, fired another shot at the stage a second later while Trump fans streamed out of the bleachers.\n\nSecret Service scrambled to take control of the pandemonium where three attendees were hit, one fatally, within a matter of seconds.\n\n6:13PM\n\nAn emergency room doctor with blood spattered on his shirt later said he sprang into action to perform emergency CPR on one victim.\n\n'The guy had spun around was jammed between the benches and a head shot here. There's lots of blood and he had brain matter,' he told CBS News.\n\n'So I got him together so I got people there really helpful. I did CPR chest compressions as well.'\n\n6:14PM\n\nMicrophones surrounding the stage picked up staggering detail of the urgent response, beginning with one ordering screaming people to 'get down, get down, get down.'\n\nAt the same moment, snipers set up on a roof next to bleachers were seen firing back at the gunman, with Secret Service agents surrounding Trump heard on microphones confirming the moment he was brought down.\n\nDespite the chaos flying around the scene, the rally appeared to hold its breath to see if Trump was hit.\n\nA blood-spattered Donald Trump pumped his fist after being shot in the ear by a sniper, eight minutes after he took the stage at a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nIn a move that sparked iconic images set to define his candidacy, Trump stood up and triumphantly held his fist in the air, pumping it at his supporters to raucous relief.\n\n'USA, USA, USA,' the crowd chanted at the sight, with a blood-spattered Trump appearing to mouth the word 'fight' several times as Secret Service tried to hurry him away.\n\nWhile getting up off the floor, an agent picked up a white cloth and held it to Trump's bleeding ear, telling him to 'hold that on your head, it's bloody.'\n\n'Are we good?' one male agent says, as another responds quickly: 'Shooter down!'\n\n'Shooter's down. Are we good to move?' one says next. 'We're clear, we're clear, we're clear - let's move.'\n\nTrump repeatedly ordered the agents to 'let me get my shoes', to which one responds: 'I got you sir, I got you.'\n\nThe gunman was killed by agents shortly after opening fire, as footage emerged online showing him appear to be shot in the head while crouched on the roof.\n\nCrooks was seen laying lifeless on the rooftop in a later image, surrounded by law enforcement stood over him.\n\nA number of camouflaged law enforcement officers emerged from the side of the stage, part of a huge law enforcement presence that flooded the area within minutes of the first shot was fired.\n\nAt 6:14pm, Trump was whisked into his motorcade by around dozen Secret Service agents, who formed a protective human shield around him.\n\nBefore he got into his SUV, Trump again raised his fist to signify triumphantly surviving the assassination attempt.", "source": {"uri": "expressdigest.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "expressdigest.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Matt Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_enforcement", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Law enforcement"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Assassination"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8242029698", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:29:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:29:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:27:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/trump-attack-gunman-searched-online-about-jfk-shooting-fbi-chief/article_a9c3c7c8-2bba-53f7-873e-322ecbb87fb7.html", "title": "Trump attack gunman searched online about JFK shooting: FBI chief", "body": "Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump is evacuated from a rally by Secret Service agents after an assassination attempt in Butler, Pennsylvania, on July 13, 2024\n\nThe gunman who attempted to assassinate Donald Trump at a campaign rally searched online for details about the November 1963 shooting of US president John F. Kennedy in the days before the attack, the FBI director said Wednesday.\n\nFBI chief Christopher Wray, testifying before a congressional committee, said the gunman flew a drone over the venue where the former president was scheduled to speak about two hours before he took the stage in Butler, Pennsylvania, on July 13.\n\nWray told members of the House Judiciary Committee that investigators have not established a motive for the shooting but \"we are digging hard because this is one of the central questions for us.\"\n\nTrump survived the assassination bid, suffering a wound to his right ear, and a Secret Service sniper shot dead the suspected gunman -- named as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks -- less than 30 seconds after he had fired eight shots.\n\n\"With respect to former president Trump, there's some question about whether or not it's a bullet or shrapnel that, you know, that hit his ear,\" FBI chief Wray said.\n\nTwo rally attendees were seriously injured and a 50-year-old Pennsylvania firefighter was shot dead.\n\nWray said Crooks \"appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures, in general\" but that there was no clear pattern to the research.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" he said.\n\n\"Starting somewhere around July 6 or so, he became very focused on former president Trump and this rally,\" the FBI chief said, and he registered that same day to attend the campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for, quote, 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?'\" he said, a reference to Kennedy's assassination by Lee Harvey Oswald.\n\n\"That obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind.\"\n\nThe FBI director said no evidence has emerged so far that Crooks had any accomplices or co-conspirators and he seems to have been a \"loner.\"\n\nMore from this section CT GOP Chair says Trump will focus on Harris' record at the border Ashley Benefield's attorney argues for delay in ex-ballerina murder trial British Army tests high-powered laser weapon for first time\n\nCrooks was perched on the roof of a nearby building and opened fire on Trump with an AR-style assault rifle shortly after 6:00 pm, as the Republican White House candidate was addressing the rally in Butler.\n\n- Drone flight -\n\nUS Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned on Tuesday, a day after acknowledging the agency had failed in its mission to prevent the assassination attempt.\n\nWray said Crooks flew a drone over the rally area for around 11 minutes -- sometime between 3:50 pm and 4:00 pm -- on the day of the attack.\n\nHe said it was not flown directly over the stage but about 200 yards (meters) away.\n\nThe drone and its controller were recovered in the gunman's car along with two \"relatively crude\" explosive devices, Wray said.\n\nAnother explosive device was found in Crooks's residence.\n\nWray said the gunman purchased a ladder on the day of the shooting but appears not to have used it. Instead, he climbed onto the roof using some mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping.\n\nWray also said Crooks's AR-style gun had a collapsible stock which may explain why he was not seen by rally-goers or members of law enforcement with the weapon before the shooting.\n\nHe said Crooks visited the rally site on at least three occasions: about a week before the shooting, for about 70 minutes on the morning of the rally and again that afternoon.\n\nHe purchased 50 rounds of ammunition on the day of the attack and visited a shooting range the previous day.\n\ncl/aha", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_lefkow@reformer.com", "name": "Chris Lefkow", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secret_Service", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "United States Secret Service"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butler,_Pennsylvania", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Butler, Pennsylvania"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Butler, Pennsylvania"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241924426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:41:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:41:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:39:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "http://sentinelcolorado.com/uncategorized/the-fbi-will-leave-no-stone-unturned-investigating-the-trump-rally-shooting-wray-tells-congress/", "title": "The FBI will 'leave no stone unturned' investigating the Trump rally shooting, Wray tells Congress - Sentinel Colorado", "body": "WASHINGTON | The FBI will \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, the bureau's director told Congress on Wednesday.\n\nChristopher Wray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee was reflecting his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Pennsylvania that once more has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom. Agents are investigating the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, and what was the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's regular oversight of the FBI and Justice Department.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led committee, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the shooting. On Tuesday, Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned.\n\nWray was expected to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the FBI's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nThis story has been corrected to show the assassination attempt on Trump was July 13, not June 13.", "source": {"uri": "sentinelcolorado.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Sentinel Colorado"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. assassination attempt", "body": "The US Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) said it would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, its director told Congress on Wednesday.\n\nChristopher Wray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee was reflecting his most detailed comments to date about the 13 July shooting in Pennsylvania that once more has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom.\n\nAgents are investigating the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, and what was the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's regular oversight of the FBI and Justice Department.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the failure to prevent the attempted assassination.\n\nWray was expected to be questioned by lawmakers sceptical of the FBI's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one spectator and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted {"uri": "8241627144", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:36:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:36:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:35:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://qctimes.com/trump-rally-gunman-looked-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_8f7336ab-20e4-51a7-b04a-56a3804d22de.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "WASHINGTON -- FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers on Wednesday that a laptop tied to the Trump rally gunman included a Google search of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nThat is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nWray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nSecret Service director steps down after assassination attempt against Trump By COLLEEN LONG The Associated Press\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nPeople are also reading... New business coming to Davenport's former Bed Bath & Beyond Two injured in shooting at NorthPark Mall in Davenport Monday Witnesses describe gunfire at NorthPark Mall that injured 2 Quad-Cities business openings: New furniture store coming to Davenport, other happenings Davenport code enforcement officer quits after argument with boss over Wold-owned duplex Teen arrested in relation to shooting at NorthPark Mall in Davenport Deere rolls back diversity, equity, inclusion initiatives after conservative backlash Several Davenport teens accused of gang crimes; police report group violence down overall Timeless Tickets: East Moline-raised rapper Torrian Ball remembers opening for Lil Durk in 2021 Second person dies after Friday house fire in Riverdale One injured in Scott County motorcycle crash Davenport developer pulls 16-unit central city development at Sixth and Sylvan Iowa nursing home resident suffocated while trapped in bed rails, state says One person found dead during Riverdale house fire early Friday morning Name released in fatal East Moline shooting\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\nGOP threatened to sue over November ballot if Biden dropped out. Experts call that 'ridiculous' ROBERT YOON Associated Press\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up!
