{"uri": "8241850558", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:34:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:34:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:33:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/trump-shooter-searched-online-for-jfk-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_f7d6b134-1903-589e-acdd-d9f7411f3ddd.html", "title": "Trump shooter searched online for JFK assassination, FBI director says", "body": "By David Morgan and Sarah N. Lynch\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) -The 20-year-old gunman who tried to kill Donald Trump did an online search of the John F. Kennedy assassination around the time he began to focus attention on the Republican presidential candidate, FBI Director Christopher Wray said on Wednesday.\n\nWray told the U.S. House Judiciary Committee that suspect Thomas Crooks visited the Trump rally site in Butler, Pennsylvania, twice before he clambered onto the roof of a nearby building on July 13 and fired off at least eight rounds, wounding Trump in the ear, killing one rally-goer and injuring two others.\n\n\"Analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6, he did a Google search for -quote - 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Wray said.\n\nHe was referring to Lee Harvey Oswald, who assassinated former President Kennedy in Dallas, Texas, on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\n\"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray said.\n\n\"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally,\" he added, saying Crooks became \"very focused on President Trump and his rally\" at that point after showing interest in public figures more generally.\n\nAbout two hours before the shooting, Crooks flew a drone over the area about 200 yards (180 meters) from the stage where Trump spoke to the crowd, and live-streamed footage for about 11 minutes.\n\nLaw enforcement officers did not spot Crooks on the roof with his AR-15-style rifle until \"seconds\" before he opened fire, said Wray, noting that the timeline could change as the investigators' understanding of facts evolves.\n\n\"It's all happening in seconds,\" Wray said. He added that the rifle had a collapsible stock, \"which could explain why it might have been less easy for people to observe.\"\n\nCrude explosive devices later recovered from Crooks' car and home were designed to be detonated remotely. Crooks had a transmitter with him, Wray added. But he said the FBI believes the suspect would not have been successful had he tried to detonate the devices.\n\nThe motive for the shooting remains unclear. Wray said many people have described Crooks as a loner and the list of contacts in his phone was short.\n\nThe hearing also focused on the increasingly tense political atmosphere surrounding the presidential campaign.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated-threat environment. And tragically, the ... assassination attempt is another example, particularly heinous,\" Wray testified.\n\nA day before Wray's testimony, Kimberly Cheatle resigned as director of the U.S. Secret Service after bipartisan demands to quit over the failure to prevent the attempted assassination.\n\nJudiciary Committee Chairman Jim Jordan welcomed Wray's willingness to share details about the FBI investigation into the assassination attempt.\n\nBut he also cited skepticism toward the FBI that exists among some Republicans, who are angry about the arrest of Trump supporters who stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, as Congress certified President Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.\n\n\"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation,\" Jordan said.\n\nRepresentative Jerrold Nadler, the panel's top Democrat, condemned the Trump shooting \"unequivocally and unabashedly\" but pointed to years of political threats and violence, and violent rhetoric from Republicans including Trump himself.\n\n\"If you think that this one assassin's bullet was a bolt out of the blue, and not part of a wave of violence that has threatened this nation for years, then you have missed the point,\" Nadler said.\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan and Sarah N. Lynch; Editing by Scott Malone, Alistair Bell, Nick Zieminski and Rod Nickel)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sarah_n_lynch@gazette.com", "name": "Sarah N. {"uri": "2024-07-432539556", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:27:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:27:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:08:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.nysun.com/article/trumps-would-be-assassin-did-searches-on-lee-harvey-oswald-kennedy-as-he-plotted-his-attack-fbi-director-testifies", "title": "Trump's Would-Be Assassin Did Searches on Lee Harvey Oswald, Kennedy, as he Plotted His Attack, FBI Director Testifies", "body": "The gunman looked up the Kennedy assassination the same day that he registered to attend the Trump rally in Pennsylvania, the director tells Congress.\n\nThe FBI director, Christopher Wray, told a Congressional committee on Wednesday that President Trump's would-be assassin researched Lee Harvey Oswald's assassination of John F. Kennedy the day he registered to attend the Pennsylvania rally.\n\nMr. Wray, during his appearance before the House Judiciary Committee reported that a week before the assassination attempt against Trump -- which wounded one bystander and critically injured others -- Crooks searched on Google: \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nThat same day, Mr. Wray reported, the shooter registered to attend Trump's rally at Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"That's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Mr. Wray said.\n\nCrooks's search history suggests he was \"broadly interested\" in various public figures though became \"very focused\" on Trump on around July 6.\n\nMr. Wray also confirmed that there is currently no evidence to suggest that Crooks was working in cahoots with any individual or organization when he attempted to take the 45th President's life.\n\nHe also added that prevailing descriptions of the gunman as a \"loner\" seem to fit with what they've seen on his devices.\n\n\"There doesn't appear to be a whole lot of interactions between him, face-to-face or digital, with a lot of people,\" Mr. Wray noted. \"That doesn't mean there's not any.\"\n\nHe added that Crooks had fewer-than-expected contacts in his devices.\n\nMr. Wray also notes that gaining access to Crooks's phone was a \"significant technical challenge\" and that the gunman was communicating via encrypted messaging apps.\n\nOver the course of the hearing, Mr. Wray also confirmed that they found evidence that the gunman had flown a drone over the site two hours before the rally began. The drone was reportedly in the air for 11 minutes.\n\n\"We're still trying to figure out exactly what he saw,\" he said, adding that FBI experts think he was likely live-streaming the video footage.\n\nWhile they have been able to make out the flight path of the drone while it was in the air, they are still trying to determine what the shooter \"could have seen in these 11 minutes.\"\n\nMr. Wray also reported that the FBI confirmed that Crooks brought a five foot ladder to the rally, though he also said that investigators did not find the ladder at the scene. As a result, it remains unclear how Crooks managed to get on the roof.\n\nCrooks also visited a shooting range a day before his attempted assassination of Trump, and investigators believe he \"probably\" used a weapon similar to the one he fired on July 13.\n\nThroughout the hearing, the FBI chief maintained that they have not found a \"clear motive\" for the shooting, but affirmed that investigators are \"digging hard\" to uncover more information about the shooter.", "source": {"uri": "nysun.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Sun"}, "authors": [{"uri": "novi_zhukovsky@nysun.com", "name": "Novi Zhukovsky", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. {"uri": "8241609120", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:24:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:24:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:22:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://turnto10.com/news/nation-world/fbi-director-christopher-wray-to-face-questioning-on-former-president-donald-trump-assassination-attempt-butler-pennsylvania-shooting-thomas-crooks-motive-investigation", "title": "FBI director Christopher Wray to face questioning on Trump assassination attempt", "body": "WASHINGTON (TND) -- FBI director Christopher Wray is testifying before the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday as the agency continues its investigation into the failed assassination of former President Donald Trump as lawmakers continue their investigations into how the Secret Service failed to prevent the shooting and law enforcement continues to search for a motive behind the shooting.\n\n\"The attempted assassination of the former president was an attack on our democracy,\" Wray said during his opening statement.\n\nIt will be the most in-depth comments yet from Wray as the FBI continues its investigation of the suspected 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Crooks, and what may have drove him to open fire at the rally, killing one person in the crowd, injuring two others and wounding Trump's right ear. The FBI is investigating the shooting as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Wray said Wednesday that they have not uncovered any accomplices in the shooting.\n\nThe FBI is generally secretive around active investigations but the public interest and extraordinary circumstances surrounding the attack has prompted agency officials to be more forthcoming with details and developments as they continue to piece things together.\n\nInvestigators recovered a drone Crooks flew around 200 yards away from the stage roughly two hours before Trump started to speak, which Wray said he was watching footage of on a live feed through a phone.\n\nSnipers killed the suspected gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Crooks, after seeing him on the nearby rooftop. He used an AR 15-style rifle that he purchased legally and eight bullet cartridges were recovered from the roof where he opened fire, Wray told lawmakers.\n\nThe hearing was scheduled before the July 13 shooting as part of routine oversight of the FBI and Justice Department, which have both under the spotlight in the GOP-led House for the criminal cases against the former president that are likely on hold past Election Day after the Supreme Court issued a ruling giving presidents immunity.\n\nWray and Attorney General Merrick Garland have both been the focus of repeated contentious hearings in front of House GOP-led committees amid lingering frustration over its 2016 investigation of Trump's ties to Russia, the prosecution of rioters at the Jan. 6 insurrection at the Capitol and the legal cases against Trump.\n\n\"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation,\" Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, said during the hearing.\n\nThe Secret Service has taken the brunt of the congressional criticism for the attempt on Trump's life, leading to the resignation of director Kimberly Cheatle, but Wray is likely to face tough questioning on the lack of details about a potential motive behind the shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania. {"uri": "8241696099", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:28:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:28:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:27:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.jamaicaobserver.com/2024/07/24/gunman-flew-drone-trump-rally-area-shooting-fbi-chief/", "title": "Gunman flew drone over Trump rally area before shooting: FBI chief - Jamaica Observer", "body": "WASHINGTON, United States (AFP) - The 20-year-old gunman who attempted to assassinate Donald Trump at a campaign rally flew a drone over the area about two hours before the former US president began to speak, the FBI director said Wednesday.\n\nFBI chief Christopher Wray, testifying before a congressional committee, also said the investigation into the July 13 shooting had not yet revealed a motive for the gunman.\n\nThomas Matthew Crooks opened fire on Trump with an AR-style assault rifle shortly after 6:00 pm as the Republican White House candidate was addressing a campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nCrooks, who was perched on the roof of a nearby building, was shot dead by a Secret Service sniper less than 30 seconds after firing his first shots.\n\nTrump was wounded in the ear, two rally attendees were seriously injured and a 50-year-old Pennsylvania firefighter was shot dead.\n\nUS Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned on Tuesday, a day after acknowledging that the agency had failed in its mission to prevent the assassination attempt.\n\nWray said Crooks flew a drone over the rally area for around 11 minutes -- between around 3:50 pm and 4:00 pm -- on the day of the shooting some 200 yards (meters) away from the stage where Trump was scheduled to speak.\n\nThe drone and its controller were recovered in the gunman's car.\n\nTwo \"relatively crude\" explosive devices were also found in the car along with another at the gunman's residence, Wray said.\n\nThe FBI director said the devices had the ability to be detonated remotely and the gunman had a transmitter with him when he was shot.\n\n\"It looks like, because of the on-off position on the receivers, that that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" he said. \"But that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous.\"\n\nAsked how many shots Crooks fired, Wray said eight cartridges had been recovered on the roof.\n\nWray told members of the House Judiciary Committee that investigators \"do not yet have a clear picture of his motive.\"\n\n\"We're not seeing that yet, but we are digging hard, because this is one of the central questions for us,\" the FBI chief said.\n\nHe said the gunman \"appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures, in general\" but \"there doesn't seem to be a whole lot of rhyme or reason to it so far.\"\n\n\"Sarting somewhere around July 6 or so, he became very focused on former president Trump and this rally,\" Wray said.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for quote, 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?'\" he said, a reference to the 1963 assassination of president John F. Kennedy by Lee Harvey Oswald.\n\nThere is no evidence at this time that Crooks had any accomplices or co-conspirators, the FBI chief said.", "source": {"uri": "jamaicaobserver.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Jamaica Observer"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Unmanned aerial vehicle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secret_Service", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "United States Secret Service"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241689673", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:22:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:22:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:21:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.dailywire.com/news/fbi-says-trump-rally-shooter-flew-drone-200-yards-away-from-stage-hours-before-assassination-attempt", "title": "FBI Says Trump Rally Shooter Flew Drone 200 Yards Away From Stage Hours Before Assassination Attempt", "body": "The FBI believes the gunman who opened fire on former President Donald Trump's rally in Pennsylvania earlier this month flew a drone near the venue for about 11 minutes in the hours before the shooting, FBI Director Christopher Wray testified to the House on Wednesday.\n\nIn an exchange with House Judiciary Chairman Jim Jordan (R-OH), Wray said investigators \"recovered\" a drone that the shooter, identified as a 20-year-old man named Thomas Matthew Crooks, \"appears to have used.\"\n\nThe drone was recovered in Crooks' vehicle, where it and the controller were located at the time of the shooting, Wray said, who noted the drone is being \"exploited and analyzed by the FBI lab.\"\n\nWray said \"it appears\" that around 3:50 p.m. on the day of the shooting, Crooks was flying the drone \"around the area,\" which he explained was \"about 200 yards, give or take, away\" from the stage.\n\nThe FBI director said investigators \"think, but we do not know\" that Crooks was \"live-streaming -- you know, viewing the footage ... for about 11 minutes.\"\n\nLater in the hearing, Wray explained how there were no recordings or photos on the drone from the day of the rally, but the FBI has been able to recreate the flight pattern. He said experts believe that Crooks was using the drone to view the area with a live stream.\n\nRoughly two hours after the drone is believed to have taken flight on July 13, Crooks began shooting with a rifle from the rooftop of a building roughly 150 yards away from the stage where Trump was speaking to supporters.\n\nA Secret Service sniper shot and killed the gunman while other personnel rushed to protect Trump and escort him off the stage, but not before a bullet ripped through the former president's ear. One rallygoer was killed, and two others were injured.\n\nWray told Jordan the FBI recovered three explosive devices, two from Crooks' vehicle and one from his residence. The devices were \"relatively crude\" but did have the capability to be \"detonated remotely,\" Wray added.\n\nReceivers for two of the explosive devices were found with the devices themselves, Wray said. He added that Crooks had a \"transmitter\" with him when law enforcement killed him.\n\nWray said the devices were also being reviewed by the FBI's lab and noted how \"at the moment\" it appears to investigators that because of the \"on-off position on the receivers,\" if Crooks \"had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked.\"\n\nWray said the FBI \"finally\" got into Crooks' phone in an effort to determine his motives and state of mind. He said Crooks had been using \"some encrypted messaging applications.\"\n\nDuring another exchange, this one with Rep. Dan Bishop (R-NC), Wray said investigators recovered \"eight cartridges\" on the roof of the building where Crooks opened fire.\n\nAsked why Crooks was able to get off eight shots, Wray responded, \"Well, that I think is something we're still digging into.\"\n\nUnder questioning from Rep. Adam Schiff (D-CA), Wray testified that a laptop linked to Crooks revealed a Google search related to Lee Harvey Oswald and the 1963 assassination of President John F. Kennedy.\n\nIn particular, Wray said, Crooks queried \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" on July 6, which appears to be the same day the shooter registered for Trump's rally.", "source": {"uri": "dailywire.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Daily Wire"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Matt Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Unmanned aerial vehicle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241527881", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:28:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:28:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:27:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/7/24/fbi-director-wray-faces-questions-from-lawmakers-over-trump-rally-shooting", "title": "FBI Director Wray faces questions from lawmakers over Trump rally shooting", "body": "Christopher Wray says FBI probe into 'despicable' assassination attempt against ex-president continues.\n\nFBI Director Christopher Wray has said the agency will leave \"no stone unturned\" as he faced questions from United States lawmakers about this month's assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump.\n\nDuring his opening statement to the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, Wray said the shooting at Trump's July 13 rally in Pennsylvania was \"an attack on our democracy and our democratic process\".\n\n\"We will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind, especially a despicable account of this magnitude,\" he said.\n\n\"And I want to assure you and the American people that the men and women of the FBI will continue to work tirelessly to get to the bottom of what happened.\"\n\nWray's testimony comes a day after US Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned amid widespread criticism over the security protocols deployed for the Trump rally.\n\nThe former president and current Republican Party presidential nominee was shot in the ear by a gunman who witnesses said had taken up a position on a rooftop with a direct line of sight to the rally stage.\n\nOne rally attendee was killed and two were seriously injured in the incident.\n\nThe FBI said it is investigating the shooting as an act of \"domestic terrorism\" and an attempted assassination.\n\nBut the agency has not yet determined the motive of the suspected shooter, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, fuelling questions for Wray from lawmakers.\n\nThe FBI director and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump, President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention and Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press news agency last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nOn Wednesday morning, Wray told lawmakers that the FBI had recovered a drone in Crooks's vehicle. He said the agency believes the suspect flew the drone about 180 metres (200 yards) from the rally stage before the event began.\n\n\"We're going to leave no stone unturned. The shooter might be deceased, but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing,\" the director said.\n\nRepublican Congressman Jim Jordan, the chairman of the House Judiciary Committee, said at the start of the hearing that multiple questions remained unanswered, including why all the buildings near the rally stage were not secured.\n\n\"We hope to learn more today from Director Wray about the shooter: his use of the drone, the explosives that were in his car, how he got on the roof and a host of other questions,\" Jordan said.\n\n\"It is our hope that Director Wray's testimony can begin to give answers to the American people about all these questions and concerns.\"\n\nRepresentative Jerry Nadler, the panel's top Democrat, condemned the Trump shooting \"unequivocally and unabashedly\" but pointed to years of political threats and violence and violent rhetoric from Republicans, including Trump himself.\n\n\"If you think that this one assassin's bullet was a bolt out of the blue and not part of a wave of violence that has threatened this nation for years, then you have missed the point,\" Nadler said.\n\nThe FBI has largely avoided the same level of scrutiny directed at the Secret Service over security lapses that preceded the Trump rally shooting.\n\nBut some US lawmakers have been sceptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI director has long faced opposition from hardline Republicans, some angered over the arrest of Trump supporters who stormed the US Capitol on January 6, 2021, as Congress certified Biden's 2020 election victory over Trump.", "source": {"uri": "aljazeera.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Al Jazeera Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "2024-07-432362901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:42:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:42:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:10:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/national-and-world-news/trump-shooter-searched-details-of-lee-harvey-oswald-and-jfk-assassination-flew-drone-near-rally/article_212a222f-d5ae-5dfa-b967-7c6a77270365.html", "title": "Trump shooter searched details of Lee Harvey Oswald and JFK assassination; flew drone near rally site, FBI director says", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray, pictured at the Rayburn House Office Building on July 24 in Washington, DC, said Donald Trump's would-be assassin flew a drone near the rally area two hours before the former president took the stage.\n\n(CNN) -- Donald Trump's would-be assassin searched for details of the John F. Kennedy shooting from his laptop and flew a drone in the area near the rally just two hours before the former president took the stage on July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday.\n\nAccording to the FBI's analysis of Thomas Matthew Crooks' laptop, Crooks searched how far Lee Harvey Oswald was when he shot and killed President John F. Kennedy in 1963.\n\nThe search was on July 6, the same day the Trump rally was announced.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for: 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\n\"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" the FBI director added. \"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally.\"\n\nShooter flew drone just 2 hours before Trump took the stage\n\nSpeaking to the House Judiciary Committee, Wray revealed that \"around 4 p.m.,\" the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, \"was flying the drone around the area\" of the rally, approximately 200 yards from the stage.\n\nThe drone was in the air for approximately 11 minutes, and investigators believe Crooks watched a live feed from the drone on his phone. CNN previously reported that the drone was found in his car following the shooting.\n\nIn addition, Crooks had two explosives in his car at the time of the shooting and one in his home, but likely did not have the ability to detonate them from the roof where he was killed, Wray testified.\n\n\"It looks like because of the on/off position on the receivers, that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting as both an attempted assassination and as a potential act of domestic terrorism.\n\nGun had a collapsable stock and was purchased from shooter's father\n\nInvestigators say that Crooks fired approximately eight times from an AR-style rifle at the former president before being killed by a US Secret Service counter sniper.\n\nThe rifle Crooks used was purchased from his father, Wray testified.\n\n\"The weapon that he used for the attempted assassination was an AR-style rifle that was purchased legally, that he - as my understanding - acquired, I think bought actually from his father, who was the one who originally bought it,\" Wray said.\n\nPreviously, officials said they believed the firearm belonged to Crooks' father - not the shooter - and they didn't know how Crooks accessed the weapon.\n\nFBI officials have repeatedly asserted that they believe Crooks acted alone, and Wray reiterated that there is no evidence of any co-conspirators.\n\n\"I have been saying some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment,\" Wray said. \"The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is ongoing.\"\n\nInvestigators have gone through the shooter's phone and computer, scoured his search history and bedroom and have interviewed his family and friends, but have struggled to identify what motivated the 20-year-old would be assassin to act.\n\nCrooks also had no prior contacts with the FBI, officials say, and had not been previously on their radar or databases.\n\nShooter was searching for news stories\n\nWray pushed back against reports that Crooks searched for images of specific prominent public officials online, saying that it appears he was actually searching for news articles.\n\n\"The shooter appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures in general, but so far we are seeing kind of news articles and things like that,\" Wray said. He continued, \"so the images that have been reported about, really what we are talking about there are when you do a news search of an article the image appears in a cache as opposed to like a search for that specific individual.\"\n\nThe FBI director cautioned that the effort to uncover Crooks' motive is ongoing, but warned that \"it is, quite frankly, a dangerous time to be a prominent public official.\"\n\nThe House Judiciary Committee hearing is ongoing.\n\nThis story is breaking and will be updated.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. All rights reserved.\n\nTHE-CNN-WIRE (TM) & \u00a9 2024 CABLE NEWS NETWORK, INC., A TIME WARNER COMPANY. Kennedy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Unmanned aerial vehicle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butler,_Pennsylvania", "type": "loc", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Butler, Pennsylvania"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Butler, Pennsylvania"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. Kennedy"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "CNN"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Google", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Google"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington,_D.C.", "type": "loc", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Washington, D.C."}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Washington, D.C."}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Domestic_terrorism", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Domestic terrorism"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sniper", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "Sniper"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secret_Service", "type": "wiki", "score": 2, "label": {"eng": "United States Secret Service"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Warner_Bros._Discovery", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Warner Bros. Discovery"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WarnerMedia", "type": "org", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "WarnerMedia"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trademark", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Trademark"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Firearm", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Firearm"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Radar", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Radar"}}], "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns", "wgt": 13}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition_Shooting", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Competition Shooting", "wgt": 14}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/Searching", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Internet/Searching", "wgt": 16}, {"uri": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Search_Engines", "label": "dmoz/Computers/Software/Search Engines", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Organizations", "label": "dmoz/Recreation/Guns/Organizations", "wgt": 11}, {"uri": "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 80}], "image": "https://bloximages.newyork1.vip.townnews.com/channel3000.com/content/tncms/assets/v3/editorial/1/8b/18b7e1b8-77dc-55d2-b255-1a20ace7bc51/66a059efd59cc.image.jpg?crop=1920%2C1008%2C0%2C35&resize=438%2C230&order=crop%2Cresize", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9758656", "eventUri": "eng-9758656", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-24", "textStart": 80, "textEnd": 87}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-13", "textStart": 449, "textEnd": 456}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-06", "textStart": 719, "textEnd": 725, "freq": 2}], "sentiment": -0.1372549019607843, "wgt": 194, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8241988586", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:44:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:44:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:42:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.inquirer.com/news/nation-world/trump-shooting-jfk-thomas-crooks-christopher-wray-congress-20240724.html", "title": "Trump gunman searched for info on JFK's assassin and other new details we learned from this week's hearings on the attack", "body": "Authorities revealed new information about gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks' motive and preparations as well as the security failures that allowed him to carry out his attack on the former president.\n\nThomas Matthew Crooks came to Donald Trump's July 13 rally in Butler, Pa., prepared for violence. The authorities charged with protecting the former president weren't adequately prepared to stop him.\n\nThose twin conclusions emerged this week during a series of congressional oversight hearings into the circumstances of, motivations for, and security failures surrounding the attempt on Trump's life -- the most serious threat to a president or presidential nominee since a gunman shot President Ronald Reagan in 1981.\n\nAnd as lawmakers heard testimony from U.S. Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle, FBI Director Christopher Wray and Pennsylvania State Police Commissioner Christopher Paris in a series of proceedings over the past three days, several new details about the shooting and the investigation emerged.\n\nHere are some of the highlights:\n\nCrooks, 20, of Bethel Park, Pa., had searched online for details of the assassination of President John F. Kennedy roughly a week before his attack on Trump, Wray told members of the U.S. House Judiciary Committee during a hearing Wednesday.\n\nThe FBI director said agents scouring Crooks' search history discovered that he'd made queries like \"How far away was [Kennedy assassin Lee Harvey] Oswald from Kennedy\" the same day he registered to attend the Butler rally.\n\n\"That's a search that is significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray said, adding that around the same time his search history had become \"very focused on former President Trump and this rally.\"\n\nCrooks had also taken other steps to prepare, including visiting the rally site -- on the grounds of the Butler Farm Show, about an hour away from Crooks' home in Bethel Park -- at least twice before unleashing his attack.\n\nWray testified that Crooks visited the site for roughly 20 minutes about a week before the rally, and then spent roughly 70 minutes there on the morning of July 13. During that later visit, Wray said, Crooks surveilled the grounds with a drone he flew over an area some 200 yards above the rally stage.\n\nThe day before Trump's stop in Western Pennsylvania, Crooks, who Wray described as a \"fairly avid shooting hobbyist,\" went to a shooting range near his home to practice with the AR-15-style rifle investigators believe he used in the attack.\n\nThat weapon, complete with a collapsible scope that Wray said may have helped Crooks hide that he was carrying a firearm on July 13, was originally purchased by his father more than a decade ago. And while investigators initially said that the firearm was still registered to him, Wray told lawmakers Wednesday that the son had legally purchased the gun from his father.\n\nThe morning of the rally Crooks bought 50 rounds of ammunition from a local gun store, then drove to the fairgrounds with two \"relatively crude\" explosive devices found in his car, Wray said.\n\nBoth were capable of being remotely detonated with a switch Crooks was carrying with him as he carried out his attack.\n\nHowever, Wray said, \"because of the on/off position on the receivers, if he had tried to detonate those devices from [the rooftop perch from where he opened fire] it would not have worked.\"\n\nThe FBI director added: \"That doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous.\"\n\nNearly two weeks after the shooting, investigators have made little progress in identifying Crooks' motive in attacking Trump. Wray told lawmakers Wednesday that agents have conducted dozens of interviews and spent countless hours examining the gunman's digital footprint both online and on his personal devices.\n\n\"We'd love to have a roadmap that tells us exactly what he was thinking. We haven't found that yet,\" he said. \"Doesn't mean we won't. We're looking all over the place and we're going to leave no stone unturned.\"\n\nCrooks' parents have been cooperative so far in the investigation, Wray said, but from what agents have been able to discern so far, their son largely kept his own counsel.\n\n\"There doesn't appear to [have been] a whole lot of interactions between him, face-to-face or digital, with a lot of people,\" Wray said. \"That doesn't mean there's not any.\"\n\n\" READ MORE: What Thomas Matthew Crooks' ex-classmates and employer have said about the Trump shooting suspect\n\nMeanwhile, members of the House Oversight Committee roasted Cheatle, the U.S. Secret Service director, for hours on Monday over her agency's failure to adequately secure the rally site before Trump's speech.\n\nThe bipartisan criticism she received throughout the most contentious of the week's proceedings culminated in her resignation a day later.\n\nCheatle acknowledged during her testimony that the Secret Service had turned down requests over the two years before the attack to beef up Trump's security detail. But she insisted that on July 13 \"there were not requests that were denied\" for the Butler rally.\n\nCheatle also told lawmakers that her agency had identified the building from which Crooks carried out his attack -- an agricultural toolmakers' warehouse roughly 150 yards from the stage -- as a potential security vulnerability as they reviewed the location before the rally.\n\nAnd yet because it fell outside a security perimeter the Secret Service had established, it had tasked local authorities -- specifically, the Butler County Emergency Services Unit -- with securing the building.\n\nButler County District Attorney Richard Goldinger, whose office oversees the unit, has previously said it informed the Secret Service that local police did not have the manpower to secure that building.\n\nCheatle told lawmakers that the Secret Service received \"two to five\" reports the day of the rally of a suspicious person lingering outside the security perimeter.\n\nInitially, she said, local officers had noticed him using a rangefinder -- used by marksmen to measure distances to remote objects. Wray told lawmakers Wednesday that those reports came about an hour before Crooks opened fire.\n\nAnother local officer positioned outside the venue reported Crooks skulking around the rally site and crawling on the ground, Cheatle said. That officer disseminated his photo to others involved in the security effort.\n\nAbout a half hour before the shooting, yet another officer spotted Crooks again, scoping out the roof of the building from which he would eventually open fire and circulated his photo among other law enforcement.\n\nDuring that period, two local officers -- members of the Butler County Emergency Services Unit -- left their assigned posts in a building with a vantage-point view of the roof from where Crooks would eventually fire to join the search for him on the ground, said Paris, the Pennsylvania State Police commissioner, in testimony before the House Homeland Security Committee on Tuesday. It was not clear, Paris said, whether those officers would have been able to spot Crooks on the roof had they remained at their duty posts.\n\nBut Cheatle and Paris both stressed that no one reported seeing Crooks with a firearm until seconds before he opened fire. And despite the early reports of Crooks' suspicious activity, authorities had no reason to deem him an imminent security threat, they said.\n\nParis told lawmakers that Crooks was one of several individuals in the crowd that day whose behavior authorities had flagged as potentially suspicious.\n\nThe first time anyone reported spotting Crooks with a gun came just seconds before he opened fire, Wray told lawmakers in his testimony Wednesday.\n\nHe, Paris and Cheatle all described how moments before the shooting a local officer, responding to reports from other spectators of an armed man on the roof, tried to hoist himself up on top of the building to confront him.\n\nAs he \"dangled\" from the edge, Crooks pointed his rifle at the officer, prompting him to fall from his position, Paris said. Crooks fired off eight shots in the six seconds that followed -- hitting Trump, killing one rally spectator and injuring two others.\n\nA Secret Service sniper shot and killed him moments later.\n\nThis week's congressional hearings were only the start of what is shaping up to be an exhaustive review by multiple agencies of Crooks' shooting that day and the multiple security failures that allowed it to happen.\n\nIn addition to the ongoing FBI investigation into Crooks' preparation and motivation, the Pennsylvania State Police are conducting a parallel probe into the shooting of the three spectators hit by the gunman as well as the Secret Service sniper's use of force that ultimately killed Crooks.\n\nMeanwhile, the U.S. Secret Service and the Inspector General's Office for the Department of Homeland Security are conducting their own internal reviews. Cheatle told lawmakers her agency's probe would not be complete before September -- a timeline several members of Congress balked at Monday.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson (R,, La.) and Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries (D., N.Y.) also announced plans to form a bipartisan task force to continue Congress' investigation of the incident. Lawmakers are expected to vote on that proposal later this week.\n\n\"The security failures that allowed an assassination attempt on Donald Trump's life are shocking,\" they said in a joint statement Tuesday. \"The task force will be empowered with subpoena authority and will move quickly to find the facts, ensure accountability, and make certain such failures never happen again.\"", "source": {"uri": "inquirer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Philadelphia Inquirer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jeremy_roebuck@inquirer.com", "name": "Jeremy Roebuck", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Matt_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Matt Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secret_Service", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "United States Secret Service"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butler_County,_Pennsylvania", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Butler County, Pennsylvania"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Butler County, Pennsylvania"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "United States"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8242128431", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:26:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:26:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:25:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.abc.net.au/news/2024-07-25/trump-shooter-searched-online-for-jfk-assassination-fbi-director/104139882", "title": "Trump shooter searched online for JFK killing week before assassination attempt", "body": "The motive for the shooter remains unknown, however he has been described as a loner with a short list of phone contacts.\n\nThe 20-year-old gunman who tried to kill Donald Trump did an online search of the John F Kennedy assassination around the time he began to focus attention on the Republican presidential candidate.\n\nFBI Director Christopher Wray on Wednesday told the US House Judiciary Committee that suspect Thomas Crooks visited the Trump rally site in Butler, Pennsylvania, twice before he clambered onto the roof of a nearby building on July 13 and fired off at least eight rounds, wounding Trump in the ear, killing one rally-goer and injuring two others.\n\n\"Analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6, he did a Google search for -- quote -- 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Mr Wray said.\n\nHe was referring to Lee Harvey Oswald, who assassinated former president Kennedy in Dallas, Texas, on November 22, 1963.\n\n\"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Mr Wray said.\n\n\"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally,\" he added, saying Crooks became \"very focused on president Trump and his rally\" at that point after showing interest in public figures more generally.\n\nAbout two hours before the shooting, Crooks flew a drone over the area about 180 metres from the stage where Trump spoke to the crowd, and live-streamed footage for about 11 minutes.\n\nLaw enforcement officers did not spot Crooks on the roof with his AR-15-style rifle until \"seconds\" before he opened fire, said Mr Wray, noting that the timeline could change as the investigators' understanding of facts evolves.\n\n\"It's all happening in seconds,\" Mr Wray said. He added that the rifle had a collapsible stock, \"which could explain why it might have been less easy for people to observe.\"\n\nCrude explosive devices later recovered from Crooks' car and home were designed to be detonated remotely. Crooks had a transmitter with him, Wray added. But he said the FBI believes the suspect would not have been successful had he tried to detonate the devices.\n\nThe motive for the shooting remains unclear. Mr Wray said many people have described Crooks as a loner and the list of contacts in his phone was short.\n\nThe hearing also focused on the increasingly tense political atmosphere surrounding the presidential campaign.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated-threat environment. And tragically, the ... assassination attempt is another example, particularly heinous,\" Mr Wray testified.\n\nA day before Mr Wray's testimony, Kimberly Cheatle resigned as director of the US Secret Service after bipartisan demands to quit over the failure to prevent the attempted assassination.\n\nJudiciary Committee chairman Jim Jordan welcomed Mr Wray's willingness to share details about the FBI investigation into the assassination attempt.\n\nBut he also cited skepticism toward the FBI that exists among some Republicans, who are angry about the arrest of Trump supporters who stormed the US Capitol on January 6, 2021, as Congress certified President Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.\n\n\"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation,\" Mr Jordan said.\n\nRepresentative Jerrold Nadler, the panel's top Democrat, condemned the Trump shooting \"unequivocally and unabashedly\" but pointed to years of political threats and violence, and violent rhetoric from Republicans including Trump himself.\n\n\"If you think that this one assassin's bullet was a bolt out of the blue, and not part of a wave of violence that has threatened this nation for years, then you have missed the point,\" Mr Nadler said.", "source": {"uri": "abc.net.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Australian Broadcasting Corporation"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Thomas Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. {"uri": "8241688549", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:21:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:21:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:20:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/fbi-director-trump-shooter-did-online-search-for-jfk-assassination/article_f7d6b134-1903-589e-acdd-d9f7411f3ddd.html", "title": "FBI director: Trump shooter did online search for JFK assassination", "body": "WASHINGTON (Reuters) - The 20-year-old man suspected of trying to kill former President Donald Trump conducted an online search of the John F. Kennedy assassination on the day he registered for Trump's rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, FBI Director Christopher Wray said on Wednesday.\n\n\"Analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6, he did a Google search for -quote - 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Wray said in testimony before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\n\"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally,\" he said, adding that suspect Thomas Crooks had become \"very focused on President Trump and his rally\" at the time.\n\nFormer President Kennedy was assassinated in Dallas, Texas, on Nov. 22, 1963, by Lee Harvey Oswald.\n\nWray said Crooks, a nursing home aide, fired at least eight rounds from his rooftop position near the July 13 rally, wounding the Republican presidential candidate in the ear, killing one rally attendee and wounding two others.\n\nCrooks used an AR-15 assault-style rifle with a collapsible stock, \"which could explain why it might have been less easy for people to observe,\" Wray said.\n\nThe motive for the shooting remains unclear. Wray said many people have described Crooks as a loner and the list of contacts in his phone was short.\n\nWray also told lawmakers that Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the stage where Trump spoke to the crowd and live-streamed footage for about 11 minutes, some two hours before the event.\n\nHe said the crude explosive devices recovered from Crooks' car and home were designed to be detonated remotely. Crooks had a transmitter with him at the time of the shooting, Wray added. But he said the FBI believes the suspect would not have been successful had he tried to detonate the devices.\n\nThe hearing also focused on the increasingly tense political atmosphere surrounding the presidential campaign.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated-threat environment. And tragically, the ... assassination attempt is another example, particularly heinous,\" Wray testified.\n\nKimberly Cheatle resigned as director of the U.S. Secret Service on Tuesday after bipartisan demands to quit over the failure to prevent the attempted assassination.\n\nJudiciary Committee Chairman Jim Jordan said he expected Wray to answer questions about what happened before, during and after the incident but expressed doubt about the FBI director's answers even before questioning began.\n\n\"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation,\" Jordan said.\n\nRepresentative Jerrold Nadler, the panel's top Democrat, condemned the Trump shooting \"unequivocally and unabashedly\" but pointed to years of political threats and violence, and violent rhetoric from Republicans including Trump himself.\n\n\"If you think that this one assassin's bullet was a bolt out of the blue, and not part of a wave of violence that has threatened this nation for years, then you have missed the point,\" the New York Democrat said.\n\nWray has long faced opposition from hardline Republicans, some angered over the arrest of Trump supporters who stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, as Congress certified President Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan and Sarah N. Lynch; Editing by Scott Malone, Alistair Bell, Nick Zieminski and Rod Nickel)\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE GAZETTE", "source": {"uri": "gazette.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Colorado Springs Gazette"}, "authors": [{"uri": "sarah_n_lynch@gazette.com", "name": "Sarah N. {"uri": "8241673125", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:10:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:10:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:09:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://tucson.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/trump-rally-gunman-looked-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_b9816f22-c70f-509f-83c1-71d70932f531.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nElections Secret Service director steps down after assassination attempt against Trump By COLLEEN LONG The Associated Press\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nPeople are also reading... Lake Powell reaches highest level in more than 3 years Furniture and electronics store closing Tucson locations 46-year-old man shot to death at east side Tucson gas station Buyers of Ram diesel pickups were defrauded, Arizona attorney general says Storm damage seeds debate about Tucson's tree choices Court rejects requiring citizenship proof for some AZ voters in presidential race Woman held against will dies after jump from moving car chased by Pima deputies Two Democrats vie in primary for Pima County treasurer nomination 50 fun events happening in Tucson this weekend July 18-21 \ud83c\udf05\ud83c\udfac Global system IT outage forces closure of Tucson health clinics, urgent cares U of A quietly drops unpopular 'UArizona' moniker U.S. authorities plan to relocate endangered wolves spotted near Flagstaff Woman who died after jumping from car is identified Reggae star Ziggy Marley heading to Tucson Tucson Sen. Justine Wadsack clocked at 71 mph on Speedway, police say\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said that Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. The use of the drone so close the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nElections GOP threatened to sue over November ballot if Biden dropped out. Experts call that 'ridiculous' ROBERT YOON Associated Press\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, when Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle,\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally\n\nSubscribe to stay connected to Tucson. {"uri": "8241704471", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:33:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:33:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:32:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.npr.org/2024/07/24/g-s1-13130/fbi-director-gunman-rally-trump-jfk-assassination", "title": "FBI director says gunman at Trump rally searched for info on JFK assassination", "body": "The gunman who attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump conducted an online search a week before the shooting about the killing of former President John F. Kennedy, the FBI director said Wednesday.\n\nTestifying before the House Judiciary Committee, Christopher Wray gave lawmakers an update on the investigation into the July 13 shooting targeting Trump at a rally in Butler, Pa. That includes information pulled from a computer linked to the 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Crooks, that suggests he spent at least a week planning the attack.\n\n\"An analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6 he did a Google search for 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?'\" Wray said. \"That's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally.\"\n\nLee Harvey Oswald is the gunman who shot former President John F. Kennedy in Dallas, Texas, in 1963.\n\nWray's testimony comes 11 days after the attempt on Trump's life. He said the FBI still has found no indication of a motive or political ideology for Crooks, but he did fill in some of the details about him and the timeline ahead of the shooting.\n\nInvestigators believe Crooks visited the site of the Butler rally on three occasions, Wray said.\n\nThe first time was a week before the event, when he spent roughly 20 minutes there. The second time was the morning of the Trump rally, when he appears to have been on site for roughly 70 minutes, Wray said. The third time was later that afternoon, a few hours before the event -- and he never left.\n\nDuring that last visit, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone at the rally grounds for 11 minutes around 4 p.m., about 200 yards from the stage. Investigators recovered the drone in the gunman's vehicle along with its controller. They have been able to reverse engineer the device's flight path, Wray said, but they don't know exactly what Crooks was able to see or why.\n\nWray also discussed the three explosive devices that investigators recovered: two from Crooks' vehicle and one at his residence. Wray described the devices as \"relatively crude,\" but said they did have the ability to be detonated remotely.\n\nA transmitter was found on Crooks' body, he said, but it appears that the receivers on the explosive devices were not turned on so he wouldn't have been able to detonate them.", "source": {"uri": "npr.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "NPR"}, "authors": [{"uri": "ryan_lucas@npr.org", "name": "Ryan Lucas", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Thomas Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241845759", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:31:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:31:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:29:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/gunman-searched-online-about-jfk-shooting-before-trump-attack-fbi-chief/article_6ddf9aa7-90e7-5625-bef4-c8d8b64b6439.html", "title": "Gunman searched online about JFK shooting before Trump attack: FBI chief", "body": "Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump is evacuated from a rally by Secret Service agents after an assassination attempt in Butler, Pennsylvania, on July 13, 2024\n\nThe gunman who attempted to assassinate Donald Trump at a campaign rally searched online for details about the November 1963 shooting of US president John F. Kennedy in the days before the attack, the FBI director said Wednesday.\n\nFBI chief Christopher Wray, testifying before a congressional committee, also said the gunman flew a drone over the area where the former president was scheduled to speak about two hours before he took the stage.\n\nWray told members of the House Judiciary Committee that investigators \"do not yet have a clear picture of his motive\" for the July 13 shooting but \"we are digging hard because this is one of the central questions for us.\"\n\nHe said the gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, \"appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures, in general\" but \"there doesn't seem to be a whole lot of rhyme or reason to it so far.\"\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" he said.\n\n\"Starting somewhere around July 6 or so, he became very focused on former president Trump and this rally,\" Wray said, and he registered that same day to attend the campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for, quote, 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?'\" he said, a reference to Kennedy's assassination by Lee Harvey Oswald.\n\n\"So that's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind.\"\n\nThe FBI director said there is no evidence \"so far\" that Crooks had any accomplices or co-conspirators.\n\nCrooks opened fire on Trump with an AR-style assault rifle shortly after 6:00 pm as the Republican White House candidate was addressing the campaign rally.\n\nCrooks, who was perched on the roof of a nearby building, was shot dead by a Secret Service sniper less than 30 seconds after firing his first shots.\n\nTrump was wounded in the ear, two rally attendees were seriously injured and a 50-year-old Pennsylvania firefighter was shot dead.\n\nUS Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned on Tuesday, a day after acknowledging the agency had failed in its mission to prevent the assassination attempt.\n\nMore from this section Firefighters rescue residents from intense Sunset Park apartment fire; several people injured See the Beverly Hills home of former Victoria's Secret model with infrared sauna, cold plunge Terrifying moment breaching whale attacks boat in ocean - Drone flight -\n\nWray said Crooks flew a drone over the rally area for around 11 minutes -- sometime between 3:50 pm and 4:00 pm -- on the day of the shooting.\n\nHe said it was not flown directly over the stage but some 200 yards (meters) away.\n\nThe drone and its controller were recovered in the gunman's car.\n\nTwo \"relatively crude\" explosive devices were also found in the car along with another at the gunman's residence, Wray said.\n\nThe FBI director said the devices had the ability to be detonated remotely and the gunman had a transmitter with him when he was shot.\n\n\"It looks like, because of the on-off position on the receivers, that that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" he said. \"But that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous.\"\n\nAsked how many shots Crooks fired, Wray said eight cartridges had been recovered on the roof.\n\nHe said the gunman purchased a ladder on the day of the shooting but appears not to have used it. Instead, he climbed onto the roof using some mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping.\n\nWray also said Crooks's AR-style gun had a collapsible stock which may explain why he was not seen by rallygoers or members of law enforcement with the weapon before the shooting.\n\nHe said Crooks visited the rally site on at least three occasions, about a week before the shooting, for about 70 minutes on the morning of the rally and again that afternoon.\n\ncl/sst", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, "authors": [{"uri": "chris_lefkow@reformer.com", "name": "Chris Lefkow", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "2024-07-432405180", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:28:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:28:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:11:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://eu.northjersey.com/story/news/politics/2024/07/24/fbi-christopher-wray-trump-assassination-attempt/74524295007/", "title": "Trump shooter searched JFK's assassin, flew drone over rally area, had explosives in car: FBI director", "body": "WASHINGTON - FBI Director Christopher Wray confirmed Wednesday that the gunman who tried to assassinate former President Donald Trump searched for the distance between former President John F. Kennedy and his assassin when he was shot in 1963.\n\nWray said the shooter at Trump's rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, this month also flew a drone over the area two hours before Trump's campaign speech and had two \"relatively crude\" explosives in his car.\n\nWray revealed to the House Judiciary Committee for the first time that on July 6 the gunman did a Google search for how far assassin Lee Harvey Oswald was from Kennedy. The same day he registered for the Trump rally.\n\n\"That is a search that obviously is significant for his state of mind,\" Wray said.\n\nThe gunman first visited the rally grounds a week before the event for about 20 minutes, Wray said. The shooter then visited the grounds the morning of the rally about 70 minutes and then went back for good in the afternoon, Wray said.\n\nAnother revelation was that the AR-style rifle the shooter used had a collapsible stock, which Wray said may help explain how no one saw the man carrying the gun.\n\n\"We haven't yet found anybody with firsthand observation of him with the weapon walking around beforehand,\" Wray said. \"The collapsible stock could be very significant feature that could be relevant to that.\"\n\nWray said the drone and controller were found in gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks' car. The drone flew about 3:50 p.m. for about 11 minutes, apparently livestreaming over an area about 200 yards from the stage where Trump spoke, Wray said.\n\nThe FBI is studying two explosives in the shooter's car and one in his residence, Wray said. The devices were connected to receivers and Crooks had a receiver with him when he was killed by a Secret Service sniper, but the equipment didn't appear capable of setting off what he called \"relatively crude devices,\" Wray said.\n\nWray said investigators now believe the gunman climbed onto the roof with the help of mechanical equipment on the ground and piping on the side of the building, rather than a ladder.\n\n\"We do not believe he used a ladder to get up there,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI recovered eight cartridges where the gunman was slain, Wray said, suggesting he fired that many shots. The gunman sent encrypted messages before the attack, which Wray said had \"unfortunately become very commonplace\" to thwart law enforcement.\n\nThe chair of the House Judiciary Committee, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, said lawmakers want to know more about why Trump's campaign team was denied extra security in the weeks before the rally, why buildings weren't secured at the rally and why Trump was allowed on stage despite the presence of a suspicious person seen by the crowd with a range-finder.\n\nJordan focused on five minutes between 6:09 p.m., when the gunman was identified and 6:14 p.m., when Trump was led wounded from the stage.\n\n\"We need to know what happened play by play, moment by moment, second by second - communications that took place - during that critical five minutes,\" Jordan said.\n\nGunman's pictures of Trump, Biden not necessarily from specific searches: FBI\n\nRep. Zoe Lofgren, D-Calif., asked whether pictures of political figures such as Trump, President Joe Biden and others were found on the gunman's phone.\n\nWray said investigators haven't found a manifesto or obvious motive for the shooter. He said pictures were saved in the cache of his electronics from news searches, rather than necessarily because of a specific search for a public official.\n\n\"There is a whole lot of work under way and still a lot of work left to do,\" Wray said. \"We're going to leave no stone unturned. The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing.\"\n\nWray testimony follows resignation of Secret Service chief\n\nWray's testimony came a day after former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned over what she acknowledged was a \"colossal failure\" to protect Trump at a rally July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nThe House Oversight and Accountability Committee excoriated Cheatle during a hearing Monday for having no explanation for how a gunman was able to climb onto the roof of a building within 150 yards of the former president and fire eight shots, one of which hit Trump in the ear. One rally attendee was killed.\n\nWray, a Trump appointee, has been criticized by some Republicans angered over the arrest of Trump supporters who stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, as Congress certified President Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.", "source": {"uri": "northjersey.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "North Jersey"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Assassination"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "2024-07-432522517", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:04:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:04:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:24:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://www.ccenterdispatch.com/news/national/article_e5ac22c5-6c97-572f-8cf3-1d7cf22704ee.html", "title": "FBI director grilled over assassination attempt investigation", "body": "(The Center Square) - Members of Congress grilled FBI Director Christopher Wray Wednesday over details of the FBI's investigation into the assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump.\n\nWray's testimony at a House Judiciary Committee hearing comes as the FBI faces criticism over unanswered questions surrounding the agency's handling of the ongoing investigation into the recent shooting at a Trump campaign rally earlier this month.\n\nThe Secret Service has also come under fire for the security issues surrounding the rally shooting.\n\nFormer Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle on Tuesday stepped down from her post after calls for her resignation, as The Center Square previously reported.\n\nJudiciary Committee Chairman Jim Jordan questioned Wray on many of the details leading up to the attempted assassination.\n\n\"Why was the president allowed to walk out on stage when there was a suspicious person on the property?\" Jordan asked.\n\n\"We need to know what happened play by play, moment by moment, second by second,\" Jordan added.\n\nJordan went on to say that Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas was \"lying to the American people\" with his prior comments about security failures. The Secret Service is part of the Department of Homeland Security.\n\nWray slammed political violence during his opening statements.\n\n\"We will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind,\" Wray said. \"Especially a despicable account of this magnitude.\"\n\n\"We are going to leave no stone unturned,\" Wray added when discussing the investigation.\n\n\"The attempted assassination of the former President was an attack on our democracy,\" Wray said.\n\nWray went on to mention the United States being under an environment of \"heightened threat\" at several points during his testimony.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in a heightened threat environment,\" Wray said.\n\nU.S. Rep. Dan Bishop asked about reports of an unmanned aerial surveillance drone at the Trump rally.\n\nWray said that the FBI found a drone and controller in the shooter's vehicle as well as explosive devices. Wray called the three explosive devices that the FBI recovered in the shooter's car \"relatively crude.\"\n\nWray acknowledged that the shooter had a drone and said that the FBI thinks that he was \"live-streaming\" and \"viewing the footage\" for several minutes before the shooting.\n\nU.S. Rep. Jerry Nadler asked Wray for his response to people calling for the defunding of the FBI.\n\n\"Cutting our funding is incredibly shortsighted,\" Wray said.\n\nThe question of any possible motives from the shooter leading up to the assassination attempt against Trump came up several times during the hearing.\n\n\"I think it's fair to say that we do not yet have a clear picture of his motive,\" Wray said in response.\n\nWray said that the shooter is thought to have visited the surrounding area three separate times leading up to the rally after Jordan asked him about it.\n\nWray revealed that the shooter did a \"Google search for how far away was [Lee Harvey] Oswald from [the late President John F.] Kennedy\" on July 6. Wray added that that was the same day that the shooter registered to attend the Trump campaign rally.\n\nWray said that the shooter seemed interested in images of various public officials and public figures who \"cover both parties\" and added that the FBI is still trying to \"grill into that\" amidst their ongoing investigation.\n\nMany members of the Judiciary Committee denounced acts of political violence at several points throughout the hearing.\n\n\"In America violence has never been the answer,\" Rep.
