{"uri": "8241834697", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:21:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:21:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:19:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/trump-rally-shooter-searched-online-191335482.html", "title": "Trump Rally Shooter Searched Online About JFK Assassination Days Before Attack", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray revealed the search while testifying in front of the House Judiciary Committee\n\nThe man who attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump at a July 13 campaign rally in Pennsylvania searched on Google about the assassination of John F. Kennedy days prior to the shooting.\n\nThe information was revealed by FBI Director Christopher Wray, who testified at a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Wednesday, July 24.\n\n\"Analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6, he did a Google search for, quote, 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Wray testified, in a hearing aired by C-SPAN.\n\nThe shooter, identified as Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, was killed by Secret Service agents after firing several shots toward Trump, who was speaking on stage, from a building outside the venue in Butler, Pa..\n\nTrump, whose ear was bleeding in the aftermath of the shooting, was evacuated safely from the scene. One person in the audience was killed, while two others were seriously injured.\n\nRelated: What to Know About Thomas Matthew Crooks, Shooter Who Opened Fire at Donald Trump Rally\n\nAccording to Wray's testimony, Crooks registered to attend the rally on the same day he made the search about the Kennedy assassination.\n\nWray also testified that Crooks had a drone in his vehicle at the time of the shooting. About two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks had flown the drone in the area of the venue.\n\nThe FBI director was asked then about explosive devices found in the shooter's vehicle and home.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.\n\n\"[The explosive devices] did have the ability to detonate remotely,\" Wray testified, though he added that the investigation currently indicates that had Crooks attempted to detonate them from the roof, he would have been unsuccessful based on the \"on-off position of the receivers.\"\n\n\"But that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous,\" Wray said.\n\nCrooks graduated from Bethel Park High School in 2022 in Bethel Park, Pa., about 50 miles from Butler.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241764199", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:18:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:18:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:17:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://gizmodo.com/trump-shooter-used-drone-like-a-rearview-mirror-before-assassination-attempt-2000478514", "title": "Trump Shooter Used Drone Like a 'Rearview Mirror' Before Rally", "body": "The shooter also googled \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" before trying to kill Trump.\n\nThomas Matthew Crooks, the 20-year-old man who tried to kill Donald Trump at a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania on July 13, used a drone before the rally \"like a rearview mirror\" and googled facts about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy, according to new testimony Wednesday from FBI director Christopher Wray.\n\nThe drone was found in the car Crooks used to get to the Trump rally, and while there aren't any known photos or videos of the drone from that day, according to Wray, the FBI was able to reverse engineer the flight path. Crooks flew the drone for about 10 minutes, from about 3:50 p.m. to 4:00 p.m., Wray said, about 200 yards away from where Trump would ultimately be speaking. Trump ultimately took the stage at 6:03 p.m. and the first shot was fired at 6:11 p.m., according to CBS News.\n\nRep. Andy Biggs, a Republican from Arizona, asked about the FBI's discovery that Crooks had used a drone and what he may have been observing in the lead-up to the shooting. Wray explained that since it wasn't used during the actual shooting, it was more about observing his surroundings before the shooting.\n\n\"It's almost like giving him a rearview mirror of the scene behind him except, again, he wasn't flying it overhead while he was later back for the assassination,\" Wray said.\n\nBut Wray acknowledged that it's taking some work to figure it all out. And they're speculating that perhaps Crooks was even livestreaming the video captured by the drone.\n\n\"We're still trying to figure out exactly what he saw because we're having to, in effect... because there's no recording of what he saw during those 11 minutes, you know, our hypothesis at this point the experts think he would have been livestreaming it,\" Wray said.\n\nWray explained that the FBI has cracked some of the electronic devices used by Crooks, though \"not all of them,\" and that's how they're gleaning information about his internet activity. \"Some of them we're still waiting on, some of them we may never have access to because of the encryption issue,\" Wray said.\n\nCrooks googled \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\", a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the only person officially believed to have shot the president, though there are plenty of conspiracy theories about what actually happened that day in Dallas back in 1963. That fact came out while Wray was being questioned by Rep. Adam Schiff, a Democrat from California. The Google search about Oswald and Kennedy was on July 6, which is the same day that he used his own name to register for the Trump rally online, according to Wray's testimony.\n\nWray also noted the collapsible stock that may have allowed Crooks to conceal the weapon he used. The FBI director said that no first-hand account of Crooks walking around with a weapon has surfaced and the only person who saw the shooter with a gun saw him when he was already on the roof of the building where he took the shots.\n\nWray's testimony at the House Judiciary Committee in Washington D.C. is just the latest information the public is learning about the attempt on the former president's life and the various ways Crooks used technology in his plot to assassinate Trump. The shooting set off a range of conspiracy theories about the potential existence of two shooters or some kind of involvement by the FBI, and this new information about both the drone and Crooks's search history is likely to just produce more wild theories.\n\nIncredibly, some of the conspiracy theories are being floated by Trump-loving members of Congress.\n\n\u00e2\u20ac\u0153I\u00e2\u20ac\u2122m sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI\u00e2\u20ac\u2122s ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation,\" Rep. Jim Jordan, a Republican from Ohio, told Wray.\n\nRep. Victoria Spartz from Indiana even took the opportunity during Wednesday's hearing to suggest the FBI was involved in a false flag against the U.S. Capitol during Donald Trump's coup attempt on January 6, 2021.\n\nAs the Associated Press notes, the hearing was actually scheduled before the assassination attempt on Trump and is just a routine part of congressional oversight of the FBI. {"uri": "8241852144", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:35:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:35:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:35:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://abcnews.go.com/US/trump-shooter-looked-kennedy-assassination-details-fbi-director/story?id=112238228", "title": "Trump shooter looked up Kennedy assassination details, FBI director says", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray testified before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nA week before Thomas Mathew Crooks opened fire on former President Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania, he became \"very focused\" on Trump and the rally, FBI Director Christopher Wray testified before the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday.\n\nCrooks also searched for information on the assassination of President John F. Kennedy in 1963, he said.\n\nWray told Congress in the last few days the FBI has been able to analyze a laptop connected to Crooks.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for quote, 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy?' So that's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray said.\n\nHe added that Crooks had pictures of public figures on his phone, but had \"no rhyme or reason\" to their methodology.\n\nThe FBI director said there is no apparent motive yet for the July 13 assassination attempt.\n\n\"We're hoping to learn more, and we're still exploiting a number of digital devices,\" Wray said.\n\nCrooks went to the site a week before the assassination attempt, he also said.\n\n\"He traveled to the grounds, I think, a week before, he spent roughly 20 minutes there,\" he said. \"Then he went to grounds again on the morning of the event, it appears, for about 17 minutes.\" Crooks went to the site a third time \"for good.\"\n\nCrooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally venue and had it up in the air for about 11 minutes, he testified.\n\n\"We have recovered a drone that the shooter appears to have used,\" Wray said, adding the drone was recovered in the shooter's vehicle.\n\n\"It appears that around 3:50 p.m., 4 o'clock, in that window, on the day of shooting, that the shooter was flying the drone around the area,\" he said.\n\n\"Let me be clear about the area, not over the stage, and that part of the area itself, but I would say about 200 yards, give or take away,\" he said.\n\nWray said it appears the shooter was a \"loner\" and didn't have a lot of contacts in his cell phone.\n\n\"A lot of people describe him as a loner ... that does kind of fit with what we're seeing in his devices. You know, his list of contacts, for example, is very short, compared to what you would normally see from most people ... there doesn't appear to be a whole lot of interaction between him, you know, face to face or digital, with a lot of people,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI has conducted over 400 interviews with \"many more to conduct,\" he said.\n\nIn addition to questions about the assassination attempt against Trump, the FBI director was asked about the threat emanating from the southern U.S. border.\n\nOver the past five or six years, the number of known or suspected terrorists encountered along the southern border \"has increased,\" and \"that should be of concern,\" Wray testified.\n\nHe also said that it doesn't take a lot of foreign terrorists to be a \"real problem.\"\n\n\"I am increasingly concerned that foreign terrorists could seek to exploit vulnerabilities at our Southwest border or at other ports of entry or in other aspects of our immigration system to facilitate an attack here in the United States. I think that is something we have to be concerned about,\" he said.\n\nWray also said the Russians are continuing attempts to \"influence\" and \"in various ways interfere with our democracy.\"\n\n\"In fact, just in the last few weeks, we announced a significant disruption of a generative AI, enhanced social media and a bot farm, essentially of the Russians that was designed, designed to be an influence operation, and some of the fake, fictitious profiles of those bots purported to be US persons, so they're still at it,\" Wray said.", "source": {"uri": "abcnews.go.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ABC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. {"uri": "8241743279", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:04:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:04:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:03:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/fbi-director-says-trump-shooter-searched-details-of-lee-harvey-oswald-and-jfk-assassination-5692952", "title": "FBI Director Says Trump Shooter Searched Details of Lee Harvey Oswald and JFK Assassination", "body": "Would-be Trump assassin Thomas Matthew Crooks searched for details about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy as well as how far Lee Harvey Oswald positioned himself from his target, said FBI Director Christopher Wray on Wednesday.\n\nAfter an FBI analysis of Mr. Crooks's laptop, according to Mr. Wray, it was determined that the suspected gunman searched for how far Mr. Oswald was from President Kennedy during the 1963 assassination. Mr. Crooks carried out the Google search on July 6, the same day the Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, was announced, the FBI director told members of the House Judiciary Committee.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for: 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Mr. Wray told the House panel.\n\n\"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" the FBI director said. \"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally.\"\n\nThe FBI has said that it is investigating the shooting as both an attempted assassination and also opened up a domestic terrorism investigation in connection to the shooting, which injured former President Donald Trump's right ear, killed one rally attendee, and injured two others.\n\nWhen asked about whether Mr. Crooks, 20, acted alone, Mr. Wray said there was no indication of any co-conspirators. The FBI also has not established a motive for the shooting suspect, he said.\n\nHowever, he cautioned that, \"It is, quite frankly, a dangerous time to be a prominent public official.\"\n\n\"I have been saying some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment,\" Mr. Wray said. \"The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is ongoing.\"\n\nMr. Wray said that reports Mr. Crooks was searching for images of public officials online may have been related to his searches of news articles.\n\n\"The shooter appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures in general, but so far we are seeing kind of news articles and things like that,\" he said.\n\n\"So the images that have been reported about, really what we are talking about there are when you do a news search of an article the image appears in a cache as opposed to like a search for that specific individual.\"\n\nOther new details provided by Mr. Wray included details about a drone that was used by Mr. Crooks. {"uri": "8241695540", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:27:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:27:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:26:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.fox28spokane.com/gunman-flew-drone-over-trump-rally-area-before-shooting-fbi-chief/", "title": "Gunman flew drone over Trump rally area before shooting: FBI chief | FOX 28 Spokane", "body": "The 20-year-old gunman who attempted to assassinate Donald Trump at a campaign rally flew a drone over the area about two hours before the former US president began to speak, the FBI director said Wednesday.\n\nFBI chief Christopher Wray, testifying before a congressional committee, also said the investigation into the July 13 shooting had not yet revealed a motive for the gunman.\n\nThomas Matthew Crooks opened fire on Trump with an AR-style assault rifle shortly after 6:00 pm as the Republican White House candidate was addressing a campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nCrooks, who was perched on the roof of a nearby building, was shot dead by a Secret Service sniper less than 30 seconds after firing his first shots.\n\nTrump was wounded in the ear, two rally attendees were seriously injured and a 50-year-old Pennsylvania firefighter was shot dead.\n\nUS Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned on Tuesday, a day after acknowledging that the agency had failed in its mission to prevent the assassination attempt.\n\nWray said Crooks flew a drone over the rally area for around 11 minutes -- between around 3:50 pm and 4:00 pm -- on the day of the shooting some 200 yards (meters) away from the stage where Trump was scheduled to speak.\n\nThe drone and its controller were recovered in the gunman's car.\n\nTwo \"relatively crude\" explosive devices were also found in the car along with another at the gunman's residence, Wray said.\n\nThe FBI director said the devices had the ability to be detonated remotely and the gunman had a transmitter with him when he was shot.\n\n\"It looks like, because of the on-off position on the receivers, that that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" he said. \"But that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous.\"\n\nAsked how many shots Crooks fired, Wray said eight cartridges had been recovered on the roof.\n\n- No clear motive -\n\nWray told members of the House Judiciary Committee that investigators \"do not yet have a clear picture of his motive.\"\n\n\"We're not seeing that yet, but we are digging hard, because this is one of the central questions for us,\" the FBI chief said.\n\nHe said the gunman \"appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures, in general\" but \"there doesn't seem to be a whole lot of rhyme or reason to it so far.\"\n\n\"Sarting somewhere around July 6 or so, he became very focused on former president Trump and this rally,\" Wray said.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for quote, 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?'\" he said, a reference to the 1963 assassination of president John F. Kennedy by Lee Harvey Oswald.\n\nThere is no evidence at this time that Crooks had any accomplices or co-conspirators, the FBI chief said.\n\ncl/des\n\nFOX28 Spokane\u00a9", "source": {"uri": "fox28spokane.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "FOX 28 Spokane"}, "authors": [{"uri": "agence_france_presse@fox28spokane.com", "name": "Agence France-Presse", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Unmanned aerial vehicle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secret_Service", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "United States Secret Service"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241844471", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:29:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:29:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:28:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/donald-trumps-would-be-assassin-googled-how-far-away-was-oswald-from-kennedy-6445537-Jul2024/", "title": "Trump's would-be assassin Googled 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?' in days before shooting", "body": "The gunman also flew a drone over the area where the former president was scheduled to speak about two hours before he took the stage.\n\nTHE GUNMAN WHO attempted to assassinate Donald Trump at a campaign rally searched online for details about the November 1963 shooting of US president John F. Kennedy in the days before the attack, the FBI director said today.\n\nFBI chief Christopher Wray, testifying before a congressional committee, also said the gunman flew a drone over the area where the former president was scheduled to speak about two hours before he took the stage.\n\nWray told members of the House Judiciary Committee that investigators \"do not yet have a clear picture of his motive\" for the 13 July shooting but \"we are digging hard because this is one of the central questions for us.\"\n\nHe said the gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, \"appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures, in general\" but \"there doesn't seem to be a whole lot of rhyme or reason to it so far.\"\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" he said.\n\n\"Starting somewhere around 6 July or so, he became very focused on former president Trump and this rally,\" Wray said, and he registered that same day to attend the campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"On 6 July, he did a Google search for, quote, 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?'\" Wray said, a reference to Kennedy's assassination by Lee Harvey Oswald.\n\n\"So that's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind.\"\n\nChristopher Wray sworn in to the House Judiciary Committee hearing titled 'Oversight of the Federal Bureau of Investigation' today Alamy Stock Photo Alamy Stock Photo\n\nThe FBI director said there is no evidence \"so far\" that Crooks had any accomplices or perched on the roof of a nearby building, was shot dead by a Secret Service sniper less than 30 seconds after firing his first shots.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTrump was wounded in the ear, two rally attendees were seriously injured and a 50-year-old Pennsylvania firefighter was shot dead.\n\nUS Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned yesterday, a day after acknowledging the agency had failed in its mission to prevent the assassination attempt.\n\nDrone flight\n\nWray said Crooks flew a drone over the rally area for around 11 minutes - sometime between 3:50 pm and 4:00 pm - on the day of the shooting.\n\nHe said it was not flown directly over the stage but some 200 meters away.\n\nThe drone and its controller were recovered in the gunman's car.\n\nTwo \"relatively crude\" explosive devices were also found in the car along with another at the gunman's residence, Wray said.\n\nLaw enforcement officers gather at campaign rally site after assassination attempt on Trump. Alamy Stock Photo Alamy Stock Photo\n\nThe FBI director said the devices had the ability to be detonated remotely and the gunman had a transmitter with him when he was shot.\n\n\"It looks like, because of the on-off position on the receivers, that that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" he said. \"But that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous.\"\n\nAsked how many shots Crooks fired, Wray said eight cartridges had been recovered on the roof.\n\nHe said the gunman purchased a ladder on the day of the shooting but appears not to have used it. {"uri": "8241875280", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:03:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:03:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:57:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/fbi-director-reveals-details-trump-194837008.html", "title": "FBI director reveals new details on how Trump shooter carried out attack", "body": "The gunman who tried to assassinate former President Donald Trump may have had a firearm with a collapsible stock, making it easier for him to carry and conceal the weapon, the director of the FBI testified Wednesday.\n\nThe gunman also had researched President John F. Kennedy's assassination, FBI Director Christopher Wray said.\n\nOn July 6, Thomas Crooks, 20, searched \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" Wray told a House Judiciary Committee hearing, referring to the 1963 assassination.\n\nThe collapsible stock, Wray said, would explain why witnesses did not see Crooks walking around with a weapon beforehand and why the firearm was not spotted until Crooks was already on the roof.\n\nCrooks fired at least eight shots and also flew a drone about 200 yards away from the campaign rally's main stage area in Butler, Pennsylvania, about two hours before it began on July 13, Wray said.\n\nHe began to shoot seconds after he noticed a local law enforcement officer on the ground had spotted him, Wray said.\n\nThe officer had gotten a boost from a colleague and pulled his head up over the roof. Crooks pointed his gun at the officer, causing him to fall, and then started shooting in Trump's direction, Wray said.\n\nAuthorities recovered the drone in Crooks' car, where they also found a drone controller and two explosive devices that could be remotely detonated, Wray said.\n\nCrooks had a transmitter on him, the director said, adding that it appears the remote detonation \"would not have worked.\"\n\nEight bullet cartridges were found on the roof with the gunman's body, he said.\n\nWray said Crooks had purchased a ladder, about 5-foot tall, according to a bloodied receipt that he had on him, but the ladder was not found at the scene. The FBI director said it is unclear how Crooks got onto the roof.\n\nCrooks was a \"fairly avid shooting hobbyist,\" who went to a shooting range the day before the assassination attempt, \"probably\" with the same AR-style rifle he used at the rally, Wray said.\n\nLawmakers say key questions surrounding the shooting remain unanswered, particularly by Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned as director of the Secret Service on Tuesday after Republicans accused her of failing to fully cooperate with the House Oversight Committee in testimony the day before.\n\n\"We need to know play-by-play, moment-by-moment, second-by-second,\" Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray on Wednesday at the start of the hearing.\n\nThe congressional committee hearings this week have begun to yield more information on the shooting and how Crooks evaded law enforcement.\n\nOn Tuesday, Pennsylvania State Police Col. Christopher Paris told the House Homeland Security Committee that officers with the Butler County Emergency Services Unit had spotted Crooks from a second-story window and left their post to search for him.\n\nParis said Crooks was identified as suspicious before the shooting because he was hanging around but never attempted to enter the rally. That suspicion was later heightened, Paris said, when Crooks was seen with a rangefinder.\n\nThat day, three other people had been identified as suspicious, the state police commissioner said.\n\nCrooks was not designated as an actual threat until seconds before he opened fire, Paris said. {"uri": "2024-07-432517342", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:56:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:56:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:39:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/gunman-searched-online-about-jfk-shooting-before-trump-attack-fbi-chief/article_140ff490-0319-5079-b389-a2b950197b82.html", "title": "Gunman searched online about JFK shooting before Trump attack: FBI chief", "body": "The gunman who attempted to assassinate Donald Trump at a campaign rally searched online for details about the November 1963 shooting of US president John F. Kennedy in the days before the attack, the FBI director said Wednesday.\n\nFBI chief Christopher Wray, testifying before a congressional committee, also said the gunman flew a drone over the area where the former president was scheduled to speak about two hours before he took the stage.\n\nWray told members of the House Judiciary Committee that investigators \"do not yet have a clear picture of his motive\" for the July 13 shooting but \"we are digging hard because this is one of the central questions for us.\"\n\nHe said the gunman, Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, \"appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures, in general\" but \"there doesn't seem to be a whole lot of rhyme or reason to it so far.\"\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" he said.\n\n\"Starting somewhere around July 6 or so, he became very focused on former president Trump and this rally,\" Wray said, and he registered that same day to attend the campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for, quote, 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?'\" he said, a reference to Kennedy's assassination by Lee Harvey Oswald.\n\n\"So that's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind.\"\n\nThe FBI director said there is no evidence \"so far\" that Crooks had any accomplices or co-conspirators.\n\nCrooks opened fire on Trump with an AR-style assault rifle shortly after 6:00 pm as the Republican White House candidate was addressing the campaign rally.\n\nCrooks, who was perched on the roof of a nearby building, was shot dead by a Secret Service sniper less than 30 seconds after firing his first shots.\n\nTrump was wounded in the ear, two rally attendees were seriously injured and a 50-year-old Pennsylvania firefighter was shot dead.\n\nUS Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned on Tuesday, a day after acknowledging the agency had failed in its mission to prevent the assassination attempt.\n\n- Drone flight -\n\nWray said Crooks flew a drone over the rally area for around 11 minutes -- sometime between 3:50 pm and 4:00 pm -- on the day of the shooting.\n\nHe said it was not flown directly over the stage but some 200 yards (meters) away.\n\nThe drone and its controller were recovered in the gunman's car.\n\nTwo \"relatively crude\" explosive devices were also found in the car along with another at the gunman's residence, Wray said.\n\nThe FBI director said the devices had the ability to be detonated remotely and the gunman had a transmitter with him when he was shot.\n\n\"It looks like, because of the on-off position on the receivers, that that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" he said. \"But that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous.\"\n\nAsked how many shots Crooks fired, Wray said eight cartridges had been recovered on the roof.\n\nHe said the gunman purchased a ladder on the day of the shooting but appears not to have used it. Instead, he climbed onto the roof using some mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping.\n\nWray also said Crooks's AR-style gun had a collapsible stock which may explain why he was not seen by rallygoers or members of law enforcement with the weapon before the shooting.\n\nHe said Crooks visited the rally site on at least three occasions, about a week before the shooting, for about 70 minutes on the morning of the rally and again that afternoon.\n\ncl/sst\n\nMore from this section\n\niMyFone VoxBox TTS Voice AI Launches Video Dubbing Feature\n\nOptimal Blue Launches New Generative AI Assistant Capabilities\n\nExodus United Global Signs Multi-Year Agreement to Bring Indian Films and TV shows to the U.S.", "source": {"uri": "kulr8.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "KULR-8 Local News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241945827", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:59:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:59:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:59:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.rt.com/news/601609-trump-shooter-jfk-fbi/", "title": "Trump shooter studied JFK assassination - FBI  --  RT World News", "body": "Would-be assassin Thomas Michael Crooks researched the assassination of John F Kennedy before opening fire on former President Donald Trump earlier this month, FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nCrooks shot Trump in the ear during a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania on July 13. Firing from a rooftop that Trump's Secret Service detail had inexplicably left unguarded, the 20-year-old gunman killed one person in the audience and injured two others before Secret Service snipers shot him dead.\n\nTestifying before the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, Wray said that an FBI examination of Crooks' computer revealed that he began researching the JFK assassination on July 6, the same day he registered to attend the Trump rally.\n\n\"He did a Google search for - quote - 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy',\" Wray said, referring to Lee Harvey Oswald, the gunman accused of shooting Kennedy in 1963.\n\n\"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray said, adding that Crooks had become \"very focused on President Trump and his rally\" at the time.\n\nWray's testimony shed little light on Crooks' motivation. The FBI chief insisted that the shooter was not in contact with any accomplices or co-conspirators, and did not speculate about his political leanings. Before becoming fixated on Trump, Crooks did \"a lot of searches of public figures in general,\" Wray said, warning that \"it is, quite frankly, a dangerous time to be a prominent public official.\"\n\nWray did not comment on how many Secret Service snipers were present at the rally, nor did he comment on allegations that the agency had pulled some staff from Trump's detail before the event. Wray did, however, reveal that Crooks visited the site in Butler on three occasions, and on the day of the rally \"was flying the drone around the area\" just two hours before Trump took to the stage.\n\nRepublicans have fiercely criticized the Secret Service for failing to secure Crooks' rooftop vantage point, despite it being around 150 meters from the stage, and for apparently disregarding reports of an armed Crooks crawling around on the roof minutes before opening fire.\n\nSecret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned on Tuesday, a day after telling the Oversight Committee that she took responsibility for the \"most significant operational failure at the Secret Service in decades.\"", "source": {"uri": "rt.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "RT"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8242068229", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:16:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:16:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T23:15:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.jamaicaobserver.com/2024/07/24/trump-attack-gunman-searched-online-jfk-shooting-fbi-chief/", "title": "Trump attack gunman searched online about JFK shooting: FBI chief - Jamaica Observer", "body": "WASHINGTON, United States (AFP) -- The gunman who attempted to assassinate Donald Trump at a campaign rally searched online for details about the November 1963 shooting of US president John F. Kennedy in the days before the attack, the FBI director said Wednesday.\n\nFBI chief Christopher Wray, testifying before a congressional committee, said the gunman flew a drone over the venue where the former president was scheduled to speak about two hours before he took the stage in Butler, Pennsylvania, on July 13.\n\nWray told members of the House Judiciary Committee that investigators have not established a motive for the shooting but \"we are digging hard because this is one of the central questions for us.\"\n\nTrump survived the assassination bid, suffering a wound to his right ear, and a Secret Service sniper shot dead the suspected gunman -- named as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks -- less than 30 seconds after he had fired eight shots.\n\n\"With respect to former president Trump, there's some question about whether or not it's a bullet or shrapnel that, you know, that hit his ear,\" FBI chief Wray said.\n\nTwo rally attendees were seriously injured and a 50-year-old Pennsylvania firefighter was shot dead.\n\nWray said Crooks \"appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures, in general\" but that there was no clear pattern to the research.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" he said.\n\n\"Starting somewhere around July 6 or so, he became very focused on former president Trump and this rally,\" the FBI chief said, and he registered that same day to attend the campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for, quote, 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?'\" he said, a reference to Kennedy's assassination by Lee Harvey Oswald.\n\n\"That obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind.\"\n\nThe FBI director said no evidence has emerged so far that Crooks had any accomplices or co-conspirators and he seems to have been a \"loner.\"\n\nCrooks was perched on the roof of a nearby building and opened fire on Trump {"uri": "8241851167", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:34:50", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:34:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:33:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.ktbs.com/news/national/fbi-director-grilled-over-assassination-attempt-investigation/article_61753a67-074d-5809-88a9-7380004b2fe8.html", "title": "FBI director grilled over assassination attempt investigation", "body": "(The Center Square) - Members of Congress grilled FBI Director Christopher Wray over details of the FBI's investigation into the assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump at a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Wednesday.\n\nWray's testimony comes as the FBI faces criticism over unanswered questions surrounding the agency's handling of the ongoing investigation into the recent shooting at a Trump campaign rally earlier this month.\n\nThe Secret Service has also come under fire for the security issues surrounding the rally shooting.\n\nFormer Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle stepped down from her post after calls for her resignation, as The Center Square previously reported.\n\nChairman Jim Jordan questioned the details of the shooter being allowed onto the premises of the Trump campaign rally.\n\n\"Why was the president allowed to walk out on stage when there was a suspicious person on the property?\" Jordan asked.\n\n\"We need to know what happened play by play, moment by moment, second by second,\" Jordan added\n\nJordan went on to say that Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas was \"lying to the American people.\"\n\nWray slammed political violence during his opening statements.\n\n\"We will no and do not tolerate political violence of any kind,\" Wray said. \"Especially a despicable account of this magnitude.\"\n\n\"We are gonna leave no stone unturned,\" Wray added when discussing the investigation.\n\n\"The attempted assassination of the former President was an attack on our democracy,\" Wray said.\n\nWray went on to mention the United States being under an environment of \"heightened threat\" at several points during his testimony.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in a heightened threat environment,\" Wray said.\n\nRep. Dan Bishop asked about reports of an unmanned aerial surveillance drone at the Trump rally.\n\nWray said that the FBI found a drone and controller in the shooter's vehicle as well as explosive devices. Wray called the three explosive devices that the FBI recovered in the shooter's car \"relatively crude.\"\n\nWray acknowledged that the shooter had a drone and said that the FBI think that he was \"live-streaming\" and \"viewing the footage\" for several minutes before the shooting.\n\nWray went on to denounce political violence in the country, calling it an \"alarming phenomenon.\"\n\nU.S. Rep. Jerry Nadler asked Wray for his response to people calling for the defunding of the FBI.\n\n\"Cutting our funding is incredibly shortsighted,\" Wray said.\n\nThe question of any possible motives from the shooter leading up to the assassination attempt against Trump came up several times during the hearing.\n\n\"I think it's fair to say that we do not yet have a clear picture of his motive,\" Wray said in response.\n\nWray said that the shooter is thought to have visited the surrounding area three separate times leading up to the rally when Jordan asked him about how many times the shooter was at the premises of the Trump rally.\n\nWray revealed that the shooter did a \"Google search for how far away was Oswald from Kennedy\" on July 6. Wray added that that was the same day that the shooter registered to attend the Trump campaign rally.\n\nWray said that the shooter seemed interested in images of various public officials and public figures who \"cover both parties\" and added that the FBI are still trying to \"grill into that\" amidst their ongoing investigation.\n\nMany members of the Judiciary Committee denounced acts of political violence at several points throughout the hearing.\n\n\"In America violence has never been the answer,\" Rep. {"uri": "8241991603", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:47:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:47:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:46:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://matzav.com/fbi-director-wray-testifies-to-congress-about-trump-rally-shooting/", "title": "FBI Director Wray Testifies to Congress about Trump Rally Shooting", "body": "FBI Director Christopher A. Wray told lawmakers on Capitol Hill on Wednesday morning that the assassination attempt against former president Donald Trump was \"despicable,\" and he pledged that investigators would leave \"no stone unturned\" in the case.\n\n\"We are living in an elevated threat environment, and, tragically, the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I have been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\n\"There's a whole lot of work underway and still a lot of work to do,\" he continued. \"The shooter may be deceased, but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing.\"\n\nThe hearing before the House Judiciary Committee was scheduled before the July 13 attempted assassination of Trump at an outdoor campaign rally in Butler, Pa., but that attack is taking center stage as officials worry about political violence in a presidential election year.\n\nThe gunman, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, fired at Trump from a rooftop just outside the rally security perimeter, using an AR-style rifle. One rallygoer was killed, two others were critically injured, and Trump, the Republican nominee in this year's presidential election, suffered a graze wound to his ear.\n\nThe security lapses that afforded the gunman a sightline to Trump on the rally stage have prompted multiple investigations of the U.S. Secret Service, whose director resigned Tuesday under pressure from both Republican and Democratic lawmakers.\n\nFBI investigators have said so far that the gunman did not appear to have any discernible ideology, suggesting he was not motivated primarily by political animosity.\n\nRep. Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), who chairs the Judiciary committee, is a longtime Trump ally and critic of Wray, the FBI and the Justice Department. He began the hearing by criticizing what he called \"the Biden-Harris Justice Department\" - an acknowledgment that Vice President Harris is now running for the Democratic nomination after President Biden announced he would not seek a second term.\n\nWray confirmed a number of details from the investigation that have been publicly reported already, including that there were eight spent bullet casings found near the gunman's body - indicating that he fired at least that many times.\n\nThe director also described how Crooks apparently used a drone hours before the shooting to examine the area near the rally, but not directly overhead.\n\n\"The drone was recovered in his vehicle,\" Wray testified. \"The shooter was flying the drone around the area, not over the stage. ... We think that he was live-streaming, viewing the footage for about 11 minutes, about 200 yards away.\"\n\nTwo explosive devices were found in the shooter's car, devices that Wray called \"relatively crude devices themselves, but they did have the ability to be detonated remotely.\"\n\nBecause the remotely controlled devices attached to the homemade bombs were left in the \"off\" position, Wray said, it appears \"that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked.\"\n\nTechnical experts at the FBI lab in Quantico, Va., were able to crack open the gunman's phone within two days of the attack. While they found some evidence of interest, the device did not provide an explanation for his motive, people familiar with the investigation have said, speaking on the condition of anonymity to describe the ongoing case.\n\nThe gunman used some encrypted messaging applications, which Wray said have \"unfortunately now become very commonplace\" in FBI investigations, as popular messaging software often includes encryption.\n\nAsked whether the FBI believed there were any accomplices or co-conspirators in the shooting, Wray answered, \"Not at this time, but again the investigation is ongoing.\"", "source": {"uri": "matzav.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "matzav.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241622691", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:32:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:32:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:32:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.washingtonexaminer.com/news/justice/3097152/wray-gunman-flew-drone-over-trump-rally-site-before-assassination-attempt/", "title": "Wray confirms gunman flew drone over Trump rally site hours before assassination attempt - Washington Examiner", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray fielded questions from lawmakers Wednesday about the assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump and confirmed several details about the incident, including that the shooter flew a drone over the Trump rally site.\n\nWray said during a House Judiciary Committee hearing that Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, used the drone in the 3:50 p.m. to 4 p.m. time frame on the day of the rally and that the FBI believes Crooks may have flown it about 200 yards away from the stage where Trump would speak two hours later.\n\n\"We think, but we do not know, so again, this is one of these things that's qualified because of our ongoing review, that he was livestreaming, you know, viewing the footage\" for about 11 minutes, Wray said.\n\nWray said the FBI recovered the drone in Crooks's car and also recovered two explosive devices in the vehicle, as well as a third explosive device at Crooks's home.\n\nThe FBI is leading the investigation into the shooting, which left one dead and two seriously injured. Trump was grazed on the side of the head by a bullet, resulting in a minor injury to the former president's ear.\n\nWray reiterated several times that the FBI's investigation was ongoing. Asked by Rep. Dan Bishop (R-NC) about why the FBI has not provided more details to the public about the shooting, Wray said he was being as transparent as possible, adding, \"frankly, unusually so for an ongoing investigation.\"\n\nAs lawmakers on the committee began laying into Wray about the massive security failures that led to the shooting, Wray clarified the scope of the bureau's investigation and deferred security-related questions to the Secret Service.\n\n\"The FBI's mandate is focused on the shooter and all things related to his attack,\" Wray said, noting that the Department of Homeland Security inspector general and an independent panel are both investigating the Secret Service's actions.\n\n\"There's a whole lot of work underway and still a lot of work to do, and our understanding of what happened and why will continue to evolve, but we're going to leave no stone unturned,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI is tasked with establishing Crooks's motive, and Wray said that is still a work in progress.\n\n\"I think it's fair to say that we do not yet have a clear picture of his motive,\" Wray said, noting agents have found no manifestos or garnered any information about a motive from interviews and an examination of Crooks's social media.\n\n\"The shooter appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures in general,\" Wray said.\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\nThe director indicated that the FBI had issued warrants to obtain information about Crooks's various digital accounts.\n\nWray's long-planned appearance before the committee comes as part of the FBI's annual congressional oversight, but the circumstances surrounding his testimony changed after the assassination attempt. (Anna Moneymaker/Getty Images)\n\nBefore attempting to shoot Donald Trump, the would-be assassin went to Google and typed: \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nAs the Associated Press reported, Matthew Thomas Crooks searched for the answer to that question on July 6, the same day the Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, was announced. Lee Harvey Oswald is the man who killed President John F. Kennedy on. Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe FBI found the search after recovering Crooks' laptop in an attempt to discern his motive for shooting at Trump.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" FBI director Christopher Wray told the AP. Crooks also had photos of President Joe Biden saved on his laptop, though he reportedly was fixated on Trump in the days leading up to the shooting, Wray said.\n\nThough Crooks' intent remains unknown, the FBI revealed that Crooks flew a drone \"around the area\" just hours before the rally began. The drone was in the air for approximately 11 minutes, CNN reported.\n\n\"It was almost like giving him a rear-view mirror of the scene behind him,\" Wray told CNN.\n\nThe assassination attempt on Trump has been widely considered as a major failure on the part of the Secret Service, with many questioning how it could happen at such a high-profile event.\n\nThe scrutiny has been so severe that the previous director of Secret Service, Kimberly Cheatle, resigned this week after lawmakers from both parties repeatedly called for her to do so.\n\nThe FBI will continue its investigation into the shooting, Wray promising lawmakers that his agency would \"leave no stone unturned.\"", "source": {"uri": "salon.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Salon.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. "FBI director grilled over assassination attempt investigation", "body": "(The Center Square) - Members of Congress grilled FBI Director Christopher Wray over details of the FBI's investigation into the assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump at a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Wednesday.\n\nWray's testimony comes as the FBI faces criticism over unanswered questions surrounding the agency's handling of the ongoing investigation into the recent shooting at a Trump campaign rally earlier this month.\n\nThe Secret Service has also come under fire for the security issues surrounding the rally shooting.\n\nFormer Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle stepped down from her post after calls for her resignation, as The Center Square previously reported.\n\nChairman Jim Jordan questioned the details of the shooter being allowed onto the premises of the Trump campaign rally.\n\n\"Why was the president allowed to walk out on stage when there was a suspicious person on the property?\" Jordan asked.\n\n\"We need to know what happened play by play, moment by moment, second by second,\" Jordan added\n\nJordan went on to say that Secretary of Homeland Security Alejandro Mayorkas was \"lying to the American people.\"\n\nWray slammed political violence during his opening statements.\n\n\"We will no and do not tolerate political violence of any kind,\" Wray said. \"Especially a despicable account of this magnitude.\"\n\n\"We are gonna leave no stone unturned,\" Wray added when discussing the investigation.\n\n\"The attempted assassination of the former President was an attack on our democracy,\" Wray said.\n\nWray went on to mention the United States being under an environment of \"heightened threat\" at several points during his testimony.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in a heightened threat environment,\" Wray said.\n\nMore from this section 24/7 construction coming to Gardiner Wray called the three explosive devices that the FBI recovered in the shooter's car \"relatively crude.\"\n\nWray acknowledged that the shooter had a drone and said that the FBI think that he was \"live-streaming\" and \"viewing the footage\" for several minutes before the shooting.\n\nWray went on to denounce political violence in the country, calling it an \"alarming phenomenon.\"\n\nU.S. Rep. Jerry Nadler asked Wray for his response to people calling for the defunding of the FBI.\n\n\"Cutting our funding is incredibly shortsighted,\" Wray said.\n\nThe question of any possible motives from the shooter leading up to the assassination attempt against Trump came up several times during the hearing.\n\n\"I think it's fair to say that we do not yet have a clear picture of his motive,\" Wray said in response.\n\nWray said that the shooter is thought to have visited the surrounding area three separate times leading up to the rally when Jordan asked him about how many times the shooter was at the premises of the Trump rally.\n\nWray revealed that the shooter did a \"Google search for how far away was Oswald from Kennedy\" on July 6. Wray added that that was the same day that the shooter registered to attend the Trump campaign rally.\n\nWray said that the shooter seemed interested in images of various public officials and public figures who \"cover both parties\" and added that the FBI are still trying to \"grill into that\" amidst their ongoing investigation.\n\nMany members of the Judiciary Committee denounced acts of political violence at several points throughout the hearing.\n\n\"In America violence has never been the answer,\" Rep. RocketNews", "body": "Christopher Wray says FBI probe into 'despicable' assassination attempt against ex-president continues.FBI Director Christopher Wray has said the agency will leave \"no stone unturned\" as he faced questions from United States lawmakers about this month's assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump.\n\nDuring his opening statement to the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, Wray said the shooting at Trump's July 13 rally in Pennsylvania was \"an attack on our democracy and our democratic process\".\n\n\"We will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind, especially a despicable account of this magnitude,\" he said.\n\n\"And I want to assure you and the American people that the men and women of the FBI will continue to work tirelessly to get to the bottom of what happened.\"\n\nWray's testimony comes a day after US Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned amid widespread criticism over the security protocols deployed for the Trump rally.\n\nThe former president and current Republican Party presidential nominee was shot in the ear by a gunman who witnesses said had taken up a position on a rooftop with a direct line of sight to the rally stage.\n\nOne rally attendee was killed and two were seriously injured in the incident.\n\nThe FBI said it is investigating the shooting as an act of \"domestic terrorism\" and an attempted assassination.\n\nBut the agency has not yet determined the motive of the suspected shooter, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, fuelling questions for Wray from lawmakers.\n\nThe FBI director and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, t ...", "source": {"uri": "rocketnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "RocketNews | Top News Stories From Around the Globe"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241672747", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:10:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:10:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:09:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://journalstar.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/trump-rally-gunman-looked-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_05002c53-7fed-5b08-b7a0-3e03a17e7113.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nElections Secret Service director steps down after assassination attempt against Trump By COLLEEN LONG The Associated Press\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nPeople are also reading... Lincoln restaurant calls it quits after 15 years 'Ready to learn from this': John Cook updates Harper Murray's status for 2024 season 'Exhausting, heartbreaking, devastating': Racism at Wayne school pushes family out of Nebraska Former Nebraska Sen. Ben Sasse to resign as University of Florida president Fleet Farm backed out of northwest Lincoln development This Nebraska couple runs a senior dog sanctuary just outside of Lincoln Recruiting: New Nebraska football staffer aims for pair of 2026 four-star targets Guatemalan chicken restaurant puts Lincoln, Gretna and Crete on its expansion map Teen accused of causing train derailment near Bennet before recording it Nebraska volleyball's Harper Murray sentenced to probation for DUI Is it legal to turn on red traffic arrows in Lincoln? What new Nebraska law says Pedestrian struck by car in west Lincoln dies at hospital, police say Lincoln Animal Control reports first-ever rabies case in a fox 'Death Row:' Nebraska defensive line room embracing new nickname Numerous Lincoln operations affected by global tech outage\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said that Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. The use of the drone so close the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nElections GOP threatened to sue over November ballot if Biden dropped out. Experts call that 'ridiculous' ROBERT YOON Associated Press\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, when Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle,\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally 0 Comments Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "journalstar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "JournalStar.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@journalstar.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "manuel_balce_ceneta@journalstar.com", "name": "Manuel Balce Ceneta", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abraham_Lincoln", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Abraham Lincoln"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241748016", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:06:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:06:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:06:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.cbc.ca/news/world/fbi-wray-congress-1.7273747", "title": "Trump shooter used 'mechanical equipment' to climb roof, may have had collapsible gun stock: FBI | CBC News", "body": "Thomas Crooks, the shooter who killed one person and injured Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump on July 13, may have possessed a collapsible stock weapon, FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers on Capitol Hill on Wednesday.\n\nWray stressed to the House's judiciary committee that it wasn't a final conclusion, as FBI agents and other law enforcement officials continue to investigate the shocking event. But it could explain one of the questions yet to be answered: specifically, how Crooks was seen on the ground by some individuals before the shooting in Butler, Pa., but was not viewed in possession of a gun until he climbed his perch on a nearby roof.\n\n\"The weapon had a collapsible stock which might explain why it was less easy to observe,\" he said.\n\nWray said Trump came into particular focus for the shooter on July 6, at which point he also performed a web search for the distance Lee Harvey Oswald was from president John F. Kennedy in the 1963 assassination in Dallas.\n\nHe said Wednesday that initial analysis of a laptop owned by Crooks included some \"foreign public figures,\" without specifying individuals.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nThe furor over the shooting led to bipartisan calls for the resignation of Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle, which occurred on Tuesday.\n\nWhile a five-foot ladder was purchased by the shooter, Wray said, it was recovered not at the shooting perch nor in the shooter's vehicle, he added without specifying its location.\n\nInstead, officials believe Crooks used unspecified \"mechanical equipment\" from the ground and vertical piping on the side of the building to climb atop it.\n\nWray said eight cartridges were found on the roof after a countersniper fatally shot Crooks.\n\n\"He was able to get more rounds off more quickly than he would with other types of weapons,\" said Wray of the AR-15-style weapon used by Crooks. The gun was purchased by the shooter's father, legally, years earlier.\n\nOfficials are still analyzing a drone that Wray said Crooks flew 200 yards (182 metres) away from the stage just a few hours before the early evening shooting. It was recovered from the shooter's vehicle.\n\nThe FBI's director said there's no evidence that Crooks had any co-conspirators at this point.\n\nThree \"relatively crude\" explosive devices were found, he said, two in the shooter's vehicle at Butler and one at the shooter's home in nearby Bethel Park. Wray said Crooks had a transmitter on his person, but that it wasn't clear at this point if they would have resulted in explosions if he had utilized it.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump, Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nBut he stressed that in contrast to other high-profile shooters, Crooks appears to have not left a significant online footprint or engaged extensively in conversations on public forums. He did say that Crooks at times used encrypted messaging apps, without getting into details of those messages.\n\nWray, as he has done at other congressional committee hearings, condemned harmful rhetoric and a heightened environment for threats, which have been directed at politicians, lawyers and judges and volunteer election officials. Wray himself was the subject of alleged threats, with a Georgia man indicted in that case earlier this month.\n\nNew York Democrat Jerry Nadler stressed that dehumanizing and violent rhetoric had often come from Republicans, including Trump himself.\n\n\"If you think that this one assassin's bullet was a bolt out of the blue, and not part of a wave of violence that has threatened this nation for years, then you have missed the point,\" said Nadler.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, as well as an FBI search of Trump's Florida estate for classified documents after allegedly defying a subpoena.\n\nWray, in response to questions from Democrats, said he wasn't familiar with the details of Project 2025, the term for the Heritage Foundation's nearly 1,000-page handbook for the next Republican administration. But he expressed disapproval for any FBI reform that would involve the firing of civil servants for political reasons, or any director directly taking their cues on priorities from a president.", "source": {"uri": "cbc.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CBC News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Thomas Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. {"uri": "2024-07-432398150", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:20:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:20:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:55:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://thehill.com/homenews/4790462-trump-shooter-searched-kennedy-assassination-same-day-he-registered-for-rally-fbi/", "title": "Trump shooter searched JFK assassination same day he registered for rally: FBI", "body": "One week before a gunman attempted to kill former President Trump, he conducted a Google search for \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, who shot and killed President John F. Kennedy in 1963, according to FBI Director Christopher Wray.\n\nThat same day, the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, registered for Trump's rally in Butler, Pa., Wray told the House Judiciary Committee Wednesday.\n\nWray said the FBI conducted an analysis of a laptop tied to Crooks and found that on July 6, \"he became very focused\" on Trump and the July 13 rally.\n\n\"We've, just in the last couple days, found that . . . [the] laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6 he did a Google search 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy?'\" Wray said.\n\nWray said the search is \"significant\" in terms of the shooter's state of mind, and that it was done \"the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally.\"\n\nAuthorities so far have struggled to find a motive as to why Crooks climbed onto a roof about 150 yards away from Trump as he was speaking on stage and fired at least eight shots at the presidential nominee, grazing his ear, killing an attendee and critically injuring two others at the rally.\n\nWray also sought to clarify reports that Crooks had searched online for images of specific public officials, saying that it appears he was searching for news articles.\n\n\"The images that we've recovered so far . . . appear to be what we call cached images from searches of news articles,\" he told lawmakers. \"If you do a news article search . . . if there are photos on it, those photos get stored automatically in your cache, as opposed to him searching for a specific images of that person.\"\n\nWray added \"there doesn't seem to be a whole lot of rhyme or reason\" to Crooks's search history, other than it all includes prominent U.S. public figures across both parties and even some foreign public officials.\n\n\"That one repository of information doesn't appear to be overly indicative of motive other than interest in public figures,\" he said.\n\nEarlier in the hearing, Wray confirmed that Crooks had used a drone, apparently to survey the rally site in the hours before Trump took the stage, and said the FBI is now analyzing that device.\n\nThe FBI also recovered two \"relatively crude\" explosive devices in the Crooks's car {"uri": "2024-07-432399852", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:22:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:22:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:05:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.bizpacreview.com/2024/07/24/fbi-director-offers-details-on-trump-shooters-remote-detonation-devices-says-drone-recovered-1474878/", "title": "FBI director offers details on Trump shooter's remote detonation devices, says drone recovered", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray revealed to the House Judiciary Committee that the investigation into Trump rally shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks has turned up explosive devices.\n\nThe committee noted that the hearing on Wednesday is to \"examine the FBI's investigation into the assassination attempt against President Trump and the ongoing politicization of the nation's preeminent law enforcement agency under the direction of FBI Director Christopher Wray and Attorney General Merrick Garland.\"\n\nWray testified that the FBI \"recovered three [explosive] devices, two, in his vehicle and one back in his residence,\" referring to the 20-year-old who attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump at a July 13 rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\n\"I would say these are relatively... crude devices themselves. But they did have the ability to be detonated remotely,\" Wray told lawmakers.\n\n(Video Credit: Fox News)\n\n\"In addition to the two devices that we recovered out of his vehicle, there were receivers for those two explosive devices with the devices. And then on the shooter himself, when he was killed by law enforcement, he had a transmitter with him,\" Wray continued.\n\n\"Now, I do want to add one important point here is that at the moment... it looks like because of the on/off position on the receivers, that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" the FBI chief added. \"But that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous.\"\n\nThe FBI has reportedly been investigating the incident as a potential act of domestic terrorism as well as an attempted assassination of the former president who was struck by a bullet on his right ear.\n\n\"We have recovered a drone that the shooter appears to have used. It's being exploited and analyzed by the FBI lab. The drone was recovered in his vehicle. So at the time of the shooting, the drone was in his vehicle with the controller,\" Wray explained.\n\nHe told lawmakers that Crooks \"was flying the drone around the area\" of the rally around 4 p.m., about two hours before Trump took to the stage about 200 yards away.\n\nWray also testified about the weapon that Crooks had used, reportedly firing eight times before being killed by a US Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\n\"The weapon that he used for the attempted assassination was an AR-style rifle that was purchased legally, that he - as my understanding - acquired, I think bought actually from his father, who was the one who originally bought it,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI director noted that \"it is, quite frankly, a dangerous time to be a prominent public official.\"\n\nHe addressed reports of Crooks having done some online searches prior to the shooting.\n\n\"The shooter appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures in general, but so far we are seeing kind of news articles and things like that,\" Wray said, adding, \"so the images that have been reported about, really what we are talking about there are when you do a news search of an article the image appears in a cache as opposed to like a search for that specific individual.\"\n\nWray's testimony follows the dramatic grilling of now-former Secret Service Director Kim Cheatle before the House Oversight Committee on Monday. She subsequently resigned as the House Homeland Security Committee held a hearing Tuesday. Cheatle did not make an appearance at that hearing and neither did her boss, DHS Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas.\n\nHowever, the committee did hear testimony from other witnesses, including Colonel Christopher L. Paris, the commissioner of the Pennsylvania State Police, and Patrick Yoes, the National President of the Fraternal Order of Police.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment,\" Wray said in his opening statement Wednesday. \"The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is ongoing.\"\n\n(Video Credit: Forbes Breaking News)\n\nWe have no tolerance for comments containing violence, racism, profanity, vulgarity, doxing, or discourteous behavior.
