One rally attendee was killed, two were critically injured, and Trump sustained a minor injury when a bullet grazed his ear.\n\nOn Monday, Cheatle testified before the House Oversight Committee, pledging accountability and labeling the attack as the \"most significant operational failure\" for the Secret Service in decades. She refused to answer questions about the gunman's actions prior to the attack, citing the ongoing FBI investigation.\n\nWhether Wray plans to offer new insight wasn't clear Wednesday morning.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting.\n\nShare on FacebookTweet", "source": {"uri": "ticklethewire.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Tickle The Wire"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8242073683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "23:20:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T23:20:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T23:20:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.odt.co.nz/news/world/trump-shooter-searched-online-jfk-assassination-fbi", "title": "Trump shooter searched online for JFK assassination: FBI", "body": "You are not permitted to download, save or email this image. Visit image gallery to purchase the image.\n\nThe 20-year-old gunman who tried to kill Donald Trump did an online search of the John F Kennedy assassination around the time he began to focus attention on the Republican presidential candidate, the FBI has revealed.\n\n\"Analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6, he did a Google search for -quote - 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Wray said.\n\nHe was referring to Lee Harvey Oswald, who assassinated former President Kennedy in Dallas, Texas, on November 22 in 1963.\n\n\"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray said.\n\n\"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally,\" he added, saying Crooks became \"very focused on President Trump and his rally\" at that point after showing interest in public figures more generally.\n\nAbout two hours before the shooting, Crooks flew a drone over the area about 180 metres from the stage where Trump spoke to the crowd, and live-streamed footage for about 11 minutes.\n\nLaw enforcement officers did not spot Crooks on the roof with his AR-15-style rifle until \"seconds\" before he opened fire, said Wray, noting that the timeline could change as the investigators' understanding of facts evolves.\n\n\"It's all happening in seconds,\" Wray said. He added that the rifle had a collapsible stock, \"which could explain why it might have been less easy for people to observe.\"\n\nCrude explosive devices later recovered from Crooks' car and home were designed to be detonated remotely. Crooks had a transmitter with him, Wray added. But he said the FBI believes the suspect would not have been successful had he tried to detonate the devices.\n\nThe motive for the shooting remains unclear. Wray said many people have described Crooks as a loner and the list of contacts in his phone was short.\n\nThe hearing also focused on the increasingly tense political atmosphere surrounding the presidential campaign.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated-threat environment. And tragically, the ... assassination attempt is another example, particularly heinous,\" Wray testified.\n\nA day before Wray's testimony, Kimberly Cheatle resigned as director of the US Secret Service after bipartisan demands to quit over the failure to prevent the attempted assassination.\n\nJudiciary Committee Chairman Jim Jordan welcomed Wray's willingness to share details about the FBI investigation into the assassination attempt.\n\nBut he also cited skepticism toward the FBI that exists among some Republicans, who are angry about the arrest of Trump supporters who stormed the US Capitol on January 6 in 2021, as Congress certified President Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.\n\n\"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation,\" Jordan said.\n\nRepresentative Jerrold Nadler, the panel's top Democrat, condemned the Trump shooting \"unequivocally and unabashedly\" but pointed to years of political threats and violence, and violent rhetoric from Republicans including Trump himself.\n\n\"If you think that this one assassin's bullet was a bolt out of the blue, and not part of a wave of violence that has threatened this nation for years, then you have missed the point,\" Nadler said.", "source": {"uri": "odt.co.nz", "dataType": "news", "title": "Otago Daily Times Online News"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. Kennedy's assassination before the shooting, FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nWhy it matters: Wray, speaking before the House Judiciary Committee, said the shooter searched \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy\" on July 6 -- the same day he registered to attend Trump's July 13 rally in Butler County, Pennsylvania.\n\nWhile there are still countless questions regarding the attempted assassination, including how so many things could have gone wrong on the security front, how Crooks managed to get up on the roof with the weapon, and what his motive was, one thing that appears evident is that Crooks was contemplating assassination a full week prior to the rally.", "source": {"uri": "redstate.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Redstate"}, "authors": [{"uri": "susie_moore@redstate.com", "name": "Susie Moore", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241693869", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:25:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:25:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:25:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.westernjournal.com/trump-shooter-flew-drone-livestreamed-area-hours-attack-stunning-details-come-light-wray/", "title": "Trump Shooter Flew Drone, Livestreamed Area Hours Before Attack as Stunning Details Come to Light: Wray", "body": "Two hours before he shot former President Donald Trump, Thomas Matthew Crooks scouted the Trump rally venue in an 11-minute drone flight, FBI Director Chrisopher Wray said Wednesday.\n\nDuring a House Judiciary Committee hearing, Wray said Crooks flew the drown from about 3:50 p.m. to about 4 p.m. about 200 yards from the stage where Trump would speak, according to the New York Post. Crooks shot Trump and three other people from a rooftop about 140 yards away from the stage.\n\nWray said the FBI is trying to determine why the drone was sent up and what it told Crooks, according to CBS.\n\n\"It would have shown the shooter, we think -- again, we're still doing more work on this, I really want to qualify what I'm saying, but I'm trying to be transparent and lenient here. We think it would have shown him, kind of, what would have been behind him when he was shooting,\" Wray said.\n\n\"In other words, almost like giving him a rear-view mirror of the scene behind him. Except again, he wasn't flying it overhead while he was later back for the assassination,\" Wray said.\n\n\"We're still trying to figure out exactly what he saw, because we're having to, in effect -- because there's no recording of what he saw during those 11 minutes, our hypothesis at this point, our experts think he would have been live-streaming it,\" Wray said.\n\n\"And so we're trying to in effect say, OK, if this is the flight pattern, given these capabilities of the drone, what would you have seen, what could you have seen in these 11 minutes?\" he said.\n\nDuring his testimony, Wray revealed that on July 6, Crooks conducted a Google search for \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy.\" Lee Harvey Oswald assassinated President John F. Kennedy in Dallas in 1963.\n\n\"That's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray said.\n\nOn the day of that search, Crooks registered to attend the July 13 rally, Wray said.\n\nHe said that after the July 6 search, Crooks became \"very focused on\" Trump.\n\nDuring his testimony, Wray said Crooks used encrypted messaging apps on his devices and said that while the FBI was able to crack his phone, it is still searching other devices for a clue as to Crooks's motive.\n\nWray added that \"it is, quite frankly, a dangerous time to be a prominent public official,\" according to CNN.\n\nWray said the incident supports his concerns about a rise in domestic terrorism, according to the U.K.'s Daily Mail.\n\nHe said, it was \"another example, particularly heinous and very public one of what I have been talking about.'\"\n\nWray said he feared \"passion and heated rhetoric turning into actual violence.\"\n\n\"We've seen it against public officials of all sorts. We've seen it against law enforcements. The number of officers shot and killed in the line of duty is alarming. It's almost every five days that a law enforcement officer is killed in the line of duty. That is an example of the kinds of ways passion and heated rhetoric can bubble over into violence,\" he said.", "source": {"uri": "westernjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Western Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jack_davis@westernjournal.com", "name": "Jack Davis", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Unmanned aerial vehicle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. {"uri": "8241658912", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:00:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:00:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:59:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://missoulian.com/news/nation-world/government-politics/elections/trump-rally-gunman-looked-for-information-about-kennedy-assassination-fbi-director-says/article_170574a6-4d2c-597c-a342-01ecf078682b.html", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "WASHINGTON -- The gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nElections Secret Service director steps down after assassination attempt against Trump By COLLEEN LONG The Associated Press\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nPeople are also reading... Man kills grizzly, hospitalized after encounter in Flathead National Forest UPDATED: Evacuations ordered for new Butler Creek wildfire; Red Flag Warning The Stables: New restaurant in downtown Missoula next to Cranky Sam Fire, reported explosions prompt Missoula officials to close Lions Park Forest Service aware of interested buyer for Holland Lake Lodge Missoula police urge caution after reported downtown sexual assaults Missoula looks to build sidewalks in Westside neighborhood to avoid gentrification USPS to suspend air service delivery in Montana in favor of ground transportation Fire restrictions for county, forests, reservation, as fires start and Miller Peak grows Miller Peak fire near Missoula barely grows ahead of Friday public meeting Fire danger extreme, restrictions ordered as Miller Peak blaze grows 1 dead after officer-involved shooting in Mineral County NorthWestern monitoring Thursday's weather for possible rare power shutoff Man shot and killed by Mineral County officers was from Missoula 3 Montana inmates die in Cascade County Detention Center in 2 weeks\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.\n\nWray also said that Crooks, about two hours before the shooting, had flown a drone about 200 yards (180 meters) from the rally stage where Trump would later stand and that Crooks used the device to livestream and watch footage. The use of the drone so close the rally site just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department. Questions about the shooting dominated the session.\n\nElections GOP threatened to sue over November ballot if Biden dropped out. Experts call that 'ridiculous' ROBERT YOON Associated Press\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign, when Trump defeated Democrat Hillary Clinton.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the committee chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThe FBI so far has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting and has led to the the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle,\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/gunman-flew-drone-over-trump-rally-area-before-shooting-fbi-chief/article_140ff490-0319-5079-b389-a2b950197b82.html", "title": "Gunman flew drone over Trump rally area before shooting: FBI chief", "body": "The 20-year-old gunman who attempted to assassinate Donald Trump at a campaign rally flew a drone over the area about two hours before the former US president began to speak, the FBI director said Wednesday.\n\nFBI chief Christopher Wray, testifying before a congressional committee, also said the investigation into the July 13 shooting had not yet revealed a motive for the gunman.\n\nThomas Matthew Crooks opened fire on Trump with an AR-style assault rifle shortly after 6:00 pm as the Republican White House candidate was addressing a campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nCrooks, who was perched on the roof of a nearby building, was shot dead by a Secret Service sniper less than 30 seconds after firing his first shots.\n\nTrump was wounded in the ear, two rally attendees were seriously injured and a 50-year-old Pennsylvania firefighter was shot dead.\n\nUS Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned on Tuesday, a day after acknowledging that the agency had failed in its mission to prevent the assassination attempt.\n\nWray said Crooks flew a drone over the rally area for around 11 minutes -- between around 3:50 pm and 4:00 pm -- on the day of the shooting some 200 yards (meters) away from the stage where Trump was scheduled to speak.\n\nThe drone and its controller were recovered in the gunman's car.\n\nTwo \"relatively crude\" explosive devices were also found in the car along with another at the gunman's residence, Wray said.\n\nThe FBI director said the devices had the ability to be detonated remotely and the gunman had a transmitter with him when he was shot.\n\n\"It looks like, because of the on-off position on the receivers, that that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" he said. \"But that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous.\"\n\nAsked how many shots Crooks fired, Wray said eight cartridges had been recovered on the roof.\n\n- No clear motive -\n\nWray told members of the House Judiciary Committee that investigators \"do not yet have a clear picture of his motive.\"\n\n\"We're not seeing that yet, but we are digging hard, because this is one of the central questions for us,\" the FBI chief said.\n\nHe said the gunman \"appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures, in general\" but \"there doesn't seem to be a whole lot of rhyme or reason to it so far.\"\n\n\"Sarting somewhere around July 6 or so, he became very focused on former president Trump and this rally,\" Wray said.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for quote, 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?'\" he said, a reference to the 1963 assassination of president John F. Kennedy by Lee Harvey Oswald.\n\nThere is no evidence at this time that Crooks had any accomplices or co-conspirators, the FBI chief said.\n\ncl/des\n\nMore from this section\n\n2024 Election Latest: Biden ends reelection bid, endorses VP Harris for Democratic nomination\n\nMost airlines except one are recovering from the CrowdStrike tech outage. {"uri": "2024-07-432397228", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:20:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:20:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:10:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.waaytv.com/news/trump-shooter-flew-drone-in-rally-area-two-hours-before-shooting-fbi-director-says/article_5ca9402b-b33b-5306-aa84-233193908628.html", "title": "Trump shooter flew drone in rally area two hours before shooting, FBI director says", "body": "(CNN) -- Donald Trump's would-be assassin flew a drone in the area near the rally just two hours before the former president took the stage on July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania, FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday.\n\nSpeaking to the House Judiciary Committee, Wray revealed that \"around 4 p.m.,\" the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, \"was flying the drone around the area\" of the rally, approximately 200 yards from the stage.\n\nThe drone was in the air for approximately 11 minutes, and investigators believe Crooks watched a live feed from the drone on his phone. CNN previously reported that the drone was found in his car following the shooting.\n\nIn addition, Crooks had two explosives in his car at the time of the shooting and one in his home, but likely did not have the ability to detonate them from the roof where he was killed, Wray testified.\n\n\"It looks like because of the on/off position on the receivers, that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI is investigating the shooting as both an attempted assassination and as a potential act of domestic terrorism.\n\nInvestigators say that Crooks fired approximately eight times from an AR-style rifle at the former president before being killed by a US Secret Service counter sniper.\n\nThe rifle Crooks used was purchased from his father, Wray testified.\n\n\"The weapon that he used for the attempted assassination was an AR-style rifle that was purchased legally, that he - as my understanding - acquired, I think bought actually from his father, who was the one who originally bought it,\" Wray said.\n\nPreviously, officials said they believed the firearm belonged to Crooks' father - not the shooter - and they didn't know how Crooks accessed the weapon.\n\nFBI officials have repeatedly asserted that they believe Crooks acted alone, and used a rifle purchased legally by his father. On Wednesday, Wray reiterated that there is no evidence of any co-conspirators.\n\n\"I have been saying some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment,\" Wray said. \"The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is ongoing.\"\n\nInvestigators have gone through the shooter's phone and computer, scoured his search history and bedroom and have interviewed his family and friends, but have struggled to identify what motivated the 20-year-old would be assassin to act.\n\nCrooks also had no prior contacts with the FBI, officials say, and had not been previously on their radar or databases.\n\nShooter was searching for news stories\n\nWray pushed back against reports that Crooks searched for images of specific prominent public officials online, saying that it appears he was actually searching for news articles.\n\n\"The shooter appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures in general, but so far we are seeing kind of news articles and things like that,\" Wray said. He continued, \"so the images that have been reported about, really what we are talking about there are when you do a news search of an article the image appears in a cache as opposed to like a search for that specific individual.\"\n\nThe FBI director cautioned that the effort to uncover Crooks' motive is ongoing, but warned that \"it is, quite frankly, a dangerous time to be a prominent public official.\"\n\nThe House Judiciary Committee hearing is ongoing.\n\nThis story is breaking and will be updated.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump used a firearm with a \"collapsible stock\", likely making it easier to conceal, FBI Director Christopher Wray has said.\n\nMr Wray is testifying on Tuesday before the House Judiciary Committee about the shooting at the Butler, Pennsylvania, campaign rally earlier this month.\n\nA bullet grazed Trump's right ear and the attack left one audience member dead and two others badly wounded.\n\nMr Wray also said the gunman researched the 1963 assassination of John F Kennedy in the days before the shooting.\n\nIn his opening remarks, Mr Wray called the attempted assassination of former President Trump \"an attack on our democracy and our democratic process\".\n\n\"We will not and do not tolerate political violence of any time especially a despicable account of this magnitude,\" he told lawmakers.\n\nThe FBI director said officials found eight cartridges on the roof where the gunman, identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, was located.\n\nCrooks was killed by a counter sniper during the incident.\n\nThe AR-style rifle used in the shooting had a collapsible stock, which can make a weapon shorter and easier to transport.\n\nThe first people to see the gunman with a rifle did so when he was already on the roof from where he fired, Mr Wray said.\n\nHe also confirmed that the gunman flew a drone over the rally about two hours before the shooting.\n\nAdditionally, the FBI found three \"relatively crude\" explosive devices - one in the gunman's home and two others in his car.\n\nThese devices were capable of being detonated remotely and the gunman had a transmitter, Mr Wray said.\n\nIt did not appear as if Crooks would have been able to detonate them from the roof where he was perched at the time of the shooting, he added.\n\nThe FBI head said the agency still does not have a motive for the assassination attempt but the gunman appears to have become \"very focused\" on Trump from around 6 July.\n\nOn that day, the gunman searched for \"how far was Oswald from Kennedy\" and registered for the Trump rally, Mr Wray said.\n\nInvestigators also found the gunman had conducted searches for news articles about other public figures.\n\nMr Wray said there is no evidence that the gunman planned the attack with others.\n\nThe FBI is handling the criminal investigation into the attempted assassination and Mr Wray told the committee the agency will \"leave no stone unturned\".\n\n\"The men and women of the FBI will continue to work tirelessly to get to the bottom of what happened,\" he said.\n\nSecret {"uri": "8241709718", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:37:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:37:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:36:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://whyy.org/articles/trump-assassination-attempt-shooter-jfk-fbi-wray/", "title": "Trump rally gunman looked online for information about Kennedy assassination, FBI director says", "body": "The shooting has revealed multiple failures involving at least nine different local, county and federal law enforcement divisions\n\nThe gunman in the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump is believed to have done a Google search one week before the shooting of \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday, revealing new details about a suspect he said had taken a keen interest in public figures but had otherwise not left behind clear clues of an ideological motive.\n\nThe search, recovered from a laptop tied to 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, is a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the shooter who killed President John F. Kennedy from a sniper's perch in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe revelation to the House Judiciary Committee was part of a collection of new details offered by Wray about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The FBI's investigation has thrust the bureau into a political maelstrom months before the presidential election, with lawmakers and the public pressing for details about what may have motivated Crooks in the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nThe FBI has built out a detailed timeline of Crooks' movements and online activity, but the precise motive -- or why Trump was singled out -- remains elusive, Wray said.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded, anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said. He did note that Crooks had grown interested in public officials -- besides Trump, Crooks also had photos on his phone of Democratic President Joe Biden and other prominent figures -- and in the days before the shooting had appeared particularly consumed by Trump, the Republicans' White House nominee.", "source": {"uri": "whyy.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "WHYY"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241773542", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:28:17", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:28:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:25:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/trump-shooter-searched-for-jfk-assassination-information-fbi-director-says-what-weve-learned--and-still-dont-know--about-the-assassination-attempt-182432839.html", "title": "Trump shooter searched for JFK assassination information, FBI director says. What we've learned  --  and still don't know  --  about the assassination attempt.", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers on Wednesday that the gunman who opened fire at former President Donald Trump's campaign rally looked up \"how far away\" John F. Kennedy's assassin was located on the day the former president was fatally shot.\n\nWray testified before the House Judiciary Committee about the FBI's investigation into the attempted assassination against Trump on July 13. He called the shooting \"an attack on our democracy and our democratic process and we will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind.\"\n\n\"We're going to leave no stone unturned. The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing,\" Wray said, adding that the bureau is using all of its criminal and national security resources in the investigation.\n\nWray's testimony revealed new details about the gunman, identified by authorities as 20-year-old Thomas Crooks, who killed one person and wounded two others. He also fired a bullet that grazed Trump's ear, leaving him bleeding.\n\nGunman searched JFK assassination: Investigators found that on July 6, Crooks searched \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy\" on Google. The search was referring to Lee Harvey Oswald, who assassinated Kennedy from the sixth floor of a building in 1963. \"That search is obviously significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally,\" Wray said.\n\nThe \"collapsible stock\": When asked how the gunman was able to get a weapon to the nearby roof where he opened fire from, Wray said he didn't yet have an answer to that specific question. He testified that the gunman's weapon \"had a collapsible stock, which could explain why it might have been less easy for people to observe.\"\n\nHow the gunman got on the roof: Wray said investigators believe Crooks was able to get onto the roof by climbing up \"using some mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping on the side of the\" building. \"In other words, we do not believe he used a ladder to get up there.\"\n\nBullets on the roof: Wray said investigators \"have recovered eight cartridges on the roof.\"\n\nAccomplices? Wray was asked if there were any known co-conspirators, accomplices or cooperators who also took part in the rally shooting. \"Not at this time,\" Wray said. \"But again the investigation is ongoing.\"\n\nThe drone: Wray confirmed that Crooks flew a drone on July 13 over an area \"about 200 yards, give or take,\" from the rally hours before the shooting. He added that there was no recording of the roughly 11-minute drone flight, but believed the gunman was watching video streamed from the device to scout the area.\n\nCrooks's phone: Wray said gaining access to Crooks's phone was a \"significant technical challenge\" and that the gunman used encrypted messaging apps on his phone.\n\nExplosive devices: Wray said that two explosive devices were found in the gunman's car and one was found at his residence, classifying them as \"relatively crude,\" though they did have the capability of being \"detonated remotely.\" A transmitter was found on Crooks after he was killed. \"At a moment, it looks like because of the on/off position on the receivers, that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked, but that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous,\" Wray said.\n\nImages of political figures found on gunman's devices: Wray testified that the images of various political leaders found on the gunman's devices were \"cached images from searches of news articles.\" Wray explained that if someone reads a digital news article, the photos on said article will automatically get stored in the cache, as opposed to images specifically searched. This suggests the shooter was reading news articles on these political figures.\n\nThe gunman's motive: \"Many of us are interested in the motive of the shooter here, when it's an assault on a political figure, you immediately assume there's a political motive, and that may be the case here, we don't know yet,\" said Rep. Zoe Lofgren, a California Democrat. \"Can you enlighten us about that?\" Wray replied, \"I think it's fair to say that we do not yet have a clear picture of his motive.\" Typically there are motive answers through social media searches, messages or a manifesto, he explained. But Wray added: \"We're not seeing that, but we're digging in hard because this is one of the central questions for us.\"\n\nHow the gunman was able to fire eight shots: Wray was asked how the gunman was allowed to get eight shots out before he was neutralized by the Secret Service counter-sniper. \"That I think is something we're still digging into,\" Wray replied.\n\nWhy Trump was allowed to go on stage: The Secret Service knew that local law enforcement was looking for a suspicious person before Trump took the stage, one lawmaker said. Wray was asked why Trump was allowed to go on stage. \"We don't know the answer to that,\" he said, adding that the FBI's investigation is focused on the shooter, but acknowledged the intense interest in that key question.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Thomas Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8242214336", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "02:11:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T02:11:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T02:10:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/us/a-day-before-trumps-assassination-bid-shooter-searched-online-about-john-f-kennedys-shooting/articleshow/112001196.cms", "title": "A day before Trump's assassination bid, shooter searched online about John F Kennedy's shooting - Times of India", "body": "Thomas Matthew Crooks, the gunman who opened fire on former President Donald Trump at a Pennsylvania rally, had searched online for details about the November 1963 shooting of former US President John F Kennedy in the days leading up to the attack, FBI director Christopher Wray revealed Wednesday.\n\nWray, testifying before a congressional committee, said Crooks flew a drone over the venue in Butler, Pennsylvania, about two hours before Donald Trump took the stage on July 13.\n\nInvestigators have not established a motive for the shooting. Wray said, \"We are digging hard because this is one of the central questions for us.\" He added that Crooks \"appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures, in general\" but found no clear pattern to his research.\n\n\"Starting somewhere around July 6 or so, he became very focused on former President Trump and this rally,\" the FBI chief said. Crooks registered to attend the campaign event in Butler on July 6 and conducted a Google search for \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" referencing Kennedy's assassination by Lee Harvey Oswald. \"That obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray said.\n\nTrump survived the assassination attempt, suffering a wound to his right ear. A Secret Service sniper shot dead the suspected gunman, identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, less than 30 seconds after he fired eight shots. \"With respect to former President Trump, there's some question about whether or not it's a bullet or shrapnel that, you know, that hit his ear,\" Wray said.\n\nTwo rally attendees were seriously injured, and a 50-year-old Pennsylvania firefighter was shot dead.\n\nThe FBI director said that no evidence has emerged so far indicating Crooks had any accomplices or co-conspirators, describing him as a \"loner.\"\n\nAt TOI World Desk, our dedicated team of seasoned journalists and passionate writers tirelessly sifts through the vast tapestry of global events to bring you the latest news and diverse perspectives round the clock. Kennedy on his laptop a week before carrying out the Pennsylvania rally shooting. Thomas Matthew Crooks looked up \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" FBI director Christopher Wray testified to Congress Wednesday.\n\nThe search is \"obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray said.\n\nCrooks also flew a drone near the rally site just two hours before Trump took the stage, Wray confirmed, \"around 4 p.m.\" for several minutes approximately 200 yards from the stage.\n\nExplosives found in the shooter's vehicle were likely too far away to detonate from his position on a building roof, Wray said.\n\nWray's testimony comes after Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned her post following intense bipartisan backlash over failing to prevent the shooting.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [{"uri": "diego_mendoza@yahoo.com", "name": "Diego Mendoza", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. Kennedy days prior to the shooting.\n\nThe information was revealed by FBI Director Christopher Wray, who testified at a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Wednesday, July 24.\n\n\"Analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6, he did a Google search for, quote, 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Wray testified, in a hearing aired by C-SPAN.\n\nThe shooter, identified as Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, was killed by Secret Service agents after firing several shots toward Trump, who was speaking on stage, from a building outside the venue in Butler, Pa..\n\nTrump, whose ear was bleeding in the aftermath of the shooting, was evacuated safely from the scene. One person in the audience was killed, while two others were seriously injured.\n\nAccording to Wray's testimony, Crooks registered to attend the rally on the same day he made the search about the Kennedy assassination.\n\nWray also testified that Crooks had a drone in his vehicle at the time of the shooting. About two hours before the shooting, Wray said, Crooks had flown the drone in the area of the venue.\n\nThe FBI director was asked then about explosive devices found in the shooter's vehicle and home.\n\nNever miss a story -- sign up for PEOPLE's free daily newsletter to stay up-to-date on the best of what PEOPLE has to offer, from celebrity news to compelling human interest stories.\n\n\"[The explosive devices] did have the ability to detonate remotely,\" Wray testified, though he added that the investigation currently indicates that had Crooks attempted to detonate them from the roof, he would have been unsuccessful based on the \"on-off position of the receivers.\"\n\n\"But that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous,\" Wray said.\n\nCrooks graduated from Bethel Park High School in 2022 in Bethel Park, Pa., about 50 miles from Butler.", "source": {"uri": "people.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "PEOPLE.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. {"uri": "8241480899", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:58:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:58:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:57:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://wsbt.com/news/nation-world/fbi-director-christopher-wray-to-face-questioning-on-former-president-donald-trump-assassination-attempt-butler-pennsylvania-shooting-thomas-crooks-motive-investigation", "title": "FBI director Christopher Wray to face questioning on Trump assassination attempt", "body": "WASHINGTON (TND) -- FBI director Christopher Wray is testifying before the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday as the agency continues its investigation into the failed assassination of former President Donald Trump as lawmakers continue their investigations into how the Secret Service failed to prevent the shooting and law enforcement continues to search for a motive behind the shooting.\n\n\"The attempted assassination of the former president was an attack on our democracy,\" Wray said during his opening statement.\n\nIt will be the most in-depth comments yet from Wray as the FBI continues its investigation of the suspected 20-year-old gunman, Thomas Crooks, and what may have drove him to open fire at the rally, killing one person in the crowd, injuring two others and wounding Trump's right ear. The FBI is investigating the shooting as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination.\n\nThe FBI is generally secretive around active investigations but the public interest and extraordinary circumstances surrounding the attack has prompted agency officials to be more forthcoming with details and developments as they continue to piece things together.\n\nThe hearing was scheduled before the July 13 shooting as part of routine oversight of the FBI and Justice Department, which have both under the spotlight in the GOP-led House for the criminal cases against the former president that are likely on hold past Election Day after the Supreme Court issued a ruling giving presidents immunity.\n\nWray and Attorney General Merrick Garland have both been the focus of repeated contentious hearings in front of House GOP-led committees amid lingering frustration over its 2016 investigation of Trump's ties to Russia, the prosecution of rioters at the Jan. 6 insurrection at the Capitol and the legal cases against Trump.\n\nThe Secret Service has taken the brunt of the congressional criticism for the attempt on Trump's life, leading to the resignation of director Kimberly Cheatle, but Wray is likely to face tough questioning on the lack of details about a potential motive behind the shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania. {"uri": "2024-07-432594480", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:51:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:51:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:38:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://exbulletin.com/politics/2802367/", "title": "Trump's Shooter Wanted For JFK Assassination, FBI Director SaysExBulletin", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray, pictured here in December 2023, gave lawmakers an update Wednesday on the investigation into the July 13 assassination attempt on former President Donald Trump. Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images .\n\n. Kevin Dietsch/Getty Images\n\nThe gunman who tried to assassinate former President Donald Trump searched online a week before the shooting about the killing of former President John F. Kennedy, the FBI director said Wednesday.\n\nIn testimony before the House Judiciary Committee, Christopher Wray provided an update on the investigation into the July 13 shooting of Trump at a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. That includes information extracted from a computer linked to 20-year-old shooter Thomas Crooks that suggests he spent at least a week planning the attack.\n\nAnalysis of a laptop computer that the investigation links to the shooter reveals that on July 6, he did a Google search for \"How far was Oswald from Kennedy?\" Wray said. That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind. That's the same day he appears to have registered for the Butler rally.\n\nLee Harvey Oswald was the man who shot former President John F. Kennedy in Dallas, Texas in 1963.\n\nIn his testimony, which comes 11 days after the attempted assassination of Trump, Wray provided few details about the shooter and the timeline leading up to the shooting.\n\nThe FBI has had access to Crooks' digital devices, Wray said, but investigators have yet to find anything that indicates a political motive or ideology.\n\n\"That said, it seems pretty clear that he was interested in public figures more generally and, I think importantly, starting around July 6, he was very focused on former President Trump and this rally,\" he told lawmakers.\n\nInvestigators believe Crooks visited the Butler rally site three times, Wray said.\n\nThe first time was a week before the event, and he was there for about 20 minutes. The second time was the morning of the Trump rally, and he appears to have been there for about 70 minutes, Wray said. The third time was later that afternoon, a few hours before the event, and he never left.\n\nDuring that last visit, Wray said, Crooks flew a drone over the rally grounds for 11 minutes around 4 p.m., about 200 yards from the scene.\n\nInvestigators found the drone in the shooter's vehicle, along with its controller. They were able to reconstruct the aircraft's flight path, Wray said, but they don't know exactly what Crooks saw or why.\n\nExplosive devices deactivated\n\nWray also discussed the three explosive devices recovered by investigators: two in Crooks' vehicle and one at his home. Wray described the devices as relatively crude, but said they could be detonated remotely.\n\nA transmitter was found on Crooks' body, he said, but it appears the receivers on the explosive devices were not turned on, so he could not have detonated them.\n\nInvestigators now believe, Wray said, that Crooks climbed to the roof from where he fired using \"mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping\" on the side of the building. The FBI has not yet determined when the shooter climbed to the roof.\n\nWray said Crooks' AR-style rifle had a collapsible stock, which Wray said \"might explain why it would have been less easy for people to observe.\"\n\nThe day before the shooting, Crooks went to a shooting range and fired an AR-style rifle, Wray said. The director described Crooks as a \"pretty avid shooting enthusiast.\"\n\nDescribed as solitary, few contacts\n\nInvestigators have conducted more than 400 interviews with a wide range of people so far, he said, which has helped form a picture of Crooks' identity.\n\n\"From everything we've seen, which is consistent with what we've learned in interviews, a lot of people describe him as a loner,\" Wray said. \"That's kind of consistent with what we see on his devices. His contact list, for example, is very short compared to what you would normally see for most people. There doesn't seem to be a lot of interaction between him face-to-face or digitally with a lot of people.\"\n\nNPR and other outlets have previously reported that investigators found images of President Biden, former President Trump, the attorney general and the FBI director on Crooks' phone.\n\nWray said the photos found were automatically stored from online searches and reading news articles.\n\n\"It doesn't appear to be any kind of target list,\" he said.\n\n\"These are cached images from ongoing searches, so from news articles. And again, there's nothing, no pattern, in this particular piece of information that's particularly remarkable so far.\"\n\nWhat Are The Main Benefits Of Comparing Car Insurance Quotes Online\n\nLOS ANGELES, CA / ACCESSWIRE / June 24, 2020, / Compare-autoinsurance.Org has launched a new blog post that presents the main benefits of comparing multiple car insurance quotes. For more info and free online quotes, please visit https://compare-autoinsurance.Org/the-advantages-of-comparing-prices-with-car-insurance-quotes-online/ The modern society has numerous technological advantages. One important advantage is the speed at which information is sent and received. With the help of the internet, the shopping habits of many persons have drastically changed. The car insurance industry hasn't remained untouched by these changes. On the internet, drivers can compare insurance prices and find out which sellers have the best offers. View photos The advantages of comparing online car insurance quotes are the following: Online quotes can be obtained from anywhere and at any time. Unlike physical insurance agencies, websites don't have a specific schedule and they are available at any time. Drivers that have busy working schedules, can compare quotes from anywhere and at any time, even at midnight. Multiple choices. Almost all insurance providers, no matter if they are well-known brands or just local insurers, have an online presence. Online quotes will allow policyholders the chance to discover multiple insurance companies and check their prices. Drivers are no longer required to get quotes from just a few known insurance companies. Also, local and regional insurers can provide lower insurance rates for the same services. Accurate insurance estimates. Online quotes can only be accurate if the customers provide accurate and real info about their car models and driving history. Lying about past driving incidents can make the price estimates to be lower, but when dealing with an insurance company lying to them is useless. Usually, insurance companies will do research about a potential customer before granting him coverage. Online quotes can be sorted easily. Although drivers are recommended to not choose a policy just based on its price, drivers can easily sort quotes by insurance price. Using brokerage websites will allow drivers to get quotes from multiple insurers, thus making the comparison faster and easier. For additional info, money-saving tips, and free car insurance quotes, visit https://compare-autoinsurance.Org/ Compare-autoinsurance.Org is an online provider of life, home, health, and auto insurance quotes. This website is unique because it does not simply stick to one kind of insurance provider, but brings the clients the best deals from many different online insurance carriers. In this way, clients have access to offers from multiple carriers all in one place: this website. On this site, customers have access to quotes for insurance plans from various agencies, such as local or nationwide agencies, brand names insurance companies, etc. \"Online quotes can easily help drivers obtain better car insurance deals. All they have to do is to complete an online form with accurate and real info, then compare prices\", said Russell Rabichev, Marketing Director of Internet Marketing Company. Kennedy in Dallas on Nov. 22, 1963.\n\nThe Google search, apparently by rally gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks, was done on July 6, a week before the shooting of Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nWray disclosed the new details in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nElections Secret Service director steps down after assassination attempt against Trump By COLLEEN LONG The Associated Press\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nWASHINGTON -- Just hours before opening fire, the gunman in the attempted assassination of Donald Trump flew a drone roughly 200 yards from the rally stage where the Republican former president would later stand, viewing and livestreaming the footage, FBI Director Christopher Wray told congressional lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nPeople are also reading... Update: Distillery building damaged by fire after Highway 29 crash in Napa Report: Visit Napa Valley staff allege toxic comments, secrecy by CEO Gallagher Vallejo man dies, Napan hurt in Highway 29 crash Restaurant owners, workers urge action against unpermitted food vending in Napa Ira C. Smith, KVON/KVYN radio sports director since 1976, dies at age 88 Napa City Council votes to sell Dwight Murray Plaza, other downtown land to developers Kevin Courtney, Napa Journal: My street is getting a major luxury upgrade Napa Valley Distillery plans to rebuild, reopen after fiery crash CHP: K-9 sniffs out 70 pounds of meth during Napa traffic stop Update: Ridge Fire in Lake County is 15% contained; evacuation orders in effect Napa County education trustee Ann Cash resigns after Mayacamas school approval Four arrested after Napa grocery robbery, police say 2023-24 Napa County Boys Soccer Player of the Year: Avi\u00f1a did it all for first-time section champ Calistoga $400K in unpaid bills for grapes lead to slew of lawsuits against Napa winemaker Proposed Napa airport land use zones raise housing concerns\n\nThe FBI recovered the drone and a controller from the car of 20-year-old shooter Thomas Matthew Crook and is analyzing it as agents investigate his background and motive.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee represents his most detailed comments to date about the July 13 shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, which has thrust the FBI into a political maelstrom, with the bureau probing the most serious attempt to assassinate a president or presidential candidate since President Ronald Reagan was shot in 1981.\n\nListen now and subscribe: Apple Podcasts | Google Podcasts | Spotify | RSS Feed | SoundStack | All Of Our Podcasts\n\nThe details about Crooks' use of a drone just hours before Trump took the stage for the rally add to the questions about the security lapses preceding the event.\n\nWray pledged to lawmakers that the FBI would \"leave no stone unturned\" in its investigation of a shooting that he called despicable and horrific.\n\nElections GOP threatened to sue over November ballot if Biden dropped out. Experts call that 'ridiculous' ROBERT YOON Associated Press\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally Be the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "napavalleyregister.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Napa Valley Register"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. Experts call that 'ridiculous' ROBERT YOON Associated Press\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment, and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example -- a particularly heinous and public one -- of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the July 13 shooting as part of the committee's routine oversight of the FBI and the Justice Department, and though lawmakers may touch on a broad array of topics, questions about the shooting are expected to dominate the session.\n\nDespite being appointed by Trump, Wray typically faces antagonistic questions from the Republican-led panel, a reflection of lingering discontent over the FBI's investigation into potential ties between Russia and the 2016 campaign.\n\nThat sentiment was made clear early in the hearing when the panel's Republican chairman, Rep. Jim Jordan of Ohio, told Wray: \"I'm sure you understand that a significant portion of the country has a healthy skepticism regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\nThough the FBI has avoided the same level of scrutiny over the shooting directed at the Secret Service over security failures that preceded the shooting, culminating Tuesday in the resignation of Director Kimberly Cheatle, Wray is likely to be questioned by lawmakers skeptical of the bureau's assessment that Crooks left behind no obvious ideological motive that could explain his actions.\n\nThe FBI has said it is investigating the shooting, which killed one rallygoer and seriously injured two others, as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination. Trump's campaign said the presumptive GOP nominee was doing \"fine\" after the shooting, which Trump said pierced the upper part of his right ear.\n\nWray and other senior officials privately briefed members of Congress last week, telling them that Crooks had photos on his phone of Trump and Democratic President Joe Biden and other officials and had looked up the dates for the Democratic National Convention as well as Trump's appearances.\n\nA law enforcement official told The Associated Press last week that Crooks had also flown a drone above the rally site before the event in an apparent effort to scope out the scene in advance.\n\nPhotos: Trump injured, 2 killed in shooting at rally Love 0 Funny 0 Wow 0 Sad 0 Angry 0\n\nBe the first to know\n\nGet local news delivered to your inbox!\n\nSign up! * I understand and agree that registration on or use of this site constitutes agreement to its user agreement and privacy policy.", "source": {"uri": "lacrossetribune.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "La Crosse Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@lacrossetribune.com", "name": "Associated Press", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}, {"uri": "manuel_balce_ceneta@lacrossetribune.com", "name": "Manuel Balce Ceneta", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. Jim Jordan (D-Ohio.) pressed for answers around a drone Thomas Crooks used.\n\n\"Two hours before, he's flying a drone in the in the vicinity of the rally?\" Jordan asked.\n\n\"About 200 yards away,\" Wray replied.\n\nWray said the shooter purchased a ladder but did not use it at the scene. He confirmed Crooks fired eight shots during the rally, as eight cartridges were found on the roof.\n\n\"Why was Crooks allowed to get off eight shots?\" Rep. Dan Bishop (R-N.C.) asked.\n\n\"Well, that, I think, is something we're still digging into,\" Wray told Bishop.\n\nRep. Jerry Nadler (D-N.Y.) fears violence like this is born from political rhetoric getting out of hand.\n\n\"Could you describe how the FBI looks at this relationship between rhetoric and action, and what you are seeing around the country?\" Nadler asked.\n\n\"There is a right way and a wrong way under the First amendment to express your views,\" Wray said. \"And violence and threats of violence is not the right way.\"\n\nWray promises the FBI will continue to investigate to discover a motive, and if anyone else was involved in this attack on the former president.", "source": {"uri": "wgntv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WGN-TV"}, "authors": [{"uri": "basil_john@wgntv.com", "name": "Basil John", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Thomas Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241773706", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:26:46", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:26:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:25:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.cleveland.com/news/2024/07/what-does-the-fbi-know-about-thomas-matthew-crooks-fbi-director-briefs-ohios-jim-jordan-on-probe-of-trump-assassination-attempt.html", "title": "What does the FBI know about Thomas Matthew Crooks? FBI Director briefs Ohio's Jim Jordan on probe of Trump assassination attempt", "body": "WASHINGTON, D. C. - The day he registered to attend Donald Trump's July 13 campaign rally, the Pennsylvania man who tried to kill the former president searched Google for how far assassin Lee Harvey Oswald was from President John F. Kennedy when he shot him in 1963, the Federal Bureau of Investigation's director told the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday.\n\n\"The attempted assassination of the former president was an attack on our democracy and our democratic process,\" FBI Director Christopher Wray told the committee chaired by Ohio's Jim Jordan. \"The men and women of the FBI will continue to work tirelessly to get to the bottom of what happened. We're bringing all the resources of the FBI to bear ... We're going to leave no stone unturned. The shooter may be deceased, but the FBI investigation is very much ongoing.\"\n\nWray told the committee that his agency's investigation is focusing on would-be assassin Thomas Matthew Crooks, the 20-year-old who wounded Trump's right ear, killed firefighter Corey Comperatore, and injured two other rally attendees before a Secret Service sniper killed him.\n\nJordan told Wray he has \"a lot of unanswered questions\" about the security failures at the rally, that include failure to secure all the buildings and why Trump's security detail was denied requests for extra resources beforehand.\n\n\"We need to know what happened, play by play, moment by moment, second by second, the communications that took place\" during a roughly five minute period between when Crooks was spotted on the roof and when he took shots at Trump, Jordan said.\n\nWray told Jordan other investigations are examining why the Secret Service let Trump take the stage at the rally when witnesses spotted Crooks on a nearby roof before the shooting but said they don't yet know the answer to that.\n\nWray said his investigators have already interviewed around 400 people, gone through Crooks' home and his bedroom, and interviewed his parents. So far, they haven't found that Crooks had any accomplices or that he subscribed to any particular political ideology.\n\nSearches of Crooks' electronic devices indicated that he was broadly interested in public figures. Around July 6, the date he registered to attend the rally and searched for information on Lee Harvey Oswald, Wray said Crooks' became \"very focused\" on Trump and the rally.\n\nHe said the description of Crooks as a \"loner\" seems apt, as he had a shorter list of contacts than you'd see with most people. He said Crooks was a firearms enthusiast who went to a shooting range the day before the assassination attempt and shot an AR-style rifle of the sort used in the crime, though Wray was not sure it was the exact weapon.\n\nAlthough Crooks bought a 5-foot ladder shortly before the assassination attempt and its bloodied receipt was found on his body, Wray said the ladder wasn't found near the roof Crooks climbed to shoot at Trump. He said law enforcement believes he used mechanical equipment on the ground and vertical piping on the side of the building to get on the roof. Investigators found 8 shell casings there.\n\nWray said investigators recovered a drone in Crooks' vehicle, which Crooks used to surveil the fairgrounds for 11 minutes several hours before the rally. He said the drone flew around 200 yards away from the fairgrounds.\n\nLaw enforcement recovered two explosive devices from his vehicle, and one from his residence, which Wray described as \"relatively crude\" with the ability to be detonated remotely. He said Crooks had a transmitter with him when he was killed by law enforcement. He said the receivers on the bombs were turned off, so they probably would not have detonated if Crooks tried to do so from the roof.\n\nWhen Jordan asked him to provide a timeline of when law enforcement became aware of Crooks, Wray said local police spotted him with a range finder less than an hour before the attack and found it suspicious. He said a member of the public spotted Crooks on the roof within a \"handful of minutes\" of the attack, though he wasn't sure if a weapon was observed. Seconds before Crooks opened fire on Trump, he said a local law enforcement officer climbed onto the roof and backed away when Crooks pointed the gun at him.\n\n\"Facts are evolving, things may change, but we are working on a timeline among other things,\" said Wray.", "source": {"uri": "cleveland.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Cleveland"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8241717750", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:44:07", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:44:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:43:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.newsx.com/world/fbi-reveals-details-of-assassination-attempt-on-former-president-trump/", "title": "FBI Reveals Details of Assassination Attempt on Former President Trump", "body": "Why Asian Women? Viral Video Captures Chinese Immigrant's Disturbing Attack in NYC\n\nFBI Director Christopher Wray disclosed new details about an attempted assassination plot against former President Donald Trump. The would-be assassin, Thomas Matthew Crooks, had meticulously planned the attack, including researching the assassination of President John F. Kennedy and flying a drone near the rally venue in Butler, Pennsylvania, just hours before Trump took the stage on July 13.\n\nThe FBI's investigation into Crooks' activities revealed a disturbing level of preparation. On July 6, the day the Trump rally was announced, Crooks conducted an internet search on his laptop, looking up \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy.\" Director Wray highlighted this search during his testimony to the House Judiciary Committee, emphasizing its significance in understanding Crooks' state of mind. \"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray noted. \"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally.\"\n\nCrooks' activities on the day of the rally included flying a drone around the rally area at approximately 4 p.m., just two hours before Trump's appearance. The drone, airborne for about 11 minutes, provided Crooks with a live feed on his phone. After the incident, investigators found the drone in Crooks' car, along with two explosives and another at his home. However, Wray stated that Crooks likely could not have detonated the explosives from the roof where he was ultimately killed by a US Secret Service counter-sniper.\n\nCrooks used an AR-style rifle with a collapsible stock, which he had purchased from his father, to fire approximately eight times at the former president. Initially, officials believed the firearm belonged to Crooks' father, but it was later confirmed that Crooks had bought it legally from him.\n\nDirector Wray pointed out the elevated threat environment in which prominent public officials currently operate, indicating that the FBI's investigation into the incident is ongoing. Despite thorough searches of Crooks' phone, computer, and personal history, investigators have yet to determine his exact motivation. Crooks had no prior contacts with the FBI and was not previously on their radar.\n\nAddressing reports that Crooks had searched for images of specific public officials, Wray clarified that these searches were actually for news articles. \"The shooter appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures in general, but so far we are seeing kind of news articles and things like that,\" Wray explained, emphasizing the difference between searching for news versus targeting individuals specifically.\n\nWray also mentioned a broader security threat posed by Iran, revealing that the FBI had informed the US Secret Service about an Iranian plot to assassinate Trump. While declining to provide specific classified details, Wray stressed the increased brazenness of the Iranian regime and anticipated more such threats in the future.\n\nThe hearing also included a pointed exchange between Democratic Rep. {"uri": "2024-07-431962391", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:45:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:45:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:02:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.aol.com/fbi-director-wray-faces-turn-100227658.html", "title": "FBI Director Wray faces his turn in hot seat over Trump shooting", "body": "FBI Director Wray faces his turn in hot seat over Trump shooting\n\nDavid Morgan\n\nJuly 24, 2024 at 12:02 PM\n\nBy David Morgan\n\nWASHINGTON (Reuters) - FBI Director Christopher Wray will face questions from Congress on Wednesday over the attempted assassination of Donald Trump, but seems likely to escape the withering bipartisan criticism that preceded Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle's resignation.\n\nWray is due to appear before the House Judiciary Committee at 10 a.m. (1400 GMT) to answer questions about the FBI's investigation of suspected shooter, 20-year-old nursing home aide Thomas Crooks, who got close enough to a July 13 campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, to wound the Republican presidential candidate.\n\nTrump was shot in the ear, one rally attendee was killed and another wounded. Crooks was killed by law enforcement. The motive for the shooting remains unclear.\n\nCheatle resigned on Tuesday in the face of bipartisan demands to quit for the agency's failure to prevent the attempted assassination.\n\nBut while Wray is likely to hear demands for details of the incident on Wednesday, the shooting probe could be overshadowed by partisan divisions within the committee.\n\nThe FBI director has long faced opposition from hardline Republicans, some angered over the arrest of Trump supporters who stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, as Congress certified President Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.\n\n\"I would like to hear the truth. But I doubt it that's what we will hear,\" said Republican Representative Harriet Hageman, a Judiciary Committee member who said she would like to see Wray resign as FBI chief.\n\n\"They have circled the wagons and they're going to try to prevent us from getting the information that we need,\" she said.\n\nJudiciary Committee Democrats predicted that the hearing was unlikely to be productive.\n\n\"I'm expecting him to talk about how he's doing his best to keep our country safe. But as you know, it's the Judiciary Committee, so we will have all sorts of sparks fly,\" Democratic Representative Deborah Ross said. \"It's never a productive exercise in Judiciary. It's always a 'gotcha' game.\"\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan; Editing by Scott Malone and Alistair Bell)", "source": {"uri": "aol.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Aol"}, "authors": [{"uri": "david_morgan@aol.com", "name": "David Morgan", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bipartisanship", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Bipartisanship"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kimberly_Cheatle", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kimberly Cheatle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A.
