Kennedy when he assassinated him, the FBI revealed.\n\nSpeaking at a House Judiciary Committee hearing, FBI Director Christopher Wray revealed that Crooks, 20, registered for the Butler, Pennsylvania, rally on July 6 and, the same day, researched details about the Kennedy assassination.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for: 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Wray said. \"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally.\"\n\nCrooks flew a drone around the rally at \"around 4 p.m.,\" likely watching through a live feed. Based on investigators reverse-engineering the flight path, the primary purpose of the drone seems to have been to focus on what was going on behind him.\n\nWray said that while Crooks had explosives in his car and was carrying a detonator, he likely wouldn't have been able to set off the explosives if he had tried to.\n\nCLICK HERE TO READ MORE FROM THE WASHINGTON EXAMINER\n\n\"It looks like because of the on/off position on the receivers, that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" he said.\n\nThe FBI director said there is no evidence of any co-conspirators, and Crooks is believed to have acted alone. {"uri": "2024-07-432677107", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:42:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:42:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:03:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/before-attacking-former-president-trump-the-shooter-looked-up-information-about-jfks-assassination/", "title": "Before attacking former President Trump, the shooter looked up information about JFK's assassination. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "JACKSONVILLE, Fla. - The man who shot former President Donald Trump researched details of Lee Harvey Oswald and the JFK assassination before opening fire on Trump at a Pennsylvania rally.\n\nThis revelation came to light today during a congressional hearing where FBI Director Christopher Wray provided new details about the assassination attempt.\n\nWray revealed that the shooter, Thomas Crooks, had early access to the rally site before Trump took the stage. Newly released video shows the rooftop where Thomas Crooks attempted to assassinate Trump.\n\nAn unidentified agent can be heard on body camera video.\n\n\"I believe the sniper that was seen in pictures was inside that building there, so that's the sniper who sent the original pictures, he's the guy who saw him near the bike.\" an agent said.\n\nIn the video, law enforcement discusses spotting Crooks before losing sight of him.\n\n\"Detain those guys, find out what they know. I'm trying to get good information,\" an agent said.\n\nWray testified before a congressional committee today that Crooks fired 8 shots within five seconds from his father's AR-15 rifle.\n\nHe also said that two hours before the rally, Crooks launched a drone to conduct surveillance of the rally site, approximately 200 yards from the stage.\n\n\"We have discovered a drone that the shooter used, and it's being analyzed by the FBI lab,\" Wray said. \"We think he was livestreaming the event, two hours before the event, yes.\"\n\nInvestigators noted the drone was in the air for approximately 11 minutes, with Crooks watching the live stream on his phone.\n\nWray also revealed that Crooks was prepared for more damage with explosive devices.\n\n\"We've discovered three devices (explosive), two in his vehicle and one at his residence,\" Wray said.\n\nA search of Crooks' digital devices showed he researched news stories and images of several prominent political figures, including Trump and President Joe Biden.\n\nWray cautioned that the motive behind the attempted assassination is still not fully understood.\n\nNews4JAX also spoke with Scott Erickson who is the Director of the Center for Law and Justice at the America First Policy Institute. Erickson has more than 20 years of experience in both state and federal law enforcement.\n\n\"The Secret Service has a no-fail mission, which means they can't fail,\" Erickson said. \"There are no exceptions to that. He said the motive of Thomas Mathhew Crooks firing at Donald Trump at the Pennsylvania rally is not yet revealed.\n\n\"I have been saying for some time now that we are living in an elevated threat environment and tragically the Butler County assassination attempt is another example - a particularly heinous and public one - of what I've been talking about,\" Wray said.\n\nThe hearing had been scheduled well before the shooting, as part of the committee's regular oversight of the FBI and Justice Department.\n\nWray told members of the House Judiciary Committee that Crooks flew a drone near the site of the rally roughly two hours before he opened fire. {"uri": "8241652794", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:56:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:56:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:55:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6745098233222961, "url": "https://www.aa.com.tr/en/americas/fbi-director-details-new-insights-into-trump-assassination-attempt/3284587", "title": "FBI director details new insights into Trump assassination attempt", "body": "Thomas Matthew Crooks used drone 2 hours before opening fire, FBI director says\n\nFBI Director Christopher Wray publicly laid out new details Wednesday about the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump, saying Thomas Matthew Crooks fired eight shots from his rooftop perch and used a drone hours before the shooting.\n\nWray told lawmakers on the House Judiciary Committee that Crooks flew the drone for 11 minutes about two hours before the July 13 rally began. He flew the aircraft, which was recovered in Crooks' car and is being analyzed by the FBI, about 200 yards from the stage where Trump was speaking when he was shot.\n\nThe bureau is also examining three explosive devices, two of which were recovered in Crooks' vehicle, and a third that was recovered from his residence, said Wray. He described the bombs as \"relatively crude devices,\" but acknowledged that they were sophisticated enough to be detonated remotely.\n\nWray said Crooks had a transmitter with him, but said the FBI's review of the devices indicated that their receivers were not turned on.\n\n\"It looks like, because of the on/off position on the receivers that that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" he said.\n\nEight bullet cartridges were recovered from the roof where Crooks opened fire, according to Wray.\n\nAsked if Crooks had any accomplices, Wray said the bureau has no information \"at this time\" to indicate anyone else was involved.\n\nOutrage has mounted on Capitol Hill following the attempt on Trump's life with lawmakers demanding answers for the security lapses that led to the shooting.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson and Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries announced Tuesday the formation of a bipartisan task force to investigate the attempted assassination.\n\nThe panel will attempt to determine what went wrong when a 20-year-old gunman, identified by authorities as Crooks, opened fire as Trump was holding a rally in the state of Pennsylvania, injuring the former president, killing a rallygoer and critically injuring two others.\n\nThe task force will also seek to ensure accountability for security lapses and seek to prevent future failures. {"uri": "2024-07-432511185", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:47:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:47:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T00:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://m.arcamax.com/politics/politicalnews/s-3341704", "title": "FBI director tells House panel details about Trump rally shooting", "body": "WASHINGTON -- FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers Wednesday the agency would leave no stone unturned in its investigation of the gunman behind the assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump.\n\nThe director, testifying before the House Judiciary Committee as part of an oversight hearing for the agency, detailed information that authorities have discovered about the July 13 shooting at a Trump rally in Pennsylvania that injured the former president, left one spectator dead and another two critically injured.\n\nWray testified that they do not yet have a clear picture of the gunman's motive. He said the gunman was interested in public figures, and around July 6 or so became focused on Trump and the rally.\n\nThe shooter on July 6 did a Google search for, \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" Wray said, citing an analysis of a laptop that the investigation tied to the shooter.\n\n\"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally,\" Wray said.\n\nWray said authorities have recovered three explosive devices -- two in the shooter's vehicle and one from his residence. He also told lawmakers the gunman flew a drone at around 3:50 p.m. or 4 p.m. on the day of the shooting, about 200 yards away from the stage. Trump took the stage about two hours later, according to the Associated Press.\n\nThe director also sought to balance expectations of what he could share with lawmakers, while acknowledging the interest in the case from Congress and the public.\n\nWary said he wanted to provide information but also sought to respect the ongoing investigative process and make sure he did not prematurely provide information that turns out to be different later on.\n\n\"We have tried to be transparent with both Congress and the American people as we're going along in the investigation -- frankly unusually so for an ongoing investigation -- given the sheer nature of it,\" Wray said. \"We have provided a lot of information. I expect to continue to provide information.\"\n\nMembers of Congress are searching for answers about the security failures at the rally and have launched multiple inquiries into the assassination attempt. The House is expected to adopt a resolution this week to establish a task force on the shooting.\n\nLawmakers say they are looking for transparency in the wake of the incident, a topic that was on full display earlier this week when then-Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle sidestepped or gave limited answers to a string of lawmaker questions at a House Oversight and Accountability Committee hearing. She has since resigned, a move that came after a wave of criticism about her agency's failure to protect Trump.\n\nAt Wednesday's hearing, Judiciary Chairman Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, said a portion of the country has a \"healthy skepticism\" regarding the FBI's ability to conduct a \"fair, honest, open and transparent investigation.\"\n\n\"They can't tell us who planted the pipe bombs on January 6,\" said Jordan, a frequent critic of the FBI.\n\nWray said the agency is investigating the gunman to find out his motive and his preparations before the shooting, along with whether there were any co-conspirators or accomplices.\n\nUnder questioning from Rep. Dan Bishop, R-N.C., Wray testified they have not developed any evidence at this time to suggest there were any accomplices, cooperators or assisters.\n\n\"But again, the investigation's ongoing,\" Wray said.\n\nRep. Jerrold Nadler, the top Democrat on the Judiciary Committee, used his opening statement to condemn the assassination attempt, saying the incident was \"not just an attack on a man, but an attack on our democracy.\"\n\n\"Political violence erodes the very foundations of our nation, the concepts of freedom of speech, of peaceful transitions of power, of a democratic government at its core,\" he said. \"These cannot exist if political violence is allowed to fester and to go unchecked.\"", "source": {"uri": "m.arcamax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "m.arcamax.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "arcamax_publishing@m.arcamax.com", "name": "ArcaMax Publishing", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Congress", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "United States Congress"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241503317", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:13:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:13:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:12:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13668215/fbi-director-reveals-drone-bombs-trump-shooter-thomas-matthew-crooks.html", "title": "FBI reveals Trump shooter flew drone 200 yards from rally stage", "body": "By Morgan Phillips, Congress Reporter On Capitol Hill For Dailymail.Com\n\nFBI Director Chris Wray stunning revealed bombshell details about former President Donald Trump's assassination attempt, including what devices shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks used.\n\nCrooks, who shot Trump in the ear just 400 feet away from the stage in Butler, Pennsylvania, on July 13 from the roof of a nearby building just outside the security perimeter of the event.\n\nWray revealed that investigators found Crooks had a drone that he used to survey the scene, which was recovered from his car parked nearby.\n\nHe flew the drone around 4 p.m. over the area of the rally close to '200 yards' from the stage to survey the scene.\n\nThe FBI has also recovered three 'explosive devices' in possession of Crooks.\n\nThey were 'relatively crude devices' but had the ability 'to be detonated remotely,' Wray said.\n\nDramatic new footage shows law enforcement standing over the dead body of Donald Trump 's attempted assassin moments after he was shot dead\n\nWray also confirmed the FBI had recovered three 'explosive devices' in possession of Crooks\n\nThe FBI director said eight bullet cartridges had been recovered from the roof where Crooks fired off his shots toward the former president.\n\nAnd he wouldn't rule out that Crooks did not have any accomplices to the crime, saying it's still being looked at by law enforcement.\n\nAs Wray faced questions about why the president was allowed on stage despite the 'threat' being identified 20 minutes before the shots were fired, Wray said, 'we don't know the answer to that.'\n\nRead More Wray to face grilling on Trump shooting after hearing that led Secret Service director to resign\n\nBut he insisted his investigation was not focused on the security breach and the Secret Service failures.\n\n'Our investigation is focused on the shooter and all things related to his attack.'\n\nHis hearing comes days after the former Director of Secret Service Kimberly Cheatle was forced to resign after evading answering rounds of questioning by punting to the FBI in another congressional hearing earlier this week.\n\nWray promised his agency would leave 'no stone unturned' and emphasized that he wanted to provide all the information he had at this point of the ongoing investigation.\n\n'The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing.'\n\nHe also made a reference to the warnings he has been giving Congress for years now about the threats of domestic terrorism.\n\nThe shooting is 'another example, particularly heinous and very public one of what I have been talking about.'\n\nWray again warned about 'passion and heated rhetoric turning into actual violence.'\n\n'We've seen it against public officials of all sorts, we've seen it against law enforcements the number of officers shot and killed in the line of duty is alarming.'\n\n'It's almost every five days that a law enforcement officer is killed in the line of duty, that is an example of the kinds of ways passion and heated rhetoric can bubble over into violence.'\n\nThe Judiciary Committee hearing is expected to focus on both the shooting at the Butler, Pennsylvania, rally and the 'ongoing politicization' of the FBI.\n\nQuestioning on a separate foiled Iranian plot to assassinate Donald Trump is sure to be a topic of contention.\n\nA bombshell report last week revealed the U.S. received intelligence of an Iranian assassination plot in the weeks before Trump was shot at the Pennsylvania rally.\n\nMeanwhile, House Republicans are expected to set up a bipartisan task force to investigate the shooting in a vote this week.\n\nMembers of Congress are expected to demand answers from FBI Director Chris Wray about the Trump assassination attempt on Wednesday\n\nThe FBI and Secret Service revealed to lawmakers last week they spotted shooter Thomas Matthew Crooks as a person of interest a full 62 minutes before he fired a shot.\n\nTwenty minutes passed between the time Secret Service agents spotted Crooks with a gun on the rooftop and he fired shots at the president.\n\nIn a staggering moment, Cheatle admitted on Monday her agents on the ground were warned between two and five times that there was a 'suspicious person' reported before Trump took the stage.\n\nWhile Trump walked around with little more than a bloody ear, Crooks killed former fire chief Corey Comperatore, 50, and critically injured two other rally goers sitting close to where the former president was speaking last weekend before he was neutralized.\n\nThe security chief had faced mounting questions over why an agent was not stationed on the roof from where gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks opened fire on the former president, and why Trump was allowed to take the stage even when a threat was detected.\n\nShe had also been ridiculed for suggesting her agency did not have a presence on the roof because it was 'sloped.'\n\nThe 20-year-old shooter Crooks, was able to get within 160 yards of the stage where the former president was speaking when he opened fire. The building on which he stood was outside the security perimeter, despite clearly being within rifle shooting range.\n\nAnd that was despite the FBI learning of a threat on Trump's life from Iran leading to a bump in security for the former president in the days before the July 13 rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nCheatle said she believed she was the 'best person' to lead the Secret Service at this time, but later acquiesced to the bipartisan demands for her resignation.\n\nOn the day of the rally, Trump walked out onto the stage at 6:02 p.m.\n\nThen at around 6:12 p.m. Crooks' first shots rang out.\n\nCheatle could not tell lawmakers how the shooter had gotten onto the roof.\n\nAt the time of the shooting, law enforcement agents were inside the building, 147 yards away from where Trump stood, but not on top of it.\n\nCheatle curiously claimed no officers had been placed on the roof because it was sloped.\n\n'That building in particular has a sloped roof at its highest point. And so, you know, there's a safety factor that would be considered there that we wouldn't want to put somebody up on a sloped roof,' she told ABC News in an interview Tuesday.\n\nComer said on Fox News Sunday the hearing would go on for six hours and Cheatle would face 'hundreds of questions'\n\n'And so, you know, the decision was made to secure the building, from inside.'\n\nWhat transpired instead was a security nightmare: Thomas Matthew Crooks was able to scale the building and secure his own position, while law enforcement struggled to locate him even amid pressing warnings from members of the Trump crowd. But there wasn't sufficient time to act on the tips, she explained.\n\n'The shooter was actually identified as a potential person of suspicion,' Cheatle said. 'Unfortunately, with the rapid succession of how things unfolded, by the time that individual was eventually located, they were on the rooftop and were able to fire off at the former president.'\n\nShe was referencing claims by witnesses that they alerted law enforcement about the threat, but agents weren't able to eliminate the threat in time. Officials have pointed to the initial responding officer, who lifted himself up on the roof only to lower himself back when the gunman turned his weapon at him.\n\nCheatle has take blame for the fateful security breach, but has denied calls to step down.\n\n'The buck stops with me,' she said.\n\n'It was unacceptable,' she told ABC. 'And it's something that shouldn't happen again.'\n\n'While we give overwhelming thanks to the individual Secret Service agents who did their jobs under immense pressure, this tragedy was preventable. The Secret Service has a zero fail mission, but it failed on July 13 and in the days leading up to the rally,' Comer is also expected to say, as he will again call for Cheatle's resignation.\n\nAlso coming into question on the call was the possible motive for Crooks to commit such an atrocity.\n\nOfficials did not confirm an operating motive and said that his rationale remains a mystery.\n\nAuthorities said that they have yet to find any ideological material that could shine light on why Crooks decided to shoot the former president.\n\nRead More Secret Service Director branded a 'DEI horror show' by Republican as she responds grilling about the agents in Trump's protective detail when he was shot\n\nBut, they did reveal that Crooks operated several accounts on encrypted platforms that they are still working to gain access to.\n\nHere's a timeline of how that fateful July 11 went down:\n\n1PM\n\nThe grounds to the event at Butler Farm Show opened at 1pm.\n\nIt began an hours-long build up that saw MAGA supporters immediately pour into the area to camp out.\n\nSecurity swept the area and set up perimeters, however questions have been raised over how the gunman was able to secure a clear shot just 400ft from the stage.\n\n5PM\n\nAn hour before Trump took the stage at approximately 5pm, former GOP Senate candidate Sean Parnell warmed up the crowd, bringing cheers as he slammed President Biden and his stuttering campaign.\n\nWith the sun still high on a bright day, Trump emerged to 'God Bless the USA' playing over the loudspeakers at 6:03pm, and remained waving and shaking his fist at the crowd for several minutes.\n\n6:11PM\n\nTrump brought out a large graphic with statistics on the migrant crisis at the southern border, and told the crowd at 6:11pm: 'That chart's a couple of months old...'\n\n'If you want to really see something that's sad, take a look at what happened,' Trump continued - before he abruptly grabbed the side of his head as several 'pops' filled the event space.\n\n6:12PM\n\nThe 78-year-old dropped to the floor in an instant as five more shots rang overhead in quick succession, before four Secret Service agents raced to the stage and dove on top of the former president.\n\nStunning images showed Trump cowered on the floor as agents protected him, with blood dripping down his cheek.\n\nSeveral more Secret Service agents continued to flood the stage, while four heavily armed officers lined the perimeter ordering attendees to 'get down.'\n\nThe sniper, sat 400ft across from the rally on an exposed rooftop, fired another shot at the stage a second later while Trump fans streamed out of the bleachers.\n\nSecret Service scrambled to take control of the pandemonium where three attendees were hit, one fatally, within a matter of seconds.\n\n6:13PM\n\nAn emergency room doctor with blood spattered on his shirt later said he sprang into action to perform emergency CPR on one victim.\n\n'The guy had spun around was jammed between the benches and a head shot here. There's lots of blood and he had brain matter,' he told CBS News.\n\n'So I got him together so I got people there really helpful. I did CPR chest compressions as well.'\n\n6:14PM\n\nMicrophones surrounding the stage picked up staggering detail of the urgent response, beginning with one ordering screaming people to 'get down, get down, get down.'\n\nAt the same moment, snipers set up on a roof next to bleachers were seen firing back at the gunman, with Secret Service agents surrounding Trump heard on microphones confirming the moment he was brought down.\n\nDespite the chaos flying around the scene, the rally appeared to hold its breath to see if Trump was hit.\n\nA blood-spattered Donald Trump pumped his fist after being shot in the ear by a sniper, eight minutes after he took the stage at a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania\n\nIn a move that sparked iconic images set to define his candidacy, Trump stood up and triumphantly held his fist in the air, pumping it at his supporters to raucous relief.\n\n'USA, USA, USA,' the crowd chanted at the sight, with a blood-spattered Trump appearing to mouth the word 'fight' several times as Secret Service tried to hurry him away.\n\nWhile getting up off the floor, an agent picked up a white cloth and held it to Trump's bleeding ear, telling him to 'hold that on your head, it's bloody.'\n\n'Are we good?' one male agent says, as another responds quickly: 'Shooter down!'\n\n'Shooter's down. Are we good to move?' one says next. 'We're clear, we're clear, we're clear - let's move.'\n\nTrump repeatedly ordered the agents to 'let me get my shoes', to which one responds: 'I got you sir, I got you.'\n\nThe gunman was killed by agents shortly after opening fire, as footage emerged online showing him appear to be shot in the head while crouched on the roof.\n\nCrooks was seen laying lifeless on the rooftop in a later image, surrounded by law enforcement stood over him.\n\nA number of camouflaged law enforcement officers emerged from the side of the stage, part of a huge law enforcement presence that flooded the area within minutes of the first shot was fired.\n\nAt 6:14pm, Trump was whisked into his motorcade by around dozen Secret Service agents, who formed a protective human shield around him.\n\nBefore he got into his SUV, Trump again raised his fist to signify triumphantly surviving the assassination attempt.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, It appears that the shooter flew the drone for 11 minutes about 2\u00bd hours before opening fire on Trump at his campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. The drone did not fly above the stage where the Republican presidential nominee would later stand, but about 200 yards away, the FBI director testified.\n\nOn July 13, Crooks fired several shots at Trump while perched on nearby warehouse rooftop, striking the former president in the right ear. One rallygoer was killed, and two others were wounded. The gunman was fatally shot by a Secret Service sniper.\n\nWray said the FBI's lab is also examining three explosive devices the shooter had -- two in his vehicle and one at his home.\n\nThe FBI director described the devices as \"relatively crude\" but added \"they did have the ability to be detonated remotely.\" The gunman had a transmitter on him when he was killed, but it appears that if he had tried to detonate the devices from the roof where he was positioned, \"it would not have worked,\" Wray said.\n\nWray said investigators are still working to learn more about the shooter's state of mind, motive and ideology.\n\n\"The attempted assassination of the former president was an attack on our democracy and our democratic process, and we will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind, especially a despicable account of this magnitude,\" Wray said in his opening statement. \"And I want to assure you, and the American people that the men and women of the FBI {"uri": "8242027272", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "22:25:22", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T22:25:22Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T22:24:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://tribune.com.pk/story/2482673/fbi-director-trump-rally-shooter-researched-jfk-assassination-days-before-attack", "title": "FBI Director: Trump Rally Shooter Researched JFK Assassination Days Before Attack", "body": "In a startling revelation during a House Judiciary Committee hearing, FBI Director Christopher Wray disclosed that Thomas Matthew Crooks, the assailant who attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump at a campaign rally on July 13, 2024, had conducted online searches related to the assassination of John F. Kennedy just days before the incident.\n\nWray detailed that analysis of a laptop linked to Crooks showed a Google search on July 6 for \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" referencing Lee Harvey Oswald, the assassin of President Kennedy in 1963.\n\nThe shooting occurred during a campaign event in Butler, Pennsylvania, where Crooks fired shots from a nearby building towards Trump, causing panic and leading to a swift response from Secret Service agents.\n\nAlthough Trump sustained a minor injury to his ear, he was safely evacuated from the venue. Tragically, one person in the audience was killed, and two others were seriously injured in the attack.\n\nAccording to Wray's testimony, Crooks registered to attend the rally on the same day he conducted the search about the Kennedy assassination. Additionally, investigators found a drone in Crooks' vehicle, which he had reportedly flown near the venue approximately two hours before the shooting.\n\nThe FBI director also addressed concerns about explosive devices discovered in Crooks' vehicle and residence. Wray confirmed that these devices were capable of remote detonation, although based on the positioning of their receivers, any attempt to trigger them from the roof during the rally would likely have failed.\n\nWhile Crooks graduated from Bethel Park High School in 2022, located approximately 50 miles from Butler, details surrounding his motives and actions leading up to the attack continue to unfold as part of the ongoing investigation.\n\nThe incident has sparked renewed discussions on security measures at political events and the broader implications of online radicalization and violence.", "source": {"uri": "tribune.com.pk", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Express Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": "pop_culture@tribune.com.pk", "name": "Pop Culture", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241508175", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:15:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:15:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:14:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.theepochtimes.com/us/trump-shooter-had-3-relatively-crude-explosive-devices-flew-drone-near-rally-fbi-director-5692837", "title": "Trump Shooter Had 3 'Relatively Crude' Explosive Devices, Flew Drone Near Rally: FBI Director", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray on Wednesday provided an update on the federal investigation into the assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump at a Butler, Pennsylvania, rally earlier this month.\n\nSo far, the FBI has not identified a motive for suspected gunman Thomas Matthew Crooks' actions. He was shot and killed immediately after opening fire on the rally, killing one rally-goer, injuring two others, and striking former President Trump in the right ear.\n\n\"We have recovered a drone that the shooter used,\" he said at a House Judiciary hearing, adding that it was taken from his vehicle. Three explosive devices were also recovered, he said, describing them as \"relatively crude\" and capable of being detonated remotely.\n\nHours before the rally shooting, Mr. Crooks was flying the drone \"about 200 yards away\" from the rally stage area, the FBI director said.\n\nBoth the FBI and the Pennsylvania State Police have interviewed more than 100 people since the incident, Pennsylvania State Police Col. Christopher Paris told the House Homeland Security Committee on Tuesday.\n\nBoth Col. Paris and Mr. Wray in the separate hearings said that a detonator of sorts was found on the shooter after he was shot and killed by a Secret Service sniper. The police official did not have any knowledge of a possible motive.\n\nDetails about the 20-year-old shooter have remained unclear, including whether he was motivated by a particular political animus or something else. Several former classmates recalled him being quiet, and some claimed he was bullied, although the bullying assertions were refuted by the school he had attended. The school also refuted claims that he was on the high school's rifle team.\n\nMultiple security lapses at the rally, including officials reporting the would-be assassin as a suspicious person before he climbed onto a roof that had a direct line of sight to the former president, have triggered intense scrutiny of the Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned on Tuesday.\n\nDuring hours of questioning, Ms. Cheatle provided little to no insight into why a suspicious person was allowed to climb the roof or why an agent was not stationed on the building from which the gunman fired. In an interview last week, Ms. Cheatle said that no agent was positioned on the roof because it was sloped.\n\nWhen asked about the Secret Service's preparations, Mr. Wray said that the FBI is only focused on the shooter and why he carried out the assassination attempt. He did not make any comments about the protective agency's actions during the incident.\n\nAlso during the hearing, Mr. Wray repeated his warning that the United States is currently in the midst of an \"elevated threat environment,\" saying that the \"particularly heinous\" rally shooting underscores previous warnings he's delivered before Congress.\n\n\"The men and women of the FBI will continue to work tirelessly\" to determine what happened, Mr. Wray told the House Judiciary panel. One rally attendee was killed.\n\nAuthorities are searching for a motive for the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, who was killed by a Secret Service sniper.\n\nWray, a Trump appointee, has been criticized by some Republicans angered over the arrest of Trump supporters who stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, as Congress certified President Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.\n\nDemocrats on the committee predicted that the hearing was unlikely to be productive.\n\n\"I'm expecting him to talk about how he's doing his best to keep our country safe,\" said Rep. {"uri": "8241659292", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:00:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:00:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:00:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-shooter-thomas-crooks-oswald-kennedy-google-search/", "title": "Trump shooter searched \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" a week before rally, FBI director says", "body": "Washington -- The gunman who nearly assassinated former President Donald Trump at a rally in Pennsylvania on July 13 conducted a chilling Google search about the killing of President John F. Kennedy one week before the shooting, FBI Director Christopher Wray told lawmakers during a hearing on Wednesday.\n\nSpeaking before the House Judiciary Committee, Wray said the FBI is still trying to determine the motive of 20-year-old Thomas Crooks, who fired at least eight shots that killed one attendee and wounded Trump and two others. Wray said investigators have gained access to some of Crooks' electronic devices, including his cellphone, but the \"usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology.\"\n\nOne search found on a laptop tied to Crooks stood out, however. On July 6, one week before the Trump rally in Butler County, Pennsylvania, Crooks searched \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nThe search was a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, the assassin who shot and killed Kennedy from a perch on the sixth floor of the Texas Schoolbook Depository in Dallas in 1963. The Warren Commission determined that Oswald was 265.3 feet from Kennedy when he fired the fatal shot.\n\n\"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray said. \"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally.\"\n\nWray said Crooks seemed to become \"very focused on\" Trump and the Butler rally around that time.\n\nCrooks was a roof roughly 400 feet from Trump when he fired the shots that struck Trump in the ear and hit the rally attendees. {"uri": "2024-07-432383848", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:05:47", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:05:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:25:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.aol.com/fbi-director-reveals-details-trump-162511010.html", "title": "FBI director reveals new details on how Trump shooter carried out his attack", "body": "FBI director reveals new details on how Trump shooter carried out his attack\n\nMelissa Chan\n\nJuly 24, 2024 at 6:25 PM\n\nThe gunman who tried to fatally shoot former President Donald Trump may have had a firearm with a collapsible stock, making it easier for him to carry and conceal his weapon, and had researched John F. Kennedy's assassination, the head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified Wednesday.\n\nOn July 6, Thomas Crooks, 20, searched \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" referring to the 1963 presidential assassination, FBI Director Christopher Wray said during a House Judiciary Committee hearing.\n\nThe collapsible stock, Wray said, would explain why witnesses did not see Crooks walking around with a weapon beforehand and why the firearm was not spotted until Crooks was already on the roof.\n\nThe new details reveal how Crooks was able to evade law enforcement.\n\nCrooks fired at least eight shots and also flew a drone about 200 yards away from the event's main stage area in Butler, Pennsylvania, campaign rally site about two hours before it began on July 13, Wray said.\n\nAuthorities recovered the drone in Crooks' vehicle, where they also found a drone controller and two explosive devices that had the ability to be remotely detonated, Wray said.\n\nCrooks had a transmitter on him, the director said, adding that it appears the remote detonation \"would not have worked.\"\n\nEight bullet cartridges were found on the roof with the gunman's body, he said.\n\nWray said Crooks had purchased a ladder that was about 5-ft. tall, according to a bloodied receipt that Crooks had on him, but that the ladder was not found at the scene. The FBI director said it is unclear how Crooks got on the roof.\n\nLawmakers have demanded answers to key questions surrounding the shooting that they say remain unanswered, particularly by former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned Tuesday after apparently failing to fully cooperate with the House Oversight Committee the day before.\n\n\"We need to know play-by-play, moment-by-moment, second-by-second,\" Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray at the start of the Wednesday morning hearing.\n\nThe Congressional committee hearings this week have since begun to yield more information.\n\nOn Tuesday, Pennsylvania State Police Col. Christopher Paris told the House Homeland Security Committee that officers with the Butler County Emergency Services Unit spotted Crooks from a second-story window and left their post to search for him.\n\nParis said Crooks was identified as suspicious before the shooting because he was hanging around but never attempted to enter the rally. That suspicion was later heightened, Paris said, when Crooks was seen with a rangefinder.\n\nThat day, three other people had been identified as suspicious, the state police commissioner said.\n\nCrooks was not designated as an actual threat until seconds before he opened fire, Paris said. {"uri": "8241870259", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:52:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:52:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:51:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.databreachtoday.com/fbi-encountered-encryption-hurdles-in-trump-shooting-probe-a-25836", "title": "FBI Encountered Encryption Hurdles in Trump Shooting Probe", "body": "FBI Director: Phone Data Shows Shooter 'Became Very Focused on President Trump'\n\nA federal investigation into an assassination attempt on Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump encountered \"significant technical challenges\" due to the shooter's use of encrypted devices and platforms, FBI Director Christopher Wray said Wednesday.\n\nSee Also: Reducing Complexity in Healthcare IT\n\nWray told the House Committee on the Judiciary the bureau is \"still exploiting a number of the digital devices\" that Thomas Crooks may have used to help carry out the attempted assassination during a July 13 rally in support of the former president. After gaining access to his cellphone, the FBI discovered how Crooks \"became very focused on President Trump and his rally\" beginning in early July, according to Wray.\n\nGoogle searches on Crooks' phone revealed that he researched Lee Harvey Oswald's assassination of former President John F. Kennedy, Wray told lawmakers, including a search for \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nThe FBI faced challenges \"from an encryption perspective\" when accessing Crooks' phone, according to Wray. The bureau's Pittsburgh field office reportedly tried - and failed - to initially unlock Crooks' Samsung device using a tool developed by the Israeli-based mobile forensics firm Cellebrite.\n\nWhen that didn't work, federal officials at the FBI Laboratory in Quantico, Virginia, called Cellebrite, which shared an unreleased tool that unlocked the device in less than an hour, according to The Washington Post. The FBI did not immediately respond to a request for comment.\n\nWray told lawmakers that after gaining access to his phone, the FBI discovered Crooks was using an encrypted messaging application. The bureau is now in the legal process of requesting and gaining further access to his devices, social media accounts and other digital platforms, Wray said.\n\nThe FBI and Secret Service have not yet indicated a potential motive for Crooks, a 20-year-old with a limited digital footprint who was killed by the Secret Service shortly after the assassination attempt. President Joe Biden has urged the public not to make assumptions about Crooks or his affiliations, and there are conflicting reports about his potential political views.\n\nA debate has been brewing for more than a decade over the ability of law enforcement to access encrypted data from suspected criminals. Law enforcement sharply decried moves in 2014 by Apple and Google to enable encryption by default. End-to-end communication apps have become increasingly the norm since then, despite law enforcement decrying them as posing obstacles. Industry executives and privacy advocates have argued that encryption is a necessary prerequisite to trusting digital devices with sensitive data.", "source": {"uri": "databreachtoday.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "DataBreachToday"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encryption", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Encryption"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cellebrite", "type": "org", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Cellebrite"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241760511", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "18:16:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T18:16:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T18:16:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://www.thedailybeast.com/thomas-matthew-crooks-trump-gunman-searched-details-on-lee-harvey-oswald-before-shooting", "title": "Trump Gunman Googled Details on JFK Assassin Lee Harvey Oswald Before Shooting", "body": "Donald Trump's would-be assassin searched for details about the assassination of John F. Kennedy a week before his own attack, the FBI revealed Wednesday.\n\nThomas Matthew Crooks, 20, used his laptop on July 6 to Google about Kennedy's slaying, the same day Trump's rally in western Pennsylvania was announced, FBI Director Christopher Wray testified in front of the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nWray added that Crooks specifically sought details on how far away Kennedy's assassin, Lee Harvey Oswald, was from the former president when he shot him dead.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for: 'How far away was Oswald from Kennedy,'\" Wray said. \"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind.\"\n\nWray said Crooks registered for the Pennsylvania rally that same day.\n\nOswald landed his fatal shot on Kennedy's motorcade on Nov. 22, 1963, from about 264 feet away. Crooks was a bit further in his assassination attempt, perching himself on a rooftop just under 400 feet from Trump.\n\nThe feds are yet to release a definitive motive for Crooks' attack, but his internet searches have suggested he was depressed and wanted to kill someone prominent. Wray said Crooks was not on the FBI's radar prior to his attack. -\n\n\"We did not have any information about the shooter,\" he said. \"He was not in our holdings before the shooting.\"\n\nWray also revealed Wednesday that Crooks had deployed a drone two hours before the rally started to survey the site. The drone was in the air for about 11 minutes, with the 20-year-old viewing a stream of the aerial view on his phone.\n\nIt was previously reported that a drone was found in Crooks' car after the shooting, along with a pair of explosives that were never detonated.\n\nThose who went to high school with Crooks in Bethel Park, a middle class suburb of Pittsburgh, described him as a recluse with conservative leanings. He was registered as a Republican in voting records.\n\nCrooks' parents have kept a low profile since the July 13 shooting, but his dad, Matthew Crooks, was approached outside a grocery store on Monday by a pair of Fox News reporters. They asked questions about Crooks' motive, but were largely rebuffed.\n\nThe elder Crooks suggested his family would eventually make a statement on the matter, but didn't say when that may happen.\n\n\"We're going to release a statement when our legal counsel advises us to do so -- until then, we have no comment,\" he said. \"We just want to try to take care of ourselves right now. {"uri": "8241725573", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:50:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:50:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:49:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.westernjournal.com/trump-shooter-showed-interest-jfk-assassination-days-leading-rally/", "title": "Trump Shooter Showed Interest in JFK Assassination in Days Leading Up to Rally", "body": "Former President Donald Trump's would-be assassin conducted an online search of the distance Lee Harvey Oswald was from John Kennedy when he shot and killed the president in November 1963, FBI Director Christopher Wray testified Wednesday.\n\nAn analysis of Thomas Matthew Crooks' laptop showed he made that search on July 6, the same day that Trump's July 13 campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, was announced.\n\n\"On July 6, he did a Google search for, quote, how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\n\"That's a search that's obviously significant in terms of his state of mind,\" the FBI director added. \"That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally.\"\n\nWray further testified that a search of Crooks' laptop did not offer further evidence of the shooter's motive beyond having an interest in public figures \"more broadly.\"\n\nHe told lawmakers that Crooks flew a drone about 200 yards from the rally site for 11 minutes at approximately 4 p.m. on July 13. Trump was shot at 6:11 p.m.\n\nWray confirmed that two explosive devices were found in the assailant's car and one more at his home.\n\nThe director said Crooks likely did not have the ability to detonate the ones in his car from the roof where he fired his shots.\n\n\"It looks like because of the on/off position on the receivers, that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" he said, adding the FBI was still investigating the matter.\n\nPodcast host Matt Tardio, who served as a sniper in the Army's Special Forces, posted on X last week that Crooks appeared to have obtained a detonator for a specific firing system.", "source": {"uri": "westernjournal.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Western Journal"}, "authors": [{"uri": "randy_desoto@westernjournal.com", "name": "Randy DeSoto", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. {"uri": "8241550995", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:44:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:44:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:43:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://www.mediaite.com/news/fbi-director-testifies-trump-shooter-flew-drone-around-rally-area-two-hours-before-assassination-attempt/", "title": "FBI Director Testifies Trump Shooter Flew Drone Around Rally Area Two Hours Before Assassination Attempt", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray testified Wednesday in a House Judiciary Committee hearing that the man who attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump flew a drone around the Butler, Pennsylvania rally area in the hours before the shooting.\n\nThomas Matthew Crooks, age 20, climbed on top of the roof of a nearby building a fired multiple shots at Trump, grazing the former president's ear and killing one rally attendee and wounding others before being shot and killed by a Secret Service sniper. Bipartisan outrage over the failure to include the building Crooks used in the security perimeter or otherwise prevent him from being able to climb onto the roof has already led to the resignation of Secret Service director Kimberly Cheatle and investigations are ongoing.\n\nWray testified that the FBI had \"recovered a drone that the shooter appears to have used,\" which was \"being exploited and analyzed by the FBI lab.\" The drone was in the shooter's vehicle along with its controller during the shooting, and it was recovered there by officials investigating the scene.\n\nHe added that it appeared that Crooks had flown the drone for about 11 minutes around \"3:50 pm, 4:00 pm, in that window, on the day of the shooting\" around the area, not the stage itself where Trump would speak roughly two hours later, but the vicinity \"about 200 yards, give or take, away from that.\"\n\nThe FBI believed Crooks had been live streaming to view the footage, said Wray, noting that conclusion was \"qualified because of our ongoing review.\"\n\nWray continued his testimony, talking about the explosive devices found in the shooter's car, telling the committee that the FBI had recovered three devices in his vehicle and one at his residence. He described them as \"relatively crude devices themselves, but they did have the ability to be detonated remotely.\" Investigators also found in Crooks' vehicle two of the receivers for those explosive devices, and another receiver was found on him.\n\nAgain emphasizing that the review was \"ongoing\" and he could not say for certain, but it did appear that if Crooks had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, \"it would not have worked, but that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous.\"", "source": {"uri": "mediaite.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Mediaite"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Unmanned aerial vehicle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_Secret_Service", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "United States Secret Service"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Attempted_assassination_of_Ronald_Reagan", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Attempted assassination of Ronald Reagan"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "2024-07-431939767", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "10:27:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T10:27:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T06:02:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/top-news/articles/2024-07-24/fbi-director-wray-faces-his-turn-in-hot-seat-over-trump-shooting", "title": "FBI Director Wray Faces His Turn in Hot Seat Over Trump Shooting", "body": "WASHINGTON (Reuters) - FBI Director Christopher Wray will face questions from Congress on Wednesday over the attempted assassination of Donald Trump, but seems likely to escape the withering bipartisan criticism that preceded Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle's resignation.\n\nWray is due to appear before the House Judiciary Committee at 10 a.m. (1400 GMT) to answer questions about the FBI's investigation of suspected shooter, 20-year-old nursing home aide Thomas Crooks, who got close enough to a July 13 campaign rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, to wound the Republican presidential candidate.\n\nTrump was shot in the ear, one rally attendee was killed and another wounded. Crooks was killed by law enforcement. The motive for the shooting remains unclear.\n\nCheatle resigned on Tuesday in the face of bipartisan demands to quit for the agency's failure to prevent the attempted assassination.\n\nBut while Wray is likely to hear demands for details of the incident on Wednesday, the shooting probe could be overshadowed by partisan divisions within the committee.\n\nThe FBI director has long faced opposition from hardline Republicans, some angered over the arrest of Trump supporters who stormed the U.S. Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, as Congress certified President Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.\n\n\"I would like to hear the truth. But I doubt it that's what we will hear,\" said Republican Representative Harriet Hageman, a Judiciary Committee member who said she would like to see Wray resign as FBI chief.\n\n\"They have circled the wagons and they're going to try to prevent us from getting the information that we need,\" she said.\n\nJudiciary Committee Democrats predicted that the hearing was unlikely to be productive.\n\n\"I'm expecting him to talk about how he's doing his best to keep our country safe. But as you know, it's the Judiciary Committee, so we will have all sorts of sparks fly,\" Democratic Representative Deborah Ross said. \"It's never a productive exercise in Judiciary. It's always a 'gotcha' game.\"\n\n(Reporting by David Morgan; Editing by Scott Malone and Alistair Bell)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Thomas Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Assassination"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bipartisanship", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Bipartisanship"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kimberly_Cheatle", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Kimberly Cheatle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "2024-07-432584446", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:33:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:33:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:32:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://www.pcmag.com/news/encryption-slows-the-fbis-search-of-trump-shooters-accounts-devices", "title": "Encryption Slows the FBI's Search of Trump Shooter's Accounts, Devices", "body": "Despite unlocking the Trump shooter's phone, the FBI's investigation into the assassination attempt is facing another encryption hurdle, this time involving messaging apps.\n\nIn a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, FBI Director Christopher Wray said federal agents have been trying to determine a motive for the shooting in Butler, Pennsylvania, earlier this month, which left one dead and several people injured, including former President Donald Trump. Agents have been examining all the devices and social media accounts used by the shooter, 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks.\n\n\"Once we got on the phone, it turned out he was using some encrypted messaging applications,\" Wray said today.\n\nWray didn't identify the messaging apps, but he said encrypted apps are commonplace and can prevent investigators from accessing a user's personal messages. Two of the most popular encrypted messaging apps, WhatsApp and Signal, can be configured to require the account holder's fingerprint or passcode to unlock access.\n\nThe FBI is \"still exploiting a number of the digital devices\" that belonged to Crooks, including a laptop, Wray said. But federal investigators have yet to access all devices and accounts.\n\n\"Within his various [online] accounts, we've been able to get access to some of them, but some of them we're still waiting on, some of them we may never get access to because of the encryption issue that presents an increasingly vexing barrier for law enforcement,\" he added.\n\nIt's a familiar refrain. The FBI has long pushed US companies, such as Apple, to introduce a backdoor capable of helping them access locked phones and encrypted communications. However, the tech industry has resisted such pleas, saying this access risks the privacy of all users, not just criminal suspects.\n\nIn the Crooks case, the FBI used an Israeli digital forensics firm called Cellebrite to help them unlock the shooter's Samsung phone. The agency has also subpoenaed tech companies for legal access to Crooks' online accounts when end-to-end encryption isn't used.\n\n\"I think it is fair to say that we do not yet have a clear picture of his motive,\" Wray said during the hearing, later adding: \"What I can say is that the shooter appears to have done a lot of searches of public figures in general. But so far, we're seeing news articles and things like that.\"\n\nWray also noted that Crooks conducted a Google search on July 6 related to the assassination of former President John F. Kennedy, who was killed by Lee Harvey Oswald in 1963. Specifically, Wray said Crooks searched: \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy.\"", "source": {"uri": "pcmag.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "PC Magazine"}, "authors": [{"uri": "michael_kan@pcmag.com", "name": "Michael Kan", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Instant_messaging", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Instant messaging"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Encryption", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Encryption"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F. Two of the most popular encrypted messaging apps, WhatsApp and Signal, can be configured to require the account holder's fingerprint or passcode to unlock access.\n\nThe FBI is \"still exploiting a number of the digital devices\" that belonged to Crooks, including a laptop, Wray said. But federal investigators have yet to access all devices and accounts.\n\n\"Within his various [online] accounts, we've been able to get access to some of them, but some of them we're still waiting on, some of them we may never get access to because of the encryption issue that presents an increasingly vexing barrier for law enforcement,\" he added.\n\nIt's a familiar refrain. The FBI has long pushed US companies, such as Apple, to introduce a backdoor capable of helping them access locked phones and encrypted communications. However, the tech industry has resisted such pleas, saying this access risks the privacy of all users, not just criminal suspects.\n\nIn the Crooks case, the FBI used an Israeli digital forensics firm called Cellebrite to help them unlock the shooter's Samsung phone. {"uri": "2024-07-432508149", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:43:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:43:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:23:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.615686297416687, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/24/trump-shooter-was-avid-gun-hobbyist-who-zeroed-in-/", "title": "Trump shooter was 'avid' gun hobbyist who zeroed in on former president a week before attack", "body": "Director Wray shares FBI's profile of gunman: no accomplices, no known political motives\n\nThe man who tried to assassinate former President Donald Trump was a gun enthusiast who seemed to be interested in public figures, and only recently began to zero in on Mr. Trump as a target for an attack, the FBI said Wednesday.\n\nDirector Christopher Wray delivered his agents' latest assessment of Thomas Matthew Crooks in testimony to Congress, saying they have yet to uncover any deep ideological leanings that would explain the attempt to slay Mr. Trump.\n\nInstead, they've found some troubling internet activity including a Google search to determine how far away Lee Harvey Oswald was when he killed President Kennedy in 1963. That search took place on July 6, the same day the shooter registered to attend Mr. Trump's rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nIt's also around the time the shooter made his first visit to scout out the rally site, staying for about 20 minutes.\n\nThe day before the shooting, the man went to a gun range where he practiced with an AR-15-style rifle. On July 13, he made a morning visit to the rally site, staying for about 70 minutes, then left and returned in the afternoon.\n\nHe flew a drone around part of the site at 4 p.m., then two hours later climbed up a pipe on the outside of the AGR building, where he made his sniper's perch and fired at least eight shots at Mr. Trump.\n\nSEE ALSO: Trump shooter searched for distance of Kennedy assassination\n\nThe former president was bloodied in the ear by one round. One rally-goer was killed and two others were critically wounded.\n\nMr. Wray said the shooter's social media and other usual avenues haven't revealed much about motives, other than the fact that his internet searches spanned both political parties and even foreign officials.\n\n\"It does appear fairly clear that he was interested in public figures kind of more broadly and, I think this is important, starting somewhere around July 6 or so he became very focused on former President Trump and this rally,\" Mr. Wray said.\n\nThat's also when he did his search for the distance -- about 180 feet -- at which Oswald took the shot that killed Kennedy. He then registered to attend the rally.\n\nMr. Wray said agents see that search as important to unraveling the shooter's state of mind.\n\nMr. Wray said agents now believe the shooter got to the roof of the building by using \"some mechanical equipment\" and a vertical pipe to climb the side of the building.\n\nSEE ALSO: Trump shooter flew drone just two hours before assassination attempt, says FBI chief\n\n\"In other words, we do not believe he used a ladder to get up there,\" the FBI chief said.\n\nAt some point, law enforcement became suspicious and then alarmed over the man's behavior. Just before the 6:11 p.m. shooting, a local law enforcement officer tried to climb to the roof. The shooter turned his weapon on the officer, who retreated, then opened fire toward Mr. Trump, according to Mr. Wray's preliminary timeline.\n\nThe director said the Secret Service counter-snipers were alerted to the gunman just before the first shot.\n\nHe confirmed reports that the shooter flew a drone at the rally site about two hours before Mr. Trump took the stage. The FBI has the drone.\n\nAgents also recovered three explosives -- two from the shooter's vehicle and one from his residence. Mr. Wray described them as relatively crude, though he said they were set up to be remotely detonated, and he had a detonating transmitter with him on the rooftop. But because of the on-off switch, it does not appear that he could actually have detonated the devices from the rooftop.\n\nMr. Wray said agents found eight shell casings at the scene of the shooting, suggesting a total of eight rounds fired on the president.\n\nThe director described the shooter, who was killed by a Secret Service sniper, as a \"fairly avid shooting hobbyist\" and his gun as an AR-15 style rifle that he bought from his father. All told, some 14 guns were in the home where the shooter lived with his parents.\n\nMr. Wray, in response to a question about whether the parents knew anything, said they have been cooperating in the investigation. Indeed, Mr. Wray said there are no indications that the shooter was working with accomplices at all.\n\nQuestions have swirled over the Secret Service's handling of Mr. Trump's security and the fact that a gunman was able to get a line of sight to the former president from an undefended rooftop. Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned this week after calls from lawmakers in both parties to quit.\n\nSen. Charles E. Grassley, Iowa Republican, revealed Tuesday that a counter-drone operative was listed on the Secret Service's personnel list for the Butler event. Mr. Grassley prodded Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas, who oversees the Secret Service, on whether the agency detected the shooter's drone flight and what steps were taken.\n\nOther Republicans have complained that it took too much time between authorities identifying the shooter as a suspicious person and neutralizing him -- only after he had fired at least eight shots.\n\nMr. Wray said those are generally issues for the Secret Service, and his agency is involved in the investigation into the shooter. But he did shoot down suggestions that Secret Service counter-snipers were aware of the man as a threat for some minutes before they took him out.", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "stephen_dinan@washingtontimes.com", "name": "Stephen Dinan", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lee_Harvey_Oswald", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Lee Harvey Oswald"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/John_F._Kennedy", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "John F. The drone flew about 3:50 p.m. for about 11 minutes, apparently livestreaming over an area about 200 yards from the stage where Trump spoke, Wray said.\n\nThe FBI found two explosives in the car and one in the shooter's residence, Wray said. The devices were connected to receivers and the gunman had a receiver with him when he was killed by a Secret Service sniper, but the equipment didn't appear capable of setting off the explosive, Wray said.\n\n\"There is a whole lot of work under way and still a lot of work left to do,\" Wray said. \"We're going to leave no stone unturned. The shooter may be deceased but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing.\"\n\nThe chair, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, said lawmakers want to know more about why Trump's campaign team was denied extra security in the weeks before the rally, why buildings weren't secured at the rally and why Trump was allowed on stage despite the presence of a suspicious person seen by the crowd with a range-finder. Jordan focused on five minutes between 6:09 p.m., when the gunman was identified and 6:14 p.m., when Trump was led wounded from the stage.\n\n\"We need to know what happened play by play, moment by moment, second by second - communications that took place - during that critical five minutes,\" Jordan said.\n\nThe chair, Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, said lawmakers want to know more about why Trump's campaign team was denied extra security in the weeks before the rally, why buildings weren't secured at the rally and why Trump was allowed on stage despite the presence of a suspicious person sin the crowd with a range-finder. Jordan focused on five minutes between 6:09 p.m., when the gunman was identified and 6:14 p.m., when Trump was led wounded from the stage.\n\n\"We need to know what happened play by play, moment by moment, second by second - communications that took place - during that critical five minutes,\" Jordan said.\n\nWray's testimony comes a day after former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned over what she acknowledged was a \"colossal failure\" to protect Trump at a rally July 13 in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nThe House Oversight and Accountability Committee excoriated Cheatle during a hearing Monday for having no explanation for how a gunman was able to climb onto the roof of a building within 150 yards of the former president and fire eight shots, one of which hit Trump in the ear. One rally attendee was killed.\n\nAuthorities are searching for a motive for the shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, who was killed by a Secret Service sniper.\n\nWray, a Trump appointee, has been criticized by some Republicans angered over the arrest of Trump supporters who stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, as Congress certified President Joe Biden's 2020 election victory.\n\nDemocrats on the committee predicted that the hearing was unlikely to be productive.\n\n\"I'm expecting him to talk about how he's doing his best to keep our country safe,\" said Rep. {"uri": "8241645397", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:50:21", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:50:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:49:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/24/fbi-director-christopher-wray-reveals-new-details-on-how-trump-shooter-carried-out-his-attack/", "title": "FBI Director Christopher Wray reveals new details on how Trump shooter carried out his attack", "body": "The gunman who tried to fatally shoot former President Donald Trump may have had a firearm with a collapsible stock, making it easier for him to carry and conceal his weapon, and had researched John F. Kennedy's assassination, the head of the Federal Bureau of Investigation testified Wednesday.\n\nOn July 6, Thomas Crooks, 20, searched \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" referring to the 1963 presidential assassination, FBI Director Christopher Wray said during a House Judiciary Committee hearing.\n\nThe collapsible stock, Wray said, would explain why witnesses did not see Crooks walking around with a weapon beforehand and why the firearm was not spotted until Crooks was already on the roof.\n\nThe new details reveal how Crooks was able to evade law enforcement.\n\nCrooks fired at least eight shots and also flew a drone about 200 yards away from the event's main stage area in Butler, Pennsylvania, campaign rally site about two hours before it began on July 13, Wray said.\n\nAuthorities recovered the drone in Crooks' vehicle, where they also found a drone controller and two explosive devices that had the ability to be remotely detonated, Wray said.\n\nCrooks had a transmitter on him, the director said, adding that it appears the remote detonation \"would not have worked.\"\n\nEight bullet cartridges were found on the roof with the gunman's body, he said.\n\nWray said Crooks had purchased a ladder that was about 5-ft. tall, according to a bloodied receipt that Crooks had on him, but that the ladder was not found at the scene. The FBI director said it is unclear how Crooks got on the roof.\n\nLawmakers have demanded answers to key questions surrounding the shooting that they say remain unanswered, particularly by former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle, who resigned Tuesday after apparently failing to fully cooperate with the House Oversight Committee the day before.\n\n\"We need to know play-by-play, moment-by-moment, second-by-second,\" Rep. Jim Jordan, R-Ohio, told Wray at the start of the Wednesday morning hearing.\n\nThe Congressional committee hearings this week have since begun to yield more information.\n\nOn Tuesday, Pennsylvania State Police Col. Christopher Paris told the House Homeland Security Committee that officers with the Butler County Emergency Services Unit spotted Crooks from a second-story window and left their post to search for him.\n\nParis said Crooks was identified as suspicious before the shooting because he was hanging around but never attempted to enter the rally. That suspicion was later heightened, Paris said, when Crooks was seen with a rangefinder.\n\nThat day, three other people had been identified as suspicious, the state police commissioner said.\n\nCrooks was not designated as an actual threat until seconds before he opened fire, Paris said. {"uri": "8241688366", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:21:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:21:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:20:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://dailycallernewsfoundation.org/2024/07/24/trump-shooter-searched-how-far-away-jfk-assassin-was-christopher-wray-reveals/", "title": "Trump Shooter Searched 'How Far Away' JFK Assassin Was, Christopher Wray Reveals", "body": "The 20-year-old who attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump searched online for details about the distance from which John F. Kennedy was assassinated, FBI Director Christopher Wray disclosed on Wednesday.\n\nThomas Michael Crooks got within rifle range of Trump by climbing to the roof of a building near the former president's rally, killing former volunteer fire chief Corey Comperatore and injuring two other attendees, 57-year-old David Dutch and 74-year-old James Copenhaver. Wray, during a House Judiciary Committee hearing, said the FBI's investigation of Crooks' devices yielded a Google search about Lee Harvey Oswald's distance from Kennedy when he assassinated him.\n\nWATCH:\n\n\"One of the things that I can share here today that has not been shared yet is that we've, just in the last couple days, found that, from our review ... analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter, reveals that on July 6, he did a Google search for 'how far away was Oswald from Kennedy?' And so that's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Wray said.\n\nThe FBI director added that the search took place on the same date Crooks seems to have registered for the Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, where he attempted to assassinate the former president.\n\nU.S. Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle resigned on Tuesday in the aftermath of the assassination attempt and her evasive testimony before the House Oversight Committee on Monday.\n\n\"I take full responsibility for the security lapse,\" Cheatle said in an email to staff obtained by the Associated Press on Tuesday. \"In light of recent events, it is with a heavy heart that I have made the difficult decision to step down as your director.", "source": {"uri": "dailycallernewsfoundation.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "dailycallernewsfoundation.org"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assassination_of_John_F._Kennedy", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Assassination of John F.
