{"uri": "8241861801", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:43:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:43:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:43:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6000000238418579, "url": "https://www.aninews.in/news/world/us/fbi-director-grilled-by-lawmakers-on-trump-rally-shooting-incident20240725011113/", "title": "FBI Director grilled by lawmakers on Trump rally shooting incident", "body": "Washington, DC [US], July 25 (ANI): FBI Director Christopher Wray found himself under intense scrutiny from United States lawmakers regarding the recent assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump during a rally in Pennsylvania earlier this month, Al Jazeera reported.\n\nAddressing the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, Wray vowed that the FBI would leave \"no stone unturned\" in uncovering the truth behind the attack, which he described as \"an attack on our democracy and our democratic process\".\n\n\"We will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind, especially a despicable account of this magnitude,\" he said, adding, \"And I want to assure you and the American people that the men and women of the FBI will continue to work tirelessly to get to the bottom of what happened.\"\n\nThe shooting at Trump's rally on July 13 shocked the nation, resulting in the death of one attendee and leaving two others seriously injured. The assailant, identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, allegedly fired a shot that grazed Trump's ear from a rooftop position with a clear line of sight to the stage. The FBI swiftly labelled the incident as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination, although the motive behind Crooks's actions remained unclear, Al Jazeera.\n\nDuring his testimony, Wray disclosed significant details uncovered by the FBI's ongoing investigation. He revealed that a drone had been recovered from Crooks's vehicle, which was flown approximately 200 yards from the rally stage prior to the event.\n\n\"We're going to leave no stone unturned. The shooter might be deceased, but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing,\" the director said.\n\nThe FBI's findings so far included unsettling discoveries on Crooks's phone, where investigators found photos of Trump, President Joe Biden, and other officials. Additionally, Crooks had reportedly researched the dates of the Democratic National Convention and Trump's scheduled appearances.\n\nHowever, despite piecing together a detailed timeline of Crooks's activities and online searches, the exact motive for targeting Trump remained elusive, Al Jazeera reported.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said.\n\nThe House Judiciary Committee, chaired by Republican Congressman Jim Jordan, pressed Wray on various aspects of the investigation, including security lapses at the rally site and the presence of explosives found in Crooks's vehicle.\n\n\"We hope to learn more today from Director Wray about the shooter: his use of the drone, the explosives that were in his car, how he got on the roof and a host of other questions,\" Jordan said, adding, \"It is our hope that Director Wray's testimony can begin to give answers to the American people about all these questions and concerns.\"\n\nRepresentative Jerry Nadler, the committee's ranking Democrat, \"unequivocally and unabashedly\" condemned the assassination attempt while contextualizing it within a broader narrative of political violence in America.\n\n\"If you think that this one assassin's bullet was a bolt out of the blue and not part of a wave of violence that has threatened this nation for years, then you have missed the point,\" Nadler said.\n\nWray's appearance before lawmakers came just a day after the resignation of US Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle, who faced significant criticism over security protocols at the Trump rally. The scrutiny extended to the FBI's handling of the investigation, with some lawmakers expressing skepticism over the bureau's assertion that Crooks acted without a clear ideological motive.\n\nDespite challenges and criticism, Wray affirmed the FBI's dedication to uncovering the truth, citing parallels to historical incidents of political violence in American history, Al Jazeera reported. Kennedy on the same day he registered for the rally.\n\nWray testified that Crooks had fired at least eight rounds from a rooftop near the July 13 event, wounding Trump in the ear, killing one attendee, and injuring two others. (WSAU) - FBI Director Christopher Wray was on Capitol Hill testifying about the assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump last week.\n\nAccording to the New York Post, when asked about details about what the bureau has learned about Thomas Crooks so far, he said he came prepared to take Trump's life by studying another infamous assassin, saying, \"We've just in the last couple of days found that from our review... Analysis of a laptop that the investigation ties to the shooter reveals that on July 6, he did a Google search for \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\n\"That's a search that is obviously significant in terms of his state of mind. That is the same day that it appears that he registered for the Butler rally,\" Wray continued.\n\nAn analysis conducted by law enforcement following the attempt found Crooks opened fire on the stage from 130 yards away, while Oswald successfully assassinated former President John F. Kennedy from 88 yards away.\n\nWray further told the House Judiciary Committee that on July 13, between 3:50 and 4 p.m., or almost two hours before Trump's address started, Crooks controlled a drone about 200 yards from the main stage and was \"live-streaming the footage,\" while also having three \"relatively crude\" explosive devices in his vehicle that had the capability of being detonated remotely with a transmitter that was found in Crooks' possession after he was killed by a Secret-Service Counter Sniper.", "source": {"uri": "wsau.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WSAU News/Talk 550 AM \u00b7 99.9 FM | Wausau, Stevens Point"}, "authors": [{"uri": "thomas_schumacher@wsau.com", "name": "Thomas Schumacher", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "2024-07-432270219", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:13:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:13:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T10:59:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/jul/24/trump-shooter-flew-drone-just-two-hours-before-ass/", "title": "Trump shooter flew drone just two hours before assassination attempt, says FBI chief", "body": "The man who came within an inch of killing former President Donald Trump flew a drone near the rally site just two hours before Mr. Trump took the stage, FBI Director Christopher A. Wray revealed Wednesday.\n\nMr. Wray, testifying to Congress, also said the shooter fired at least eight rounds and had constructed at least three explosive devices, including two that were found in his vehicle at the rally in Butler, Pennsylvania.\n\nFBI agents still haven't found any evidence that anyone else was involved in planning or executing the shooting, Mr. Wray said. The shooter, Thomas Matthew Crooks, 20, was shot and killed by Secret Service.\n\nThe drone flight was particularly troubling for lawmakers who say the Secret Service failed to deliver quality protection to Mr. Trump, a former president and Republicans' nominee for president in this year's election.\n\nMr. Wray said the shooter appears to have flown the drone about 200 yards from the stage at around 4 p.m. on July 13. Mr. Trump would take the stage roughly two hours later, and would be shot at -- and bloodied by a round to his right ear -- at 6:11 p.m.\n\n\"We think, but we do not know ... that he was live-stream viewing the footage,\" Mr. Wray told the House Judiciary Committee.\n\nSEE ALSO: House committee grills FBI director about retaliation against whistleblowers, also Trump shooting\n\nKimberly Cheatle, the now-resigned director of the Secret Service, told Congress on Monday that she couldn't talk about the shooter's drone activities, nor would she say whether her own agency flew drones to try to help secure the site.\n\nSen. Charles E. Grassley, Iowa Republican, this week revealed that a counter-drone operator was listed on the Secret Service's personnel list for the event. {"uri": "8241645391", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "16:51:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T16:51:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T16:49:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/24/gunman-searched-how-far-away-was-oswald-from-kennedy-before-trump-shooting/", "title": "Gunman Searched 'How Far Away Was Oswald From Kennedy?' Before Trump Shooting", "body": "Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, disclosed on Wednesday that a gunman who tried to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump searched on Google a week before the shooting for \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nMr. Wray added that the revelation appeared to be a possible first indication that the shooter began to contemplate an assassination. That same day, he registered to attend the rally in Butler, Pa., where Mr. Trump was set to speak.\n\n\"That's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Mr. Wray said.\n\nIn addition, Mr. Wray said the gunman had visited the area a week before the rally, spending about 20 minutes at the scene. He returned twice on the day of the shooting, for about 70 minutes in the morning and then later that afternoon, when he appeared to fly a drone in the vicinity for about 11 minutes.\n\n\"It appears that around 3:50 p.m., 4:00, in that window, on the day of the shooting, that the shooter was flying the drone around the area,\" Mr. Wray said during his testimony, noting that it was \"not over the stage, but about 200 yards, give or take, away from that.\"\n\nThe shooting left Mr. Trump's ear bloodied, killed a rallygoer who had been sitting in the stands and seriously injured two others.\n\nSecret Service snipers killed the gunman, Thomas Crooks, 20, after locating him on a nearby roof. Mr. Crooks was armed with an AR-15-style rifle and had magazines for the rifle and a bulletproof vest in his car along with the drone. The F.B.I. managed to reconstruct the drone's flight's path, though it did not recover any video or pictures from the drone.\n\nThe gunman's father had purchased the gun more than a decade ago, but Mr. Wray also disclosed on Wednesday that the son bought the rifle from his father and that the family had 14 firearms in the house.\n\nMr. Wray said the rifle used had a collapsible stock, perhaps making the gunman less noticeable, and he confirmed that the F.B.I. recovered eight bullet cartridges from the roof where the gunman opened fire.\n\nSo far, Mr. Wray said, the F.B.I. has not found a motive for the shooting even as the investigation evolves. But the bureau continues to examine the gunman's electronic devices for additional clues about Mr. Crooks's mind-set and movements beforehand.\n\n\"We're hoping to learn more,\" Mr. Wray said. \"It's fair to say we do not yet have a clear picture of his motive.\"\n\nThe shooter, Mr. Wray said, reviewed news stories that mentioned public figures, but the director did not draw any conclusions from his search history.\n\nWhile the F.B.I. typically does not discuss continuing investigations, the extraordinary circumstances and public interest in the failed assassination attempt allow the bureau to inform the public.\n\n\"The attempted assassination of the former president was an attack on our democracy,\" Mr. Wray said. \"I recognize the congressional and public interest in this case.\"\n\nIndeed, Mr. Wray seemed eager to provide new information at the outset but sat through dueling opening statements rife with partisan pronouncements. Only about 30 minutes into the hearing did he have an opening to disclose more details about the drone found in the gunman's car.\n\nHe added that the investigation was evolving and that the gunman used encrypted messaging applications. He described explosive devices found in the gunman's car as \"crude\" but said they were able to be detonated remotely.\n\nLingering questions remain about the gunman's violent trajectory and when he actually started to plan the shooting. Mr. Wray said he appeared to be a loner with a small number of contacts in his phone.\n\nThe F.B.I. has conducted more than 400 interviews, and scores of bureau personnel are involved in the investigation.\n\nDuring testimony before Congress on Monday, Kimberly A. Cheatle, then the head of the Secret Service, faced withering questions from both sides of the political aisle, repeatedly declining to answer questions about the security lapses that led to the assassination attempt.\n\nOfficials investigating the matter, including lawmakers in hearings this week, have repeatedly questioned why the Secret Service's security perimeter did not include the building from which the gunman eventually fired and why no law enforcement officer was stationed there during the rally. They have also asked why Mr. Trump was allowed to take the stage when law enforcement, including the Secret Service and the local police, was searching for a suspicious person.\n\nOn Tuesday, in the face of mounting calls that she step down, Ms. Cheatle resigned.\n\nMr. Wray has not faced the same criticism, since the F.B.I. was not directly involved in protecting the president on July 13.\n\nStill, Mr. Wray was drawn into the political fray when asked about Project 2025, a set of conservative policy proposals for a future Republican administration that has angered Democrats.\n\nAsked about possible changes to the F.B.I. under Project 2025, Mr. Wray said the bureau needs to retain its independence. He also said that answering directly to the president would not be a \"wise reporting structure.\"\n\nIn the hearing on Monday with Ms. Cheatle, the Republican chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative Michael R. Turner of Ohio, said that Mr. Wray was shocked that information about an Iranian plot to kill Mr. Trump was not included in the Secret Service threat assessment for Mr. Trump's rally in Butler.\n\nMr. Wray declined to discuss specific details about the Iranian threat or other national security threats.\n\n\"We need to recognize the brazenness of the Iranian regime,\" he said, adding that there was a process for sharing such information to the Secret Service in a timely way.", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "DNyuz"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Unmanned aerial vehicle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rifle", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Rifle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/.mr", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": ".mr"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garth_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Garth Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Thomas Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AR-15\u2013style_rifle", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "AR-15\u2013style rifle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241929680", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "20:45:26", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T20:45:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:44:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://www.cbsnews.com/news/trump-shooting-house-task-force-vote/", "title": "House to vote on bipartisan task force to investigate Trump assassination attempt", "body": "Washington -- The House is set to vote Wednesday night to establish a bipartisan task force to investigate the attempted assassination of former President Donald Trump at a Pennsylvania rally.\n\nHouse Speaker Mike Johnson and Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries announced the panel earlier this week and said it will have the full investigative authority of the House, including subpoena power. It will be composed of seven Republicans and six Democrats chosen by Johnson and Jeffries, who have not yet announced their selections.\n\nThe House Freedom Caucus, a group of far-right members, urged House leadership to keep at least one Democrat, Rep. Bennie Thompson of Mississippi, off the task force.\n\nJohnson, a Louisiana Republican, and Jeffries, a New York Democrat, said the task force will seek to understand what went wrong on July 13, the day of the shooting; ensure accountability; and prevent such a failure by law enforcement from happening again. At the conclusion of its probe, the panel will make recommendations to relevant government agencies and suggest necessary legislation to enact reforms.\n\nThe resolution establishing the task force was introduced by Rep. Mike Kelly of Pennsylvania, whose district includes Butler County, where the rally was held.\n\nSeveral federal agencies have launched their own investigations into the assassination attempt, including the FBI and Secret Service. At the Department of Homeland Security, its internal watchdog is looking into the security lapses that allowed the gunman to gain access to a roof close to where Trump was speaking. Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas has also named an independent panel to investigate the shooting, which came at the direction of President Biden.\n\nThe Secret Service has come under significant criticism in the wake of the attack, and its director, Kimberly Cheatle, resigned Tuesday after a bruising day of testimony before the House Oversight and Accountability Committee.\n\nCheatle frustrated Republicans and Democrats alike with her unwillingness to provide details about the event and frequently referred to the FBI's ongoing investigation, prompting the number of lawmakers from both parties calling for her resignation to grow.\n\nFBI Director Christopher Wray appeared before the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday and shared new details with lawmakers about the gunman, identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, and his actions before he opened fire at the rally.\n\nWray revealed that on July 6, one week before the rally, the gunman conducted an online search for \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy,\" a reference to Lee Harvey Oswald, who assassinated President John F. Kennedy in 1963.\n\nThe FBI chief said he registered for Trump's rally in Butler the same day he searched for information about Kennedy's assassination, and had become \"very focused\" on Trump and the campaign event around that time.\n\nWray also told Judiciary Committee members that Crooks flew a drone near the rally site roughly two hours before he opened fire. The drone and two explosive devices were recovered from his vehicle. {"uri": "8241815901", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "19:03:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T19:03:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T19:03:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://usanews.net/life-style/chilling-google-search-made-by-trump-shooter-on-day-of-butler-rally-registration.html", "title": "Chilling Google Search Made by Trump Shooter on Day of Butler Rally Registration News", "body": "FBI Director Christopher Wray recently shared some chilling details about Thomas Matthew Crooks, the man who attempted to assassinate former President Trump during a rally in Butler, Pennsylvania. According to Wray, Crooks searched Google about the assassination of President Kennedy on the same day he registered for the Trump rally.\n\nWray's testimony before the House Judiciary Committee shed light on Crooks' state of mind leading up to the attempted assassination. The analysis of a laptop connected to Crooks revealed that on July 6, he made a Google search asking, \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" This search was significant in understanding Crooks' mindset.\n\nIt was on July 6 that Crooks registered for the Butler rally, as confirmed by Wray. This revelation has raised concerns about the motivations behind Crooks' actions and whether there were any warning signs that could have been detected earlier.\n\nThe investigation into the attempted assassination has sparked multiple hearings in Congress, with former Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle testifying before the House Oversight Committee and subsequently resigning. The House Homeland Security Committee also heard from Pennsylvania State Police before Wray's testimony.\n\nLawmakers, including Rep. Carlos Gimenez, have visited Butler to inspect the scene of the crime. Gimenez expressed disbelief that the Secret Service had not secured the roof from where Crooks fired at Trump. He climbed onto the roof himself to demonstrate that it was feasible for agents to be stationed there.\n\nCheatle had previously cited the \"sloped roof\" as a hindrance to having agents on the building. However, Gimenez's actions called this explanation into question, highlighting potential lapses in security measures that could have prevented the assassination attempt.\n\nThe investigation into Crooks' motives continues, with profilers suggesting that he may not have been politically motivated but rather an organized thinker. The search history and actions leading up to the attempted assassination paint a complex picture of a troubled individual who posed a serious threat to the former president.\n\nAs more details emerge about the events surrounding the Trump rally in Butler, Pennsylvania, questions remain about the security protocols in place and how similar incidents can be prevented in the future. {"uri": "8242119796", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-25", "time": "00:17:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-25T00:17:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-25T00:14:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-fbi-director-grilled-by-lawmakers-on-trump-rally-shooting-incident-6135432.html", "title": "World News | FBI Director Grilled by Lawmakers on Trump Rally Shooting Incident | LatestLY", "body": "Washington, DC [US], July 25 (ANI): FBI Director Christopher Wray found himself under intense scrutiny from United States lawmakers regarding the recent assassination attempt against former President Donald Trump during a rally in Pennsylvania earlier this month, Al Jazeera reported.\n\nAddressing the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, Wray vowed that the FBI would leave \"no stone unturned\" in uncovering the truth behind the attack, which he described as \"an attack on our democracy and our democratic process\".\n\nAlso Read | Bangladesh Objects to Mamata Banerjee's 'Offer' To Shelter Refugees Amid Civil Unrest in Neighbouring Country, Says 'Misleading Remarks by West Bengal CM'.\n\n\"We will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind, especially a despicable account of this magnitude,\" he said, adding, \"And I want to assure you and the American people that the men and women of the FBI will continue to work tirelessly to get to the bottom of what happened.\"\n\nThe shooting at Trump's rally on July 13 shocked the nation, resulting in the death of one attendee and leaving two others seriously injured. The assailant, identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, allegedly fired a shot that grazed Trump's ear from a rooftop position with a clear line of sight to the stage. The FBI swiftly labelled the incident as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination, although the motive behind Crooks's actions remained unclear, Al Jazeera.\n\nAlso Read | Salman Rushdie's Attacker Charged With Supporting Terrorist Group: Hadi Matar, Who Brutally Attacked Novelist in New York, Provided Material Support to Hezbollah, Says US Court.\n\nDuring his testimony, Wray disclosed significant details uncovered by the FBI's ongoing investigation. He revealed that a drone had been recovered from Crooks's vehicle, which was flown approximately 200 yards from the rally stage prior to the event.\n\n\"We're going to leave no stone unturned. The shooter might be deceased, but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing,\" the director said.\n\nThe FBI's findings so far included unsettling discoveries on Crooks's phone, where investigators found photos of Trump, President Joe Biden, and other officials. Additionally, Crooks had reportedly researched the dates of the Democratic National Convention and Trump's scheduled appearances.\n\nHowever, despite piecing together a detailed timeline of Crooks's activities and online searches, the exact motive for targeting Trump remained elusive, Al Jazeera reported.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said.\n\nThe House Judiciary Committee, chaired by Republican Congressman Jim Jordan, pressed Wray on various aspects of the investigation, including security lapses at the rally site and the presence of explosives found in Crooks's vehicle.\n\n\"We hope to learn more today from Director Wray about the shooter: his use of the drone, the explosives that were in his car, how he got on the roof and a host of other questions,\" Jordan said, adding, \"It is our hope that Director Wray's testimony can begin to give answers to the American people about all these questions and concerns.\"\n\nRepresentative Jerry Nadler, the committee's ranking Democrat, \"unequivocally and unabashedly\" condemned the assassination attempt while contextualizing it within a broader narrative of political violence in America.\n\n\"If you think that this one assassin's bullet was a bolt out of the blue and not part of a wave of violence that has threatened this nation for years, then you have missed the point,\" Nadler said.\n\nWray's appearance before lawmakers came just a day after the resignation of US Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle, who faced significant criticism over security protocols at the Trump rally. The scrutiny extended to the FBI's handling of the investigation, with some lawmakers expressing skepticism over the bureau's assertion that Crooks acted without a clear ideological motive.\n\nDespite challenges and criticism, Wray affirmed the FBI's dedication to uncovering the truth, citing parallels to historical incidents of political violence in American history, Al Jazeera reported. roughly 200 yards from the main stage between 3:50 and 4 p.m. on July 13, roughly two hours before Trump began his speech to supporters at the Butler Farm Show grounds.\n\n\"He was live-streaming the footage,\" the FBI director confirmed during a line of questioning from Judiciary chairman Jim Jordan (R-Ohio), adding that the drone was up in the air for an \"about 11 min\" window.\n\nWray also revealed that two \"relatively crude\" explosive devices were later seized from Crooks' car that were capable of remote detonation via a transmitter.\n\nThe Judiciary panel hearing comes one day after {"uri": "8241942091", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:00:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:00:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T20:56:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/fbi-director-grilled-by-lawmakers-on-trump-rally-shooting-incident/2190026/", "title": "FBI Director grilled by lawmakers on Trump rally shooting incident", "body": "Addressing the House Judiciary Committee on Wednesday, Wray vowed that the FBI would leave \"no stone unturned\" in uncovering the truth behind the attack, which he described as \"an attack on our democracy and our democratic process\".\n\n\"We will not and do not tolerate political violence of any kind, especially a despicable account of this magnitude,\" he said, adding, \"And I want to assure you and the American people that the men and women of the FBI will continue to work tirelessly to get to the bottom of what happened.\"\n\nThe shooting at Trump's rally on July 13 shocked the nation, resulting in the death of one attendee and leaving two others seriously injured. The assailant, identified as 20-year-old Thomas Matthew Crooks, allegedly fired a shot that grazed Trump's ear from a rooftop position with a clear line of sight to the stage. The FBI swiftly labelled the incident as an act of domestic terrorism and an attempted assassination, although the motive behind Crooks's actions remained unclear, Al Jazeera.\n\nDuring his testimony, Wray disclosed significant details uncovered by the FBI's ongoing investigation. He revealed that a drone had been recovered from Crooks's vehicle, which was flown approximately 200 yards from the rally stage prior to the event.\n\n\"We're going to leave no stone unturned. The shooter might be deceased, but the FBI's investigation is very much ongoing,\" the director said.\n\nThe FBI's findings so far included unsettling discoveries on Crooks's phone, where investigators found photos of Trump, President Joe Biden, and other officials. Additionally, Crooks had reportedly researched the dates of the Democratic National Convention and Trump's scheduled appearances.\n\nHowever, despite piecing together a detailed timeline of Crooks's activities and online searches, the exact motive for targeting Trump remained elusive, Al Jazeera reported.\n\n\"A lot of the usual repositories of information have not yielded anything notable in terms of motive or ideology,\" Wray said.\n\nThe House Judiciary Committee, chaired by Republican Congressman Jim Jordan, pressed Wray on various aspects of the investigation, including security lapses at the rally site and the presence of explosives found in Crooks's vehicle.\n\n\"We hope to learn more today from Director Wray about the shooter: his use of the drone, the explosives that were in his car, how he got on the roof and a host of other questions,\" Jordan said, adding, \"It is our hope that Director Wray's testimony can begin to give answers to the American people about all these questions and concerns.\"\n\nRepresentative Jerry Nadler, the committee's ranking Democrat, \"unequivocally and unabashedly\" condemned the assassination attempt while contextualizing it within a broader narrative of political violence in America.\n\n\"If you think that this one assassin's bullet was a bolt out of the blue and not part of a wave of violence that has threatened this nation for years, then you have missed the point,\" Nadler said.\n\nWray's appearance before lawmakers came just a day after the resignation of US Secret Service Director Kimberly Cheatle, who faced significant criticism over security protocols at the Trump rally. The scrutiny extended to the FBI's handling of the investigation, with some lawmakers expressing skepticism over the bureau's assertion that Crooks acted without a clear ideological motive.\n\nDespite challenges and criticism, Wray affirmed the FBI's dedication to uncovering the truth, citing parallels to historical incidents of political violence in American history, Al Jazeera reported. There were receivers at the scene for two of the devices, and Crooks had a transmitter to detonate them.\n\nHowever, Wray says because of the configuration of the on/off positions of the receivers, the devices probably wouldn't have exploded -- seemingly a testament to Crooks' inexperience in this area -- though that doesn't mean the explosives weren't dangerous.\n\nAnother revelation ... CNN previously reported that the drone was found in his car following the shooting. In addition, Crooks had two explosives in his car at the time of the shooting and one in his home, but likely did not have the ability to detonate them from the roof where he was killed, Wray testified.\n\n\"It looks like because of the on/off position on the receivers, that if he had tried to detonate those devices from the roof, it would not have worked,\" Wray said. The FBI is investigating the shooting as both an attempted assassination and as a potential act of domestic terrorism.\n\nRead more: https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/24/politics/fbi-wray-house-hearing-trump-shooting/index.html", "source": {"uri": "democraticunderground.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Democratic Underground"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CNN", "type": "org", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "CNN"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Unmanned aerial vehicle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_House_Committee_on_the_Judiciary", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "United States House Committee on the Judiciary"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "8241698105", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "17:28:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T17:28:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T17:28:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.545098066329956, "url": "https://www.democraticunderground.com/10143278525", "title": "Gunman Searched 'How Far Away Was Oswald From Kennedy?' Before Trump Shooting", "body": "Source: New York Times\n\nGunman Searched 'How Far Away Was Oswald From Kennedy?' Before Trump Shooting\n\nThe F.B.I. director, Christopher A. Wray, disclosed to lawmakers that the Google search was perhaps an early indication that the gunman began to contemplate an assassination.\n\nChristopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, revealed new details about the would-be assassin's behavior on the day of the shooting. Maansi Srivastava for The New York Times\n\nBy Adam Goldman\n\nReporting from Washington\n\nJuly 24, 2024\n\nUpdated 1:06 p.m. ET\n\nThe gunman who tried to kill former President Donald J. Trump searched online for details of John F. Kennedy's assassination a week before the shooting, apparently typing \"How far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\" the director of the F.B.I. told lawmakers on Wednesday.\n\nThe disclosure by the F.B.I. director, Christopher A. Wray, to the House Judiciary Committee, appeared to be a possible first indication that the shooter began to contemplate an assassination. That same day, July 6, he appears to have registered to attend the rally in Butler, Pa., where Mr. Trump was set to speak, Mr. Wray added. ... \"That's a search that obviously is significant in terms of his state of mind,\" Mr. Wray said, noting that the gunman's searches around that time \"became very focused on former President Trump and this rally.\"\n\nThe information about the gunman's search history was just one of several new details about the shooting that Mr. Wray disclosed to lawmakers during a lengthy hearing. ... The gunman visited the site of the rally the next day, one of three visits Mr. Wray detailed. In the first, he spent about 20 minutes at the scene. He returned twice on the day of the shooting, for about 70 minutes in the morning, and then later that afternoon, when he appeared to fly a drone in the vicinity for about 11 minutes.\n\n\"It appears that around 3:50 p.m., 4:00, in that window, on the day of the shooting, that the shooter was flying the drone around the area,\" Mr. Wray said, noting that it was \"not over the stage, but about 200 yards, give or take, away from that.\" ... The shooting left Mr. Trump's ear bloodied, killed a rallygoer who had been sitting in the stands and seriously injured two others.\n\n{snip}\n\nAdam Goldman writes about the F.B.I. and national security. He has been a journalist for more than two decades. Kennedy Assassination A Week Before Rally, FBI Says", "body": "Despite gaining access to Crooks' electronic devices, including his cellphone, investigators have yet to uncover any significant information regarding his motive or ideology.\n\nFBI Director Christopher Wray revealed during a House Judiciary Committee hearing on Wednesday that the gunman who attempted to assassinate former President Donald Trump at a Pennsylvania rally on July 13 had conducted a disturbing Google search about the assassination of President John F. Kennedy just one week prior to the shooting.\n\nThe FBI said it was still working to determine the motive behind 20-year-old Thomas Crooks' actions, which resulted in the death of one attendee and injuries to Trump and two others, CBS News reports.\n\nDespite gaining access to Crooks' electronic devices, including his cellphone, investigators have yet to uncover any significant information regarding his motive or ideology.\n\nWray's testimony highlighted the complexity of the case, as authorities strive to understand the reasoning behind Crooks' violent actions. The investigation remains ongoing, with the FBI exploring all possible leads to shed light on this disturbing incident.\n\nA chilling discovery was made on a laptop linked to Crooks. A search history revealed a disturbing query made on July 6, exactly one week before the Pennsylvania rally: \"how far away was Oswald from Kennedy?\"\n\nThis eerie search suggests Crooks may have been drawing inspiration from the infamous assassination of President John F. Kennedy by Lee Harvey Oswald in 1963.\n\nOswald fatally shot Kennedy from a sixth-floor perch at the Texas Schoolbook Depository in Dallas, with the Warren Commission later determining the distance between the two to be approximately 265.3 feet at the time of the deadly shot.\n\nThis striking search term stands out as a significant finding in the investigation, potentially offering a glimpse into Crooks' motivations or mindset leading up to the attack. {"uri": "8241521361", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "15:24:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T15:24:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T15:22:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5372549295425415, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/24/f-b-i-director-shares-new-details-in-attempted-assassination-of-trump/", "title": "F.B.I. Director Shares New Details in Attempted Assassination of Trump", "body": "Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, disclosed on Wednesday that the gunman who tried to assassinate former President Donald J. Trump appeared to have used a drone to survey the site of the shooting for about 11 minutes in the hours before Mr. Trump took the stage.\n\n\"It appears that around 3:50 p.m., 4:00, on the day of the shooting, that the shooter was flying the drone around the area,\" Mr. Wray said during his testimony, noting that it was \"not over the stage, but about 200 yards, give or take, away from that.\"\n\nThe gunfire on July 13 at a campaign rally in Butler, Pa., left Mr. Trump's ear bloodied, killed a rallygoer who had been sitting in the stands and seriously injured two others.\n\nMr. Wray said the would-be assassin operated the drone about two hours before Mr. Trump spoke at the rally.\n\nSecret Service snipers killed the gunman, Thomas Crooks, 20, after locating him on a nearby roof. Mr. Crooks was armed with an AR-15-style rifle and had magazines for the rifle and a bulletproof vest in his car. Mr. Wray confirmed that the F.B.I. recovered eight bullet cartridges from the roof where the gunman opened fire.\n\nSo far, Mr. Wray said, the F.B.I. has not found a motive for the shooting even as the investigation evolves. But the bureau continues to examine the gunman's electronic devices for additional clues about Mr. Crooks's mind-set and movements beforehand.\n\nIt is not clear what other information the F.B.I. might release during the hearing before the House Judiciary Committee, but the bureau has been forthcoming with details about the shooting since Mr. Crooks is dead. While the F.B.I. typically does not discuss continuing investigations, the extraordinary circumstances and public interest in the failed assassination attempt allow the bureau to inform the public.\n\n\"The attempted assassination of the former president was an attack on our democracy,\" Mr. Wray said. \"I recognize the congressional and public interest in this case.\"\n\nHe added that the investigation was evolving and that the gunman used encrypted messaging applications. He described explosive devices found in the gunman's car as \"crude\" but said they were able to be detonated remotely.\n\nMr. Wray said the drone operated about 200 yards from the stage, where Mr. Trump spoke.\n\nLingering questions remain about the gunman's violent trajectory and when he actually started to plan the shooting.\n\nThe F.B.I. has conducted more than 100 interviews, and scores of bureau personnel are involved in the investigation.\n\nDuring testimony before Congress on Monday, Kimberly Cheatle, the head of the Secret Service, faced withering questions from both sides of the political aisle, repeatedly declining to answer questions about the security lapses that led to the assassination attempt.\n\nOfficials investigating the matter, including lawmakers in hearings this week, have repeatedly questioned why the Secret Service's security perimeter did not include the building from which the gunman eventually fired and why no law enforcement officer was stationed there during the rally. They have also asked why Mr. Trump was allowed to take the event stage when law enforcement, including the Secret Service and the local police, was searching for a suspicious person.\n\nOn Tuesday, in the face of mounting calls that she step down, Ms. Cheatle resigned.\n\nbut he could have other details about an Iranian plot to kill Mr. Trump or other national security threats.\n\nIn the hearing on Monday with Ms. Cheatle, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative Michael Turner of Ohio, said that Mr. Wray was shocked that information about the Iranian threat was not included in the Secret Service threat assessment for Mr. Trump's rally in Butler.", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "DNyuz"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unmanned_aerial_vehicle", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Unmanned aerial vehicle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garth_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Garth Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thomas_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Thomas Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/AR-15\u2013style_rifle", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "AR-15\u2013style rifle"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. He also writes Crooks and Liars. He has a background in enterprise resource planning and previously managed the network infrastructure for the North Carolina Department of Correction.\n\nFBI Director Christopher Wray issued a warning Wednesday about how a controversial right-wing plan for Donald Trump's second term would impact law enforcement.\n\nIn a House Judiciary Committee hearing that focused on the attempted assassination of Trump, Rep. Hank Johnson (D-GA) asked Wray about the dangers of Project 2025, a presidential transition initiative organized by the Heritage Foundation.\n\n\"What he wants to do is to force the FBI director to appoint, to report directly to him,\" Johnson said of the plan. \"That's what he wants to do within the first 120 days. He also wants to eliminate the position of FBI General Counsel.\"\n\n\"I think the FBI's Office of General Counsel serves an incredibly important role, including in terms of advising our workforce,\" Wray explained. \"The idea of having an organization like ours, an independent law enforcement agency like ours that doesn't have its own general counsel's office doesn't make sense to me.\"\n\n\"That seems like it's an attempt to neuter the FBI and render it accountable only to the president,\" Johnson noted.\n\nWray acknowledged that he served at the pleasure of the president but said Project 2025 would undermine FBI independence.\n\n\"We need to be able to do our work in a way that is free from political interference,\" he pointed out.\n\n\"You wouldn't be able to do that by reporting everything you do to the president and getting his authority and approval before you take action, correct?\" Johnson asked.\n\nALSO READ: Milwaukee girded for massive convention protests. {"uri": "8241982943", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "21:36:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T21:36:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T21:35:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.dailywire.com/news/trump-demands-fbi-director-resign-after-he-told-congress-he-has-not-noticed-any-cognitive-decline-in-biden", "title": "Trump Demands FBI Director Resign After He Told Congress He Has Not Noticed Any Cognitive Decline In Biden", "body": "Former President Donald Trump called on FBI Director Christopher Wray to resign on Wednesday after the director testified before Congress that he has not noticed any cognitive decline in President Joe Biden.\n\nWray was questioned by House Republicans on Wednesday about the assassination attempt on Trump earlier this month. During the hearing, Rep. Matt Gaetz (R-FL) also questioned Wray about his interactions with Biden and if he's witnessed the president's cognitive abilities go downhill.\n\n\"I don't meet with him very often, but what you're describing is not something that I've observed during my interactions with him,\" Wray said.\n\n\"It never occurred to you that he's not up to [the job] in all these briefings you did?\" Gaetz pressed.\n\n\"As I said, my briefings with the president have all been completely fine,\" Wray replied.\n\nIn a post on Truth Social after the hearing, Trump blasted Wray, whom he nominated to serve as FBI director in 2017.\n\n\"I watched the Congressional Hearing today as Christopher Wray was asked the question whether or not he noticed any Cognitive Degeneration in his many conversations with Crooked Joe Biden and, despite the fact that Special Counsel Robert Hur said, effectively, that Joe Biden is INCOMPETENT, with LITTLE MEMORY, etc., Wray said that 'it is not something I observed during my interactions with him, which were uneventful and unremarkable,' essentially stating that he found nothing wrong, mentally or physically, with 'Joe,'\" Trump said.\n\n\"If that is the case, Director Wray should resign immediately from the FBI, and stop 'sweet talking' Congress every time he goes up, which he loves to do, because anybody can see that Joe Biden is cognitively and physically challenged, and if you can't see that, you sure as hell can't be running the FBI - Unless, that is, you want to illegally lead the Raid on Mar-a-Lago. Wray has to resign, and NOW, for LYING TO CONGRESS!\" he added.\n\nCLICK HERE TO GET THE DAILYWIRE+ APP\n\nBiden announced on Sunday that he was ending his campaign after weeks of pressure from Democrats and the media to step aside following a debate against Trump where the president appeared physically and mentally exhausted. Concerns about Biden's cognitive state also dominated headlines earlier this year when special counsel Robert Hur released his report on the investigation into Biden's handling of classified documents.\n\nIn his February report, Hur said he would not recommend charges against the president, writing at one point, \"We have also considered that, at trial, Mr. Biden would likely present himself to a jury, as he did during our interview of him, as a sympathetic, well-meaning, elderly man with a poor memory. Based on our direct interactions with and observations of him, he is someone for whom many jurors will want to identify reasonable doubt. It would be difficult to convince a jury that they should convict him-by then a former president well into his eighties-of a serious felony that requires a mental state of willfulness.\"\n\nBiden gave in to pressure to end his campaign, but said he will finish out the final months of his first term in office. Tom Tiffany, Wisconsin Republican, asked Mr. Wray if his agency considered support for former President Donald Trump and rejecting the COVID-19 vaccine among FBI personnel a security threat by senior management, to which the bureau chief responded, \"No.\"\n\nMr. Tiffany then asked who created the Trump questionnaire that was done within the FBI's investigative security division.\n\nMr. Wray said the person who made the form wasn't an FBI official.\n\n\"The document you're asking about is an interview outline that we only recently learned about and in my view is completely inappropriate,\" he told House Judiciary members.\n\n\"I asked my team to get to the bottom of what happened and to ensure it doesn't happen again. That it was created not by an FBI employee but by an outside contractor, and that individual is no longer affiliated with the FBI.\"\n\nMr. Wray said the FBI is sending what it found to the Justice Department's Office of Inspector General and will cooperate.\n\nThe FBI Security Division officials' investigation of an employee included questions about political and personal beliefs, according to whistleblower disclosures recently sent to the inspector general.\n\nTristan Leavitt, president of Empower Oversight, wrote to the IG, Michael Horowitz, that based on those documents, it's reasonable to believe the Security Division has been trying to \"purge employees with disfavored views from the FBI.\"", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "kerry_picket@washingtontimes.com", "name": "Kerry Picket", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Director_of_the_Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tom_Tiffany", "type": "person", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Tom Tiffany"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_vaccine", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "COVID-19 vaccine"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Christopher_A._Wray", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Christopher A. {"uri": "2024-07-432210700", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-24", "time": "14:17:39", "dateTime": "2024-07-24T14:17:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-24T14:13:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4313725531101227, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/2024/07/24/us/politics/fbi-director-wray-trump-shooting-hearing.html", "title": "Lawmakers Press Wray Over Attempted Assassination of Trump", "body": "Christopher A. Wray, the F.B.I. director, appeared on Wednesday before Congress, where he is expected to face a barrage of questions about the attempted assassination of former President Donald J. Trump.\n\nThe F.B.I. is investigating the shooting on July 13 at a campaign rally for Mr. Trump in Butler, Pa. The shooting left Mr. Trump's ear bloodied, killed a rallygoer who had been sitting in the stands and seriously injured two others.\n\nSecret Service snipers killed the gunman, Thomas Crooks, 20, after locating him on a nearby roof. Mr. Crooks was armed with an AR-15-style rifle and had magazines for the rifle and a bulletproof vest in his car.\n\nSo far, the F.B.I. has not a found a motive for the shooting. But the bureau continues to examine the gunman's electronic devices looking for additional clues about Mr. Crooks's mind-set and movements beforehand.\n\nIt is not clear what other information the F.B.I. might release during the hearing before the House Judiciary Committee, but the bureau has been forthcoming with details about the shooting since Mr. Crooks is dead. While the F.B.I. typically does not discuss continuing investigations, the extraordinary circumstances and public interest in the failed assassination attempt allow the bureau to inform the public.\n\nLingering questions remain about the gunman's violent trajectory and when he actually started to plan the shooting.\n\nThe F.B.I. has conducted more than 100 interviews, and scores of bureau personnel are involved in the investigation.\n\nDuring testimony before Congress on Monday, Kimberly Cheatle, the head of the Secret Service, faced withering questions from both sides of the political aisle, repeatedly declining to answer questions about the security lapses that led to the assassination attempt.\n\nOfficials investigating the matter, including lawmakers in hearings this week, have repeatedly questioned why the Secret Service's security perimeter did not include the building from which the gunman eventually fired and why no law enforcement officer was stationed there during the rally. They have also asked why Mr. Trump was allowed to take the event stage when law enforcement, including the Secret Service and the local police, was searching for a suspicious person.\n\nOn Tuesday, in the face of mounting calls that she step down, Ms. Cheatle resigned.\n\nMr. Wray is not expected to face the same level of criticism since the F.B.I. was not directly involved in protecting the president on July 13, but he could have other details about an Iranian plot to kill Mr. Trump or other national security threats.\n\nIn the hearing on Monday with Ms. Cheatle, the chairman of the House Intelligence Committee, Representative Michael Turner of Ohio, said that Mr. Wray was shocked that information about the Iranian threat was not included in the Secret Service threat assessment for Mr. Trump's rally in Butler.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "adam_goldman@nytimes.com", "name": "Adam Goldman", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Garth_Crooks", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Garth Crooks"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_Bureau_of_Investigation", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Federal Bureau of Investigation"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_F.B.I._(TV_series)", "type": "wiki", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "The F.B.I.
